questions.text: A male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. He gives a history of consuming raw refrigerated vegetables 24 hours back. What is the type of motility shown by the most likely etiologic organism when it is cultured at 25°C?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of food poisoning caused by Listeria monocytogenes. Listeria monocytogenes shows slow tumbling motility when grown at 25°C. 

L. monocytogenes is a short, Gram-positive, non-spore-forming rod. It is catalase positive and has tumbling end-over-end motility at 22–28°C but is non-motile at 37°C. This is because the peritrichous flagella are produced by the bacillus optimally between 20°C and 30°C.

It enters the body through the gastrointestinal tract after ingestion of contaminated foods such as cheese, fruit, or vegetables especially refrigerated items (the bacteria survives well at 4°C in the refrigerator). It causes a mild, self-limiting febrile gastroenteritis which lasts for 1–3 days. The incubation period is 6–48 hours. Symptoms include fever, chills, headache, myalgias, abdominal pain, and diarrhea.

The drug of choice is ampicillin with gentamicin.

The image below shows the tumbling motility of L. monocytogenes.

Other options:

Swarming motility is seen with Bacillus cereus. It has two distinct forms: the emetic type, which is associated with fried rice, milk, and pasta, and the diarrheal type, which is associated with meat dishes and sauces. The incubation period for the emetic group is 30 minutes to 6 hours and they present with nausea and vomiting. The incubation period for the diarrheal group is 6 - 15 hours and they present with watery diarrhea and abdominal cramps.

Darting motility is seen with Vibrio cholerae. It is actively motile with a polar flagellum. It results in watery diarrhea with characteristic rice watery stools. Shellfish (oysters), especially raw and undercooked food, are the common source for Vibrio species, especially V. parahaemolyticus. 

Falling motility is seen with Giardia lamblia. It is the common pathogenic protozoan found in the duodenum of humans. Infection is acquired by the consumption of water or food contaminated with cysts and may also be transmitted by the feco-oral route. The symptoms include acute or chronic diarrhoea, weight loss, malaise, abdominal cramps, distension, and weakness.

Related Pearl: Types of motility of microorganisms

Motility Microorganism

Tumbling motility  Listeria monocytogenes

questions.text: A tanner presents to the OPD with fever and  a lesion near the wrist as  shown in the image. The lesion appeared as a swelling and became vesicular over 3-4 days and started oozing blood-stained discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the image showing necrotic ulcer with a characteristic black eschar is suggestive of cutaneous anthrax which is caused by Bacillus anthracis.

It is commonly seen in tanners or hide porters who come in contact with infected animal hide and skins.

Malignant pustule is seen in infection of Bacillus anthracis.

In cutaneous anthrax, the lesion starts as a papule 1-3 days after infection and becomes vesicular, containing fluid that may be clear or blood-stained.

The whole area is congested and edematous and several satellite lesions filled with serum or yellow fluid are arranged around a central necrotic lesion which is covered by a black eschar.

This lesion is called a malignant pustule.

The disease used to be common in dock workers, carrying loads of hides and skins on their bare backs and hence known as hide porter’s disease.

Cutaneous Anthrax generally resolves spontaneously, but 10 – 20% of untreated patients may develop fatal septicaemia or meningitis.

questions.text: In a village, out of 20 women taking contraceptives this year, 7 women reported that they conceived accidentally. During the review period, the duration of exposure to the contraceptive was 30 months for all of these women. Calculate the pearl index.
questions.solution:
The pearl index in this case is 14. Pearl index is defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure

In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, whatever its outcome. 

Total accidental pregnancies  = 7

In the denominator, the total months of exposure to oral contraceptives are considered. The total period under review is 20 women x 30 months each = 600 months.

Substituting the values in the above equation, we get:

Pearl index = (7 x 1200)/600 = 14 per 100 woman-years of exposure(HWY)

 

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: A person presents to the emergency department with suspected poisoning due to ingestion of arsenic-containing pesticides 6 hours ago. Which of the following would you not expect to find?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is indicative of acute arsenic poisoning. Mees lines are unlikely to be found in a patient with arsenic ingestion 6 hours ago. It is seen in chronic poisoning. 

Features of acute arsenic poisoning:

  • Severe watery diarrhea (like cholera)
  • QTc prolongation and cardiac arrhythmias
  • Acute encephalopathy
  • Renal injury with acute tubular necrosis
  • Garlic odor of breath and stools

Mees lines are horizontal 1 to 2 mm white lines on the nails, also called transverse leukonychia. They occur due to a disturbance in the nail matrix keratinization. It may be seen 4 to 6 weeks after acute arsenic ingestion. These can also be seen in thallium poisoning.

The image given below shows Mees lines.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient was referred to you for the evaluation of renal stones. His urine microscopy shows the following type of crystals. Which statement is incorrect about the type of calculus involved?

choices.text: They have a high sulfur content
Formation of multiple stones is common

questions.solution:
Urine microscopy shows Hexagonal crystals, typical of cystine stones that are radio-opaque (due to high sulfur content).

Cystine stones are often multiple, and very hard. 

Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy is a non-invasive method of treating urinary tract stones by generating shockwaves outside the body which are focused on the stones. Cystine stones are relatively resistant to ESWL due to their hardness.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: You are working as a medical officer in a primary health center. On 5th May 2023, you took a look at these 4 vaccine vials. Vial 1 had an expiry date of 4th May 2023 and the rest of the vials had an expiry date of 14th October 2023. Which of the following vials could be used?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, only vial 2 can be used.

According to the vaccine vial monitor, vial 1 and vial 2 can be used, but vial 2 is the one that was really fit for use as it had not yet expired as on 5th May 2023. Whereas, vial 1 has crossed the date of expiry.

Vial 3 and vial 4 should be discarded even though the drug has not expired. This is because the color in the inner square has matched the outer circle in vial 3 and is darker than the outer circle in vial 4.

Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are chemical indicator labels which are used to monitor the heat stability of the vaccines and are useful throughout the vaccine supply chain. The VVMs are designed to ensure that heat-damaged vaccines are not given to the patients. They also indicate preferable order of usage of the vials, thereby minimising vaccine wastage. 

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: In a research study, a researcher is studying the effect of special intensive care in a study population consisting of at-risk infants. All of the following would be considered as one of the criteria to include the infant in the study population, except:
questions.solution:
Birth order 5 or more (not >3) is considered as one of the criteria for categorizing the infant as 'at-risk'.

At a child health clinic, the criteria to identify at-risk infants include:

  • Birth weight less than 2.5 kgs
  • Twins 
  • Birth order of 5 or more
  • Artificial feeding
  • Weight below 70% of the expected weight
  • Failure to gain weight during 3 successive months
  • Children with PEM, diarrhoea
  • Working mother or single parent

The at-risk infants contribute largely to the perinatal, neonatal and infant mortality. Hence, a special intensive care, is usually suggested for these infants.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman who was on a diet consisting predominantly of packaged and reheated meals presents with iron-deficiency anemia, painful and tender joints, and bleeding manifestations. Which of the following antioxidant deficiency can lead to these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Dietary deficiency of Vitamin C can lead to scurvy which can manifest as microcytic anemia, defective collagen synthesis, and bleeding manifestations.

Vitamin C is a water-soluble vitamin. It is mainly required for the hydroxylation of prolyl and lysyl residues of collagen reactions. It also maintains vitamin E and many metal cofactors (eg. copper) in a reduced state. It also facilitates the absorption of iron by reducing it from a ferric to a ferrous state.

Hence, vitamin C deficiency leads to defective collagen synthesis, fragile blood vessels, and iron deficiency anemia. Other clinical features of scurvy include spongy gums, loose teeth, swollen joints, subcutaneous hemorrhage, and bone fractures.

Other options:

Option A- Glutathione, an antioxidant, is present in glutathione peroxidase. It helps in the destruction of hydrogen peroxide and lipid hydroperoxides.

Option B- β-carotene is provitamin A, found in plants. It helps in the formation of retinaldehyde which is utilized in vision. It also regulates gene expression and cell differentiation.

Option D- Zinc is an essential component of several metalloenzymes like carboxypeptidases, carbonic anhydrase II, adenosine deaminase, the cytosolic form of superoxide dismutase, etc. Chronic zinc deficiency causes stunting and increases the risk of respiratory and diarrheal diseases. Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder that causes abnormalities in zinc absorption.

questions.text: All of the following are included among the major criteria of the modified Duke's criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis, except _____.

choices.text: Echocardiography showing endocardial involvement with definite vegetations
Coxiella burnetii anti-phase I IgG antibody titer greater than 1:800
At least two consecutive positive blood cultures for Coxiella burnetii

questions.solution:
Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii is one of the major criteria of modified Duke's criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis. All other options are true.

Infective endocarditis is associated with bacterial or fungal infection of the valvular or endocardial surface of the heart. The definitive diagnosis can only be established by histological and microbiological examinations of the vegetation.

However, a diagnostic schema called, modified Duke criteria, is usually used for diagnosis. The criteria are based on clinical, laboratory, and echocardiographic findings commonly encountered in patients with endocarditis, as described below.

The diagnosis is made based on the presence of

  • Two major criteria, or
  • One major and three minor criteria, or
  • Five minor criteria.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old-lady with CKD presents with bilateral limb muscle weakness and fasciculations. On investigation, her serum potassium level was found to be 6 mEq/L. What is the likely mechanism to have caused her clinical features?

choices.text: Resting membrane potential of nerves is hyperpolarised
Resting membrane potential moved closer to the threshold potential
Resting membrane potential moved away from threshold potential

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly lady with CKD presenting with bilateral limb muscle weakness and fasciculations along with serum potassium levels of 6 mEq/L (normal levels: 3.5-5) is suggestive of hyperkalemia. Resting membrane potential moved closer to the threshold potential is the likely mechanism to have caused her clinical features. 

Resting membrane potential (RMP) is the difference in the electrical potentials between the cytoplasm of the cell and the extracellular space. 

At rest, there are more open K+ channels compared to Na+ channels, thus the membrane permeability of K+ is greater. As a result of this, the intracellular and extracellular K+ concentrations are the major determinants of the RMP. Furthermore, the RMP is close to the equilibrium potential of K+ in general. 

In hyperkalemia, the extracellular level of K+ is increased. Thus the RMP moves closer to the threshold to elicit an action potential leading to a more excitable nerve. The excitable nerve stimulates the muscle repeatedly causing fasciculations, exhaustion of muscle, and weakness.

In hypokalemia, the extracellular level of K+ is reduced. Thus the RMP is reduced and the neuron is hyperpolarized.

Related Pearl: Resting membrane potential (RMP) in tissues

Tissue

RMP(mV)

Neuron

-70

Skeletal muscle

-90

Myocardial muscle

-90

Smooth muscle

-20 to -65

questions.text: A 50-year-old hypertensive patient develops right-sided tongue deviation, inability to move his left hand and leg. He has a diminished touch sensation on the left side. There are intact pain and temperature sensations on the left side and the face is spared. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features point towards a diagnosis of Medial Medullary syndrome.

The characteristic triad of 

  • Ipsilateral tongue weakness with deviation toward the lesion due to the lower motor neuron lesion of CN XII
  • Contralateral touch and proprioceptive loss due to medial lemniscus involvement
  • Contralateral hemiparesis due to pyramidal tract involvement.

Contralateral loss of pain and temperature would be seen, in a lesion of the ventrolateral spinothalamic tract. Medial medullary syndrome spares the lateral spinothalamic tract, hence Contralateral pain and temperature sensations are preserved.

Other options

Lateral medullary syndrome and Brown Sequard syndrome involve the ventrolateral spinothalamic tract, hence pain and temperature sensation won't be intact unlike this case.

Ventrolateral cord can be surgically ablated to relieve chronic pain conditions on the opposite side.

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

Syndrome

Vessel involved

Clinical features

Medial Medullary syndrome / Dejerine syndrome

Vertebral artery/Anterior spinal artery
  • C/L loss of conscious proprioception
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • I/L tongue paralysis

Lateral Medullary syndrome / Wallenberg syndrome

Vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • C/L loss of pain/temperature on the body
  • I/L loss of pain/temperature on face
  • Ataxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Vertigo
  • Horner's syndrome
  • dysphagia
  • Ipsilateral bulbar paralysis
  • Loss of gag reflex

  • C/L hemiplegia

questions.text: A man presented with fatigue and a mass in the left upper abdomen. On examination, there was massive splenomegaly with no lymphadenopathy. Investigations revealed pancytopenia. His peripheral blood smear is given below. Immunohistochemistry revealed tumor cells to be positive for annexin A1, CD22, CD25, and CD103. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image shows hairy cells i.e. abnormal B cells having round nuclei and pale blue cytoplasm with thread-like extensions. So the likely diagnosis is hairy cell leukemia. 

Hairy cell leukaemia is a rare type of B-cell tumour involving small lymphocytes. The specific activating point mutation is in the serine/ threonine kinase BRAFV600E.

Symptoms occur due to infiltration of bone marrow, liver and spleen. Clinical features include:

  • Massive splenomegaly and hepatomegaly. Lymphadenopathy is rare
  • Pancytopenia - due to marrow involvement can also be seen
  • Monocytopenia - leads to increased incidence of atypical mycobacterial infections

Routine peripheral smear shows hairy cells (abnormal B cells) having round, oblong or reniform nuclei and pale blue cytoplasm with thread-like extensions as shown below. 

Hairy cell leukaemia is limited to the red pulp of the spleen which is heavily infiltrated. This leads to obliteration of white pulp and a beefy red gross appearance. 

The pattern of bone marrow involvement on biopsy specimens is pathognomonic for hairy cell leukemia.

  • Diffuse infiltration of tumor cells with honeycomb appearance
  • Individual cells have a fried egg appearance i.e. the nucleus of each hairy cell is surrounded by a halo of cytoplasm
  • Dry tap is obtained upon performing bone marrow aspiration due to marrow fibrosis and the interlocking cell borders of hairy cells

The image given below shows small cells with clear cytoplasm and a round central nucleus ("fried egg"-like appearance).

Tests for hairy cell leukemia include:

  • CD11c, CD25 and CD103 are the characteristic immunophenotype diagnostic markers
  • Pan-B markers such as CD19, CD20, and CD22 also test positive 
  • Annexin A1 on bone marrow specimens have been shown to have 100% sensitivity and specificity in differentiating hairy cell leukemia from other B cell malignancies.
  • Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) stain is an important tool in the clinical diagnosis of hairy cell leukemia and yields positive results in  majority of the cases.

Management of hairy cell leukemia include:

  • Splenectomy
  • Cladribine (first line agent) and deoxycoformycin are highly active nucleoside agents that cause durable remissions in patients.

Other options:

Option A: Primary myelofibrosis is the replacement of the marrow by fibrous tissue leading to reduced bone marrow haematopoiesis. This results in cytopenia, and extramedullary haematopoiesis (in the spleen mainly). The peripheral blood smear shows tear drop-shaped red cells (dacrocytes).

Option C: Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell tumor. Patients present with lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, renal failure, and acquired immune abnormalities. Plasma cell tumors are positive for CD138, syndecan-1 (adhesion molecule), and CD56. Bone-marrow biopsy shows mott cells (a variant of plasma cell) with globular inclusions called Russell bodies (if cytoplasmic) or Dutcher bodies (if nuclear).

Option D: Mantle cell lymphomas express high levels of cyclin D1, CD19, and CD20. The tumor is usually CD5+ and CD23−. Painless lymphadenopathy is the most common presentation. Other organs involved are spleen and gut.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented with fatigue, growth retardation, and neurologic abnormalities. Peripheral blood smear revealed megaloblastic anaemia. The condition did not improve with administration of vitamin B12 and folate, but responded to treatment with uridine. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Megaloblastic anaemia that is responsive to uridine is consistent with orotic aciduria.

Orotic aciduria is a rare inborn error of metabolism in children. A defect in the enzyme uridine-5′-monophosphate (UMP) synthase in the pyrimidine synthesis pathway results in the failure of conversion of orotic acid to uridine. As a result, there is increased excretion of orotic acid in urine.

The condition is characterized by hypochromic megaloblastic anaemia that is unresponsive to vitamin B12 and folic acid, growth retardation, and neurologic abnormalities.

Treatment includes, administration of uridine (100–200 mg/kg per day), which corrects anaemia, reduces orotic acid excretion and improves the other sequelae of the disorder.

 

Causes of megaloblastic anaemia:-

  • Cobalamin deficiency/abnormalities of cobalamin metabolism: Nutritional, Malabsorption, absence of intrinsic factor, total/ partial gastrectomy.
  • Folate deficiency/ abnormalities of folate metabolism.
  • Therapy with antifolate drugs e.g., methotrexate.
  • Independent of cobalamin/folate deficiency:
    • Acute myeloid leukaemia, myelodysplasia.
    • Therapy with drugs interfering with the synthesis of DNA (e.g., cytosine arabinoside, hydroxyurea, 6-mercaptopurine).
    • Orotic aciduria (responds to uridine).

 

Other options:

The enzyme defects mentioned in the other options are not associated with megaloblastic anemia.

Option a: Dihydropyrimidine Dehydrogenase is responsible for the degradation of uracil and thiamine. Deficiency of the enzyme causes excessive urinary excretion of uracil and thymine.

Option b: Hereditary Xanthinuria is caused due to deficiency of xanthine oxidase, which causes all purine in the urine to occur in the form of hypoxanthine and xanthine.

Option c: Adenylosuccinate Lyase Deficiency is associated with profound psychomotor retardation, seizures, and other movement disorders.

Hemolysis*

 

*Hemolysis can be associated with macrocytosis because of compensatory reticulocytosis. However, MCV can be normal depending on the degree of hemolysis.

Note: In Orotic Aciduria, peripheral blood smear shows Hypochromic megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: A middle-aged patient presented to the outpatient clinic with frontal bossing, a large tongue, spade-shaped hands, and a protruding lower jaw as shown in the image. The physician prescribed pegvisomant for his condition. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this drug?

choices.text: It is a  growth hormone receptor antagonist
It activates JAK-STAT signaling pathway and stimulates IGF-1 secretion
Liver function tests should be monitored in all patients

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding pegvisomant is, it activates the JAK-STAT signaling pathway and stimulates IGF-1 (insulin-like growth factor 1) secretion.

The image of a middle-aged man with frontal bossing, a large tongue, a protruding lower jaw, and spade-shaped hands, are highly suggestive of acromegaly. Acromegaly is a clinical syndrome that results from the excessive secretion of growth hormones.

Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist. It is indicated for the treatment of acromegaly. Pegvisomant binds to the GHR but does not activate JAK-STAT signaling and does not stimulate IGF-1 secretion.

Insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) levels are used to screen for acromegaly. The diagnosis is confirmed by demonstrating that GH concentration is >1 ng/mL after 2 hours of an oral glucose load (75 g). The drug Pegvisomant is administered subcutaneously (a 40 mg loading dose, followed by administration of 10 mg/day). Liver function tests should be monitored in all patients because of the risk of elevation of hepatic transaminases. Lipohypertrophy can also occur at injection sites.

Related Pearl: Tests for Acromegaly

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

 

Related Pearl: Classification of Pituitary Adenomas with Associated Syndromes

The various types of pituitary tumors are listed in decreasing order of frequency:

Adenoma cell origin

Hormone

Clinical features

Lactotroph

Prolactin

Galactorrhea and amenorrhea (in females)

Sexual dysfunction, infertility

Gonadotroph

 FSH, LH subunits

Hypogonadism, mass effects, and hypopituitarism

Somatotroph 

GH

Gigantism (children)

Acromegaly (adults)

Corticotroph

 ACTH

Cushing's disease

Nelson's syndrome

Mammosomatotroph

Prolactin, GH

Hypogonadism, galactorrhea, acromegaly

Thyrotroph 

TSH

Hyperthyroidism

 

GH: Growth hormone

ACTH: Adrenocorticotropic hormone

TSH: Thyroid-stimulating hormone

FSH: Follicle-stimulating hormone

LH: Luteinizing hormone

questions.text: A new investigation modality for detecting early breast cancer is being validated in a study population of 100 women. The test was positive in 50 patients, of whom 30 actually had breast cancer. Among those who were tested negative, 10 patients had breast cancer. What is the  negative predictive value?
questions.solution:
The negative predictive value in the given case is 80%.

Negative predictive value implies the probability of a person with a negative test, definitely not having the disease.

Negative predictive value (NPV) = TN/(FN + TN)

 

Calculation:

The data given in the question can be recorded in the table as follows:

  Disease Present Disease Absent Total

Test

Positive

 30
(True positive - TP)		 20
(False positive - FP)		 50

Test

Negative

 10
(False negative - FN)		 40
(True negative - TN)		 50
Total 40 60 100

NPV = TN/(FN + TN)

= 40/(50) x 100

= 4/5 x 100

= 80%

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: A cholecystectomy is performed on a 47-year-old obese female with gall stones. The specimen shows the presence of non pigmented stones as shown below. These calculi are most likely to be associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above image shows non pigmented cholestrol gallstones, which can be seen in hyperlipidemia syndromes.

Dyslipidemia is a risk factor for the development of cholesterol gallstones.

There are two main types of gallstones:

  • Cholesterol stones, which consist of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate
  • Pigment stones, made of bilirubin calcium salts

Options A, B, and C: Chronic hemolytic syndromes, ileal resection, and biliary infection can cause pigment stones.

questions.text:
A patient presented with lethargy and muscle cramps. He was diagnosed with SIADH. Which of the following drugs can be administered orally for the management of his condition?

SIADH - Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion
questions.solution:
Tolvaptan is a selective oral V2 receptor antagonist that is FDA-approved for and is effective in clinically significant hyponatremia associated with SIADH.

SIADH is a condition where there is an inappropriate release of antidiuretic hormone or arginine vasopressin (AVP) from ectopic production of AVP. This may be from lung cancer and other neoplasms, increased release induced by various diseases, drugs, or exogenous administration of AVP. It is characterized by impaired water excretion leading to hyponatremia with euvolemia or hypervolemia. 

ADH promotes the reabsorption of water and not the solutes resulting in concentrated urine. This is depicted as high urine osmolality.

Patients usually present with hyponatremia with a euvolemic status. If hyponatremia develops acutely, signs and symptoms may include mild headache, confusion, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, coma, and convulsions. Chronic hyponatremia allows cerebral adaptation, and the patients are asymptomatic despite the hyponatremia.

Laboratory findings in SIADH:

  • Hyponatremia: serum Na+<135 mEq/L
  • Urinary loss of Na+ >25 mEq per day or >40 mEq/L 
  • Urinary osmolality is >100 mOsm/kg
  • Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels are low, usually <10 mg/dL
  • Serum K+ and serum bicarbonate are normal

Treatment: Hyponatremia should be corrected gradually. Restriction of the total fluid intake. Sodium levels can be corrected using hypertonic saline. Tolvaptan and conivaptan are vasopressin receptor-2 antagonists that block the action of anti-diuretic hormones. Other drugs which are useful in the management are demeclocycline and fludrocortisone.

Other options:

Options A and D: Terlipressin and desmopressin are not used in the treatment of SIADH. SIADH is a condition of inappropriate ADH secretion. Since excess vasopressin is the cause of SIADH, giving vasopressin analogs as desmopressin would only worsen the condition. 

Option C: Conivaptan is a nonselective V1a receptor/V2 receptor antagonist that is FDA-approved for the treatment of hospitalized patients with euvolemic and hypervolemic hyponatremia. It is available only for intravenous infusion.

Related Pearl: Causes of SIADH

Neoplasms

Carcinomas

questions.text: You diagnose peripartum cardiomyopathy based on Pearson's criteria in a 30-year-old woman, who presented with dyspnea during the last month of pregnancy. A transthoracic echocardiogram done in this patient would demonstrate classic features of _________
questions.solution:
Left ventricular systolic dysfunction on transthoracic echocardiogram. 

Pearson's criteria is used to diagnose peripartum cardiomyopathy. It includes,

  • Development of cardiac failure in the last month of pregnancy or within 5 months after delivery.
  • Absence of an identifiable cause for the cardiac failure
  • Absence of recognizable heart disease prior to the last month of pregnancy
  • Left ventricular systolic dysfunction demonstrated by classic echocardiographic criteria, such as depressed ejection fraction or fractional shortening along with a dilated left ventricle.

questions.text: In which of the following patients would you least prefer to perform an endoscopic sinus surgery?

choices.text: A 49-year-old diabetic male suffering from Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball
A 44-year-old Chronic bacterial sinusitis that is unresponsive to adequate medical treatment.
A 33-year-old with frontal osteomyelitis with Potts puffy tumor
A 38-year-old with mucocele of sphenoid sinus

questions.solution:
Among the given options, endoscopic sinus surgery would be least preferable in a 33-year-old with frontal osteomyelitis with Potts puffy tumor. Osteomyelitis is considered a contraindication for endoscopic sinus surgery. The rest of the options indicate patients who would be considered candidates for endoscopic sinus surgery.

The following are considered indications for endoscopic sinus surgery.

  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis.
  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis unresponsive to adequate medical treatment.
  • Antrochoanal polyp
  • Polypoid rhinosinusitis/ diffuse nasal polyposis.
  • Fungal sinusitis with a fungal ball or nasal polypi.
  • Mucocele of frontoethmoid or sphenoid sinus.
  • Control of epistaxis by endoscopic cautery.
  • Removal of foreign body from the nose or sinus.

The Contraindications include:

  • Disease inaccessible by endoscopic procedures, Ex:- lateral frontal sinus disease and stenosis of the internal opening of frontal sinus.
  • Osteomyelitis
  • Threatened intracranial or intraorbital complication

questions.text: During the internship, a senior resident asks you to plot a partograph to monitor the progress of labour. All the following options represent the correct steps that you would follow while plotting the WHO partograph except ______

choices.text: Plotting should start when cervix is dilated 6 cm or more
Record maternal pulse rate every 30 minutes

questions.solution:
All the above options represent the correct steps that you would follow while plotting the WHO partograph except option B. The graph must be plotted only when the cervix is 4 cm or more dilated 

The partograph is a graphic record of the progress of labour and relevant details of the mother and fetus.

The observations that are recorded will document the following:

  • Maternal well-being: Record pulse rate every 30 minutes, Blood pressure and Temperature 4-hourly
  • Fetal well-being: Record fetal heart rate for 1 minute every 15–30 minutes after a contraction in the first stage, and every 5 minutes in the second stage.
  • Uterine contractions (assessed by palpation): record every 30 minutes.
  • Liquor: clear, meconium-stained (thick or thin), bloody or absent. Thick meconium suggests fetal distress, and closer monitoring of the fetus is indicated. Check every 30 minutes

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: The following tube used to collect blood for coagulation study contains
questions.solution:
The most commonly used vacutainer for coagulation studies is a blue vacutainer containing trisodium citrate.

Image shows color coding of vacutainers with the anticoagulant used and their practical uses:

Some important plastic tubes and their additives:

Cap color Additive present
Red top Clot activator
Dark green top Heparin
Purple top EDTA
Pale yellow top Acid citrate dextrose
Light grey top Sodium fluoride and potassium oxalate

Note:

Heparin tubes can have sodium heparin or lithium heparin. For measuring lithium levels, sodium heparin is only used. For measuring ammonia levels both can be used.

Related Pearl: Anticoagulants in Vacutainers and their Uses

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient who had been advised enucleation is brought to you for a second opinion. You would inform him that it is an absolute indication if his diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Retinoblastoma is an absolute indication for Enucleation operation.

Enucleation operation: It is the complete excision of an eyeball.

Absolute indications are:

  • Retinoblastoma
  • Malignant melanoma

Note: Indication for eye donation: Removal of eyes from the cadaver is presently the most common indication for enucleation.

Few other important definitions:

Evisceration operation:

It is the removal of the contents of the eyeball leaving behind the sclera. Frill evisceration is preferred over simple evisceration. In this, only about 3mm frill of the sclera is left around the optic nerve.

Indications of evisceration

  • Panophthalmitis
  • Expulsive choroidal hemorrhage
  • Bleeding anterior staphyloma

Exenteration is a mutilating surgery in which all contents of the orbits along with periorbita are removed. It is indicated for malignant tumors arising from the orbital structures or spreading from the eyeball.

Debulking involves reduction of as much of the bulk (volume) of a tumor as possible. Nowadays, debulking of the orbit is preferred over exenteration.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of watery diarrhea, dehydration, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria. Which of the following neuroendocrine tumors can be responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of VIPoma.

Vasoactive intestinal peptide-secreting tumors (VIPomas) are neuroendocrine tumors that secrete excessive amounts of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP). The condition is known as Verner–Morrison syndrome or WDHA syndrome.

WDHA stands for:

  • WD - Watery Diarrhea
  • H – Hypokalemia
  • A – Achlorhydria

Diagnosis can be made by the demonstration of an elevated plasma VIP level and the history of large-volume diarrhoea.

Treatment includes correction of dehydration, hypokalemia, and electrolyte losses with fluid and electrolyte replacement. Long-acting somatostatin analogues such as octreotide and lanreotide are the drug of choice.

 

 

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Clinical features

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A newborn presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was diagnosed to be cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. Which of the following statements is incorrect?

choices.text: It is a severe form of mitochondrial disorder
Very-long chain fatty acids (VLCFA) levels are increased
Most patients die in the first year of life

questions.solution:
A cerebrohepatorenal syndrome is a rare inherited absence of peroxisomes (not a mitochondrial disorder). It occurs due to mutations in genes encoding proteins called peroxins, involved in peroxisome biogenesis.

It is a form of leukodystrophy (white matter lesion). Such individuals accumulate C26-C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissues and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. It causes severe neurological symptoms and most patients die in the first year of life. Very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA) levels are increased in cerebrohepatorenal syndrome.

Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome belongs to the Zellweger spectrum. The other two conditions in this spectrum are Adrenoleukodystrophy and Infantile Refsum disease in decreasing order of severity.

Other options:

Most patients die in the first year of life. It is autosomal recessive in inheritance, patients might be asymptomatic carriers.

There is an accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids, abnormalities in bile acid synthesis, and a marked reduction of plasmalogens.

questions.text: A biochemist is working on a study of enzyme activation in the fed and fasting state. He gives a dose of insulin to the study animal. Which of the following enzymes will be activated in response to this dose?
questions.solution:
Pyruvate dehydrogenase is highly active in the high insulin/well-fed/dephosphorylated state.

The rest of the enzymes are active in the phosphorylated state/low insulin/fasting state.

Fasting state / low insulin state :

Liver :

With a fall in the blood glucose levels, there is a fall in insulin levels with less uptake of glucose by muscle and adipose tissues. α-cells of the pancreas secrete glucagon which inhibits glycogen synthetase and in turn activates glycogen phosphorylase. This eventually releases glucose into the bloodstream intended for the use of the brain and RBCs. Glucagon stimulates the production of cAMP, activating cAMP-dependent protein kinase. This in turn inactivates phosphofructokinase-2 and activates fructose 2,6-bisphosphatase by phosphorylation.

Muscle: 

Acetyl-CoA formed by oxidation of fatty acids causes inhibition of pyruvate dehydrogenase consequently leading to an accumulation of pyruvate. It is then converted to alanine which is then transaminated back to pyruvate in the liver. This is used as a substrate for gluconeogenesis.

Adipose tissue:

A fall in insulin and an increase in glucagon leads to inhibition of lipogenesis and activation of hormone-sensitive lipase. This leads to a massive release of glycerol which serves as a substrate for gluconeogenesis in the liver. It is also utilised by the liver, heart, and skeletal muscle as metabolic fuel.

As fasting progresses, acetyl-CoA is used for the synthesis of ketone bodies which are utilised by skeletal and heart muscles and up to 20% of the brain's energy source. After 18 hours of fasting, amino acids from protein catabolism are utilized by the liver and kidneys for gluconeogenesis.

Related Pearl: Enzymes active in phosphorylated and dephosphorylated state

Phosphorylated state

(Low insulin)

Dephosphorylated state

(High insulin)
  • Fructose 2,6 bisphosphatase
  • PEP carboxykinase
  • Pyruvate carboxylase
  • Glycogen phosphorylase
  • Hormone-sensitive lipase
  • Phosphofructokinase
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Glycogen synthase
  • Acetyl CoA carboxylase
  • HMG CoA reductase

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with gastroparesis with decreased gastric emptying. He should avoid food rich in
questions.solution:
In a person with gastroparesis, gastric emptying is decreased due to decreased stomach motility. Fats and fibrous food take the most time to empty from stomach and hence should be avoided.

Gastric emptying is fastest for fluids and carbohydrates, followed by proteins and last by fats. Raw vegetables high in fibre also delay the gastric emptying and hence should be cooked until soft for consumption.

 Sometimes, undigested food may form a mass called as bezoar, it may also impede gastric emptying. It then needs to be broken endoscopically.

Related Pearl: Factors regulating gastric emptying

Factors that Increase gastric emptying

Factors that Decrease gastric emptying

Distension of the stomach

Distension of the duodenum

Food rich in carbohydrate

Food rich in fats > proteins

Stimulation of parasympathetic nervous system

Stimulation of sympathetic nervous system

 

Presence of fat in duodenum

 

High acidity (low pH) of the duodenal chyme

Isotonic chyme

Hypertonic >>hypotonic duodenal content

 

Breakdown products of protein digestion in the duodenum

 

Presence of any irritation in the duodenal mucosa

Gastrin

CCK, Secretin, GIP

questions.text: A pediatric resident had advised for genetic evaluation in a child diagnosed with Hereditary spherocytosis. Genetic studies showed mutations in α-Spectrin protein. The pattern of inheritance associated with this mutation is likely to be
questions.solution:
Hereditary spherocytosis due to mutation in α-Spectrin protein shows an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance.

Hereditary spherocytosis(HS) is caused by inherited defects in the proteins stabilizing the red cell membrane. It is the most common inherited abnormality of the red blood cell (RBC) membrane.

Patients with hereditary spherocytosis show mutations in the following proteins. They are the key components of the cytoskeleton and hence they are responsible for RBC shape.

  • Autosomal Dominant defects have been described in β-spectrin and band 3.
  • Autosomal Recessive defects have been described in α-spectrin and protein 4.2.
  • Both dominant and recessive defects have been described in ankyrin

Note :

Abnormalities of spectrin or ankyrin are the most common molecular defects.

questions.text: The muscle marked as X in the image gets its nerve supply from____.
questions.solution:
The short triangular muscle marked in the posterior part of the elbow joint is the anconeus, it receives its nerve supply from the radial nerve.

It arises from the posterior surface of the lateral epicondyle of the humerus and inserts to the lateral aspect of the olecranon and the proximal quarter of the posterior surface of the shaft of the ulna. The anconeus is an extensor of the elbow.

It receives its vascular supply by branches of the posterior interosseous recurrent artery. Nerve supply is from radial nerve (C6, 7, and 8).

Muscles Nerve supply Action
Anconeus Radial nerve (C6, C7, C8) Abduction of the ulna in pronation; accessory extensor of the elbow joint
Extensor digitorum Posterior interosseous nerve (C7, C8) Extends the index, middle, ring, and little fingers; can also extend the wrist
Extensor carpi ulnaris Posterior interosseous nerve (C7, C8) Extends and adducts the wrist
Extensor carpi radialis longus Radial nerve (C6, C7) before division into superficial and deep branches Extends and abducts the wrist
Extensor carpi radialis brevis Deep branch of the radial nerve (C7, C8) before penetrating supinator muscle Extends and abducts the wrist

questions.text: A 45-year-old male was subjected to a tuning fork test. A vibrating tuning fork was placed on the patient’s mastoid, and when he stopped hearing, it was brought beside his external meatus. The patient could still hear the ringing sound. Repeating the same test in the opposite ear yielded the same result. On placing a vibrating tuning fork on his forehead, it was lateralized to the right ear. What is the likely inference?

choices.text: Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear
Conductive hearing loss in the right ear
Conductive hearing loss in the left ear

questions.solution:
The given scenario shows a positive Rinne test, indicating air conduction is better than bone conduction in both ears. Since Weber’s test is lateralized to the right ear and Rinne’s test is normal, there is sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear.

Rinne’s test is done by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the patient’s mastoid, and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the external auditory meatus(EAC). If he still hears the sound, air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC). The inferences are as follows:

  • It is considered positive (normal) when the AC>BC. This is seen in normal people and people with sensorineural deafness.
  • It is considered negative when the BC>AC. This is seen in patients with conductive deafness. It suggests a minimum hearing loss of 15-20 dB.

In the Weber test, a vibrating tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead, or the vertex and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard. Normally, it is heard equally in both ears. It is lateralized to the worse ear in conductive deafness and to the better ear in sensorineural deafness.

Related Pearl: Tuning fork tests

Tests Normal
Conductive 
loss
Sensorineural
loss
Rinne AC > BC (Rinne +) BC > AC (Rinne -) AC > BC (Rinne +)
Weber Center Lateralized to the affected ear Lateralized to the normal ear
Absolute bone conduction Normal Normal Reduced
Schwabach Normal Lengthened Shortened
Bing Positive Negative Positive
Gelle Positive Negative (ossicular lesions) Positive

AC- Air conduction; BC- Bone conduction.

questions.text: A population survey recently reported a surge in xerophthalmia cases among children between 6 months to 6 years of age. The following options show the prevalence of certain indicators of vitamin A deficiency in the population at risk. Which of them signifies that vitamin A deficiency is a public health problem?

choices.text: Night blindness in >0.05% of the population
Bitot's spots in >0.5% of the population
Corneal scar in >0.01% of the population
Serum retinol less than 10 mcg/dL in >0.1% of the population

questions.solution:
Vitamin A deficiency is considered a public health problem if the prevalence rate of Bitot's spots is >0.5%, among several other criteria, in children between 6 months to 6 years of age.

To design an effective intervention program for the prevention of vitamin A deficiency, the first step is to identify the population risk. This is done by conducting population surveys or prevalence surveys that account for both clinical and biochemical criteria.

The surveys are done in preschool children between 6 months to 6 years of age. The following are the criteria, recommended by WHO to determine the public health significance of xerophthalmia and vitamin A deficiency.

Criteria 

Prevalence in population at risk(6 months to 6 years) 
Night blindness (XN) >1% 
Bitot’s spots  (X1B) >0.5% 

Corneal xerosis/ corneal ulcer/ Keratomalacia 

(X2/X3A/X3B)

 >0.01% 

Corneal scar

(XS)

 >0.05% 
Serum retinol (<10 mcg/dL)  >5% 

 

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman complains of a creepy crawling sensation in her legs associated with an irresistible urge to move the legs. It is more at night and prevents her from sleeping. Which of the following drugs is considered as the drug of choice in treating her condition?
questions.solution:
The history is suggestive of restless leg syndrome and gabapentinoids are now considered as the drug of choice in treating this condition. 

Restless leg syndrome is a typical sensory-motor disorder that generally affects the legs during rest periods, especially during sleep. There is an irresistible urge to shake the legs associated with a burning sensation, itching, and cramps of the legs. In idiopathic cases, dopaminergic hypofunction is postulated.

In patients with restless legs syndrome, iron stores are initially repleted, and the aggravating factors are eliminated. If RLS still persists, initial therapy with a gabapentinoid (pregabalin, gabapentin, gabapentin enacarbil) is preferred, rather than a dopamine agonist (pramipexole, ropinirole, rotigotine). This is due to the high frequency of intermediate and long-term augmentation with dopamine agonists, as well as their risk of impulse control disorders.

FDA-approved drugs for the treatment of restless leg syndrome: 

  • Gabapentin
  • Ropinirole
  • Pramipexole
  • Rotigotine 

A dopamine agonist is used as an alternative in patients with increased risk for side effects from gabapentinoids, such as those with obesity and its complications, a past or present history of moderate to severe depression, a disorder causing gait instability or respiratory failure, and a history of substance use disorder.

Non-pharmacological treatments that can be used in restless leg syndrome are:

  • Avoiding alcohol at bedtime
  • Massaging affected legs
  • Hot baths
  • Applying hot or cold to the affected area
  • Engaging in moderate exercises

Other options:

Option A- Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor that binds to serotonin transporter and inhibits its transport. They are mainly indicated in depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, panic disorder, social phobia, and posttraumatic stress disorder. 

Option B- Clozapine is a second-generation antipsychotic that is an antagonist to 5HT2A and D2 receptors. They are mainly used in refractory schizophrenia and refractory mania. 

Option D- Imipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant that inhibits serotonin receptor transporter, norepinephrine transporter. They also block H1 histamine, 5HT2, alpha 1 adrenergic, muscarinic 1 receptors. They are indicated in major depression.

questions.text: The urine sample of a patient with an inherited metabolic enzyme deficiency has been subjected to the Osazone test. Which of the following sugars will  form needle-shaped crystals when subjected to this test?
questions.solution:
Fructose forms broomstick or needle-shaped osazone crystals.

Broomstick or Needle shaped Osazone crystals are characteristically seen due to the presence of glucose, fructose, or mannose.

Osazone test is a routine test that is done to identify the reducing sugars. The technique of the Osazone test was first developed by Emil Fischer, a German chemist.

Principle:

Osazones are crystals that are formed when the sugars react with a compound known as phenylhydrazine, at boiling point. Phenylhydrazine reacts with the carbonyl in the sugar to create phenylhydrazone. The hydrazones then react further with the excess free phenylhydrazine to produce insoluble osazones that appear in crystal form.

Procedure:

1 ml phenylhydrazine mixture is taken in a test tube. To this 3 to 5ml of test/sample solution is added. It is thoroughly mixed and placed in a boiling water bath. The formation of yellow crystalline precipitate in the test tube indicates the presence of reducing sugars. The test tube is removed and allowed to cool slowly. The crystals are then examined under the microscope.

Interpretation:

When examined under the microscope each sugar has a characteristic crystal form of osazones as follows

Maltose forms petal-shaped / sunflower-shaped crystals.

Lactose forms powder puff-shaped crystals.

Galactose forms rhombic-plate shaped crystals.

Glucose, fructose, and mannose form broomstick or needle-shaped crystals.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is diagnosed with cholangitis and has all the features of Charcot's triad. Which of these components is not a part of this triad?
questions.solution:
Vomiting is not a component of Charcot's triad seen in patients diagnosed with acute cholangitis.

Charcot's triad has all the classical presentation of cholangitis. It includes:

  • Fever
  • Right upper quadrant pain
  • Jaundice

Reynold's pentad is seen in severe cholangitis. It includes:

  • Charcot's triad
  • Hypotension
  • Altered mental status

Related Pearl: Triads in Surgery

questions.text: A 29-year-old man came with a history of jerky and hyperkinetic movements involving all parts of the body. His MRI shows marked atrophy of the caudate nucleus. There is a significant family history with successive generations having symptoms at earlier ages of onset. The pedigree chart is given below. Identify this genetic phenomenon.
questions.solution:
The given case scenario, with the family pedigree chart showing autosomal dominant inheritance points towards Huntington’s disease, and the genetic phenomenon seen here is anticipation. Anticipation refers to an earlier onset of disease in successive generations in a pedigree. 

Huntington's disease (HD) is a degenerative disease of the striate neurons. It is caused by an autosomal dominant inheritance of a trinucleotide repeat (CAG) in the HTT gene located on chromosome 4. This results in jerky, hyperkinetic movements called chorea and dementia. It is commonly seen in the 4th and 5th decades of life. Motor problems (the characteristic chorea) precede dementia. The HTT gene, on chromosome 4 encodes a protein called huntingtin. It has a stretch of repeats of the trinucleotide CAG. When the number of repeats is increased beyond normal, it is associated with Huntington's disease. More the repeats, earlier is its onset.

The caudate nucleus is dramatically atrophied, with accompanying atrophy of the putamen, and cortex. The lateral and 3rd ventricles may be dilated. There is a loss of striatal neurons in the caudate nucleus on microscopic examination. The medium-sized, spiny neurons that use GABA as their neurotransmitter, along with enkephalin, dynorphin, and substance P are affected. Protein aggregates containing huntingtin can be seen in the neurons of the striatum and cerebral cortex. The chorea can be treated with dopamine-blocking agents like tetrabenazine.

Other options:

Option A: Each mitochondrion contains many copies of mtDNA, where deleterious mutations of mtDNA may affect a few, but not all the copies of mtDNA. Hence, individuals may harbor both wild-type and mutant mtDNA. This is known as heteroplasmy. Thus, when a cell containing both normal and mutant mtDNA divides, the proportion of the normal and mutant mtDNA in the daughter cells is variable. This explains why the expression of disorders resulting from mtDNA mutations is variable.

Option B: Genetic heterogeneity refers to the phenomenon where mutations at several different loci produce the same trait.

Option C: Variable expressivity refers to a similar genotype but a varying phenotype. The trait will be present in all individuals carrying the mutant gene but is expressed differently among individuals. Eg: varying severity of disease with NF1 mutation (neurofibromatosis).

 

Related Pearl: Inheritance pattern of important diseases
