questions.text: A study analyses the association of four factors with a certain disease and obtains the following correlation coefficients. Which of the following indicates maximum strength of correlation?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the maximum strength of correlation corresponds to the correlation coefficient of - 0.88.

Correlation (denoted by r) is used to assess the strength and direction of the association between two variables (such as smoking and lung cancer).

The correlation coefficient is represented by a plus or minus sign, followed by a number (Example: -0.88). The correlation coefficient ranges from -1 to +1.

The sign indicates the direction of correlation.

  • Plus sign (+) suggests that both the variables being studied are positively correlated, which implies that the variables are associated (Ex: Smoking and lung cancer have a positive correlation ).
  • Minus sign (-) suggests that both the variables being studied are negatively correlated, which implies that the variables are not associated with each other (Ex: Alcohol intake and Malaria have a negative correlation).

The numerical indicates the strength of correlation:

  • +1 or -1 suggests the maximum possible strength of the correlation.
  • Values closer to 1 have greater strength of the correlation.
  • For example, both -0.88 and +0.88, represents the same strength of the correlation. However, +0.88 suggests a positive correlation, and -0.88 suggests a negative correlation.

 

Correlation coefficients greater than +/- 0.5 are suggested as strong and is likely to establish (if positive correlation) or disprove (if negative correlation) the association, between two factors.

 

Analysis of given options:

Option a (+1.70) is incorrect as the value cannot be greater than +1.

Option b (+0.75) is greater than +0.5, suggestive of a strong positive correlation.

Option c (-0.88) is greater than -0.5 and suggests a strong negative correlation.

Option d (+0.25) is less than +0.5 and suggests a weak positive correlation.

 

The order of strength of the correlation, if considered alone, is as follows:

Option c (-0.88) > Option b (+0.75) > Option d (+0.25)

 

 

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with a scrotal swelling. On examination, one can feel the testis separate from the scrotal swelling and the swelling shows a brilliant transillumination. A crystal clear fluid is noticed with aspiration. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an Epididymal cyst. The swelling is palpable separately from the testis. This rules out primary hydrocoele as swelling cannot be palpated separately from the testis. Aspiration of crystal clear fluid rules out spermatocele as it contains barley-colored fluid due to the presence of spermatozoa.

Epididymal cyst occurs due to cystic degeneration of epididymis. They usually occur in middle age and are bilateral. The tense cysts are usually posterior to the testes and feel like clusters of tiny grapes. It is visible on USG as anechoic cysts different from the testes. Treatment involves the excision of the cyst if it is single. Partial or total resection of the epididymis is required in multilocular cysts.

Spermatocele Epididymal cyst
Unilocular retention cyst Multiple, multilocular, bunch of grapes

Present at the epididymal head,

Above and behind the upper pole of the testes

 Posterior to testis
Transillumination+

Transillumination+

(Chinese lantern pattern)
Barley water fluid appearance Crystal clear fluid
Treatment: Excision Treatment: Excision


Other options:

Option C: Hydrocoele is an accumulation of fluid within the tunica vaginalis in the scrotum. It will be brilliantly transilluminating and testes will not be separately palpable. USG will show anechoic (due to fluid) reflection. Treatment involves Jaboulay's operation, in which the eversion of the sac upon itself is done to prevent refilling of the hydrocoele sac.

Option D: Varicocele is an abnormal dilatation and enlargement of the scrotal venous plexus draining the testis. They are more common on the left side. They are usually asymptomatic. First-line treatment is embolization in symptomatic cases. Palomo operation can be done which is the ligation of the testicular vein in the retroperitoneum.

questions.text: The graph shows the percentage of filtered load remaining at various levels of nephrons for different substances. Select the correct options for inulin, alanine, and PAH respectively.
questions.solution:
The given graph shows the substances which are freely filtered (C - inulin), freely filtered and secreted additionally from tubules (D - PAH), and substances that are filtered very little and reabsorbed subsequently (A - alanine).

The given graph basically measures the amount (not concentration) of a particular substance in renal tubules after it undergoes ultrafiltration. 

Substances like inulin which are freely filtered (100%) are labelled with C. It further doesn't undergo any reabsorption or secretion. It is hence a straight line i.e., its concentration doesn't change throughout the length of the nephron.

Substances like PAH which are freely filtered and further secreted are labelled with D. This is because its concentration keeps increasing throughout the length of the nephron due to secretion into tubules.

Substances like amino acids or glucose are not freely filtered. And in normal conditions, they are almost completely reabsorbed. Hence they have a graph that is sloping down. And since they are completely reabsorbed within PCT itself, their concentration is not detected after proximal convoluted tubules.

questions.text: During your residency, the consultant advises you to treat an 8-year-old child, who presented with the following ocular finding, with intramuscular doses of Vitamin A. What should be your treatment plan according to WHO recommended schedule in this patient?

choices.text: 200,000 IU by intramuscular injection on Day 0, Day 1 and 4 weeks later
100,000 IU by intramuscular injection on Day 0, Day 1 and 4 weeks later
200,000 IU by intramuscular injection on Day 0, Day 7 and 4 weeks later
100,000 IU by intramuscular injection on Day 0, Day 7 and 4 weeks later

questions.solution:
The given image shows a Bitot spot which is a feature seen in vitamin A deficiency, which is treated by 100,000 IU by intramuscular injection on Day 0, Day 1, and 4 weeks later, according to WHO recommended schedule.

The WHO recommended schedule is as given below:

  • All patients above the age of 1 year (except women of reproductive age): 200,000 IU of vitamin A orally or 100,000 IU by intramuscular injection should be given immediately on diagnosis (day 0) and repeated the following day (day 1) and 4 weeks later.
  • Children under the age of 1 year and children of any age who weigh less than 8 kg should be treated with half the doses for patients of more than 1 year of age.
  • Women of reproductive age, pregnant or not;
    • Those having night blindness (XN), conjunctival xerosis (X1A), and Bitot’s spots (X1B) should be treated with a daily dose of 10,000 IU of vitamin A orally (1 sugar-coated tablet) for 2 weeks.
    • For corneal xerophthalmia, administration of a full dosage schedule (described for patients above 1 year of age) is recommended.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: The blister pack shown in the image below, used for the treatment of leprosy, contains which of the following drug regimen in the supervised dose?

choices.text: Rifampicin 300mg x 2, Clofazimine 100mg x 3, and Dapsone 100 mg
Rifampicin 300mg x 3, Clofazimine 100mg x 2, and Dapsone 100 mg
Rifampicin 100mg x 3, Clofazimine 300mg x 2, and Dapsone 200 mg
Rifampicin 100mg x 2, Clofazimine 300mg x 3, and Dapsone 200 mg

questions.solution:
The image shows pink-coloured MB (Multi-Bacillary) adult blister pack for the treatment of leprosy. The supervised dose regimen includes Rifampicin 300mg x 2 capsules, Clofazimine 100mg x 3 capsules, and Dapsone 100mg.

There are four blister packets available for multi-drug therapy (MDT) for leprosy.

  • MB (Multi-Bacillary) adult blister pack
  • PB (Pauci-Bacillary) adult blister pack
  • MB (Multi-Bacillary) child blister pack
  • PB (Pauci-Bacillary) child blister pack 

Each pack contains drugs for 28 days, which are to be taken orally. The pulse dose, which is present at the top, which has to be taken under supervision once every month.

MB (Multi-Bacillary) adult - Treatment plan:

Once a month (Day 1):

  • 2 Capsules of rifampicin (300mg x 2).
  • 3 Capsules of clofazimine (100mg x 3).
  • 1 Tablet of dapsone (100mg).

Once a day (From day 2 to day 28):

  • 1 Capsule of clofazimine (50mg).
  • 1 Tablet of dapsone (100mg).

The treatment is given for a fixed period. PB cases need MDT for 6 months and MB cases are given MDT for 12 months.

questions.text: Which of the following H1 antagonist is a second-generation antihistaminic drug?
questions.solution:
Olopatadine is a second-generation antihistaminic drug. It is a topical H1 antagonist with additional mast cell–stabilizing and anti-inflammatory properties. It is an effective treatment of allergic conjunctivitis in the drop form. Nasal spray helps reduce the nasal symptoms of allergic rhinitis.

H1 antagonists are classified into 2 generations: 

First-generation antihistamine- They have a strong sedative property and also have an antimuscarinic function. They include:

  • Diphenhydramine
  • Dimenhydrinate
  • Promethazine
  • Hydroxyzine
  • Pheniramine, 
  • Chlorpheniramine, Dexchlorpheniramine
  • Cyproheptadine
  • Cyclizine, Meclizine, Buclizine
  • Cinnarizine
  • Clemastine

Second-generation antihistamine- They are less sedative because of less central nervous system penetration and do not block autonomic receptors. They include:

  • Fexofenadine
  • Loratadine, Desloratadine
  • Cetirizine, Levocetirizine
  • Azelastine, Mizolastine, Ebastine
  • Olopatadine
  • Rupatadine

questions.text: All of the following are caused by Bartonella bacilliformis except?
questions.solution:
The trench fever/quintan fever/5-day fever is caused by Rickettsia quintana (formerly known as Bartonella quintana).

Trench fever characterized by sudden onset of fever accompanied by headache, malaise, restlessness, and shin pain. It is an exclusively human disease and no animal reservoir is known. It is transmitted by the body louse.

Bartonella bacilliformis is the causative organism of Oroya fever (also known as Carrion's disease). It presents as fever and progressive anemia due to bacterial invasion of erythrocytes.

A late sequel in survivors or in those with asymptomatic infection is verruga peruana, which is characterized by vascular nodular skin lesions that occur in successive crops.

Verruga peruana

questions.text: An inverted U-shaped dose-response curve shown below is most-likely seen with ________.
questions.solution:
An inverted U-shaped dose-response curve is seen for ligands that downregulate their receptors. Estrogen will show this curve at a higher dose above the physiological threshold. The effects of estrogen will be reduced, due to the downregulation of estrogen receptors.

Inverted U-shaped dose-response curves are seen when receptor downregulation or desensitization occurs following exposure to a ligand or when an additional and negative effect occurs at a concentration beyond the dose which produces the primary positive effect.

Estrogen at high levels can have maximal effects on the body. However, at a level above the physiological threshold, the effects of estrogen are reduced, due to the downregulation of estrogen receptors.

Many endocrine-disrupting chemicals can have inverted U-shaped dose-response curves similar to that of estrogen.

 

Hockey stick-shaped dose-response curve for toxicants that are also metabolic by-products. Ex:- Formaldehyde

Vitamins and essential metals show a U-shaped dose-response curve.

At a low dose, adverse effects are observed because there is a deficiency of these nutrients to maintain homeostasis. As dose increases, homeostasis is achieved, and the bottom of the U-shaped dose-response curve is reached. As dose increases to surpass the amount required to maintain homeostasis, overdose toxicity can ensue. Thus, adverse effects are seen at both low and high doses. 

A U-shaped curve is characteristically seen with vitamins and essential metals

questions.text: In the following specimen, obstruction of the duct of the structure marked by the "?" leads to the formation of a _____.
questions.solution:
The structure marked "?" is the sublingual gland and if the duct becomes obstructed they can develop a retention cyst.

The sublingual gland is the smallest of the main salivary glands. Small rami from the anterior part of the gland sometimes form a major sublingual duct (Bartholin’s duct), which opens with, or near to the orifice of the submandibular duct.

If the ducts of any salivary gland become obstructed they can develop a retention cyst. If such cysts occur due to obstruction in the sublingual salivary gland, it is called a plunging ranula. 

Note:

  • Retention cyst: When the duct is obstructed, there is the retention of mucous. It has an epithelial lining. Eg: Plunging Ranula is a mucous retention cyst that arises from the sublingual salivary glands.
  • Extravasation cyst: When the duct suffers trauma, mucous extravasates outside the duct. It only has a granulation lining and not an epithelial lining.
  • Mucocele: If the obstruction happens in the ducts of minor salivary glands such as labial or buccal, it is termed as a mucocele.
  • Cystic hygroma is a type of congenital lymphangioma. Here the swelling is soft and partially compressible which shows positive fluctuation and translucency test.

questions.text: During a microbiology practical class, your tutor demonstrates  "Nagler reaction" to the class in the Microbiology lab for the identification of Clostridium perfringens in clinical specimens. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this test?

choices.text: It is used for the quantification of toxin
Alpha-toxin produced by Clostridium  forms the basis of this reaction.
Opacity is absent around colonies on the side with antitoxin present.

questions.solution:
Alpha-toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens forms the basis of Nagler's reaction which is an example of a neutralization test. It is used for the identification of the toxin, not quantification. 

Neutralization tests utilize anti-toxins/antibodies to neutralize the toxin produced by an organism.

The alpha-toxin of C. perfringens has Lecithinase activity. When C. perfringens is grown on an egg yolk media with the C. perfringens antitoxin spread on one half of the plate, colonies on the other half without the antitoxin will be surrounded by a zone of opacity. There will be no opacity around the colonies on the half of the plate with the antitoxin due to the specific neutralization of alpha-toxin.

Other examples of neutralization tests are:

  • Plaque inhibition test: Neutralization of bacteriophages 
  • Schick test: Neutralization of diphtheria toxin by antitoxin
  • Anti-Streptolysin O test: For beta-hemolytic streptococci

questions.text: A 78-year-old female presents with atrial fibrillation. She is a known case of diabetes mellitus and hypertension for the past 10 years. What is her CHA2DS2-VASc score?
questions.solution:
The CHA2DS2-VASc score in this patient is 5.

  • Age ≥ 75 years = 2
  • Diabetes = 1
  • Hypertension = 1
  • Female gender = 1

Total score = 5

The CHA2DS2-VASc score is used to assess the risk of stroke in patients who have atrial fibrillation. Anticoagulation therapy is given when the score is ≥2. Patients with a score of 1 may also be considered for anticoagulation therapy.

Anticoagulation therapy is given for all patients of AF having mitral stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, or a history of stroke.

In the given case (CHA2DS2-VASc score = 5), oral Warfarin can be initiated to reduce stroke risk. If bleeding occurs, anticoagulation can be reversed by administering vitamin K or clotting factors. The factor Xa inhibitors rivaroxaban, apixaban and edoxaban, and the direct thrombin inhibitor dabigatran can be used as alternatives.

Related Pearl: CHA2DS2-VASC scoring for risk of stroke & need for oral anticoagulation in AF

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents with parkinsonism and cerebellar features. The MRI of this patient shows the following findings over the pons. Identify the sign shown in the image.

MRI - Magnetic resonance imaging
questions.solution:
The given MRI image shows pontine hot cross bun sign seen in patients with multiple system atrophy (MSA) with predominant cerebellar features

MSA manifests as a combination of parkinsonian, cerebellar, and autonomic features. Based on predominant clinical features it is further divided into :

  • MSA-P: predominantly parkinsonian features
  • MSA-C: predominantly cerebellar features

Characteristic MRI findings include:

  • MSA-P: T2 weighted imaging demonstrates hyperintense putaminal rim 
  • MSA-C: cerebellar and brainstem atrophy causing pontine hot cross bun sign

Below image shows hot cross bun sign (arrow) due to severe atrophy of pons seen in multiple system atrophy.

Other options:

Option B: Molar tooth sign refers to the appearance of the midbrain in an axial section in which the elongated superior cerebellar peduncles gives the midbrain the appearance of a molar or wisdom tooth. It is seen in Joubert syndrome.

Option C: The tram-track sign in the brain refers to the parallel calcification of the cortex in patients with Sturge-Weber Syndrome.

Option D: Dawson's fingers are multiple FLAIR hyperintense lesions arranged perpendicular to the lateral ventricles in a triangular configuration which is typical for multiple sclerosis.

questions.text: Which among the following marked cells are considered as members of amine precursor uptake and decarboxylation (APUD) system of dispersed neuroendocrine cells?
questions.solution:
The cells marked 'B' are the parafollicular cells/C-cells which are considered as members of amine precursor uptake and decarboxylation (APUD) system of dispersed neuroendocrine cells.

The C-cells (clear cells or parafollicular cells) have a pale staining cytoplasm, they are present between the follicular cells and the basement membrane or between the follicles. They are usually found in the middle third of each lateral lobe of the thyroid and scattered in between the thyroid follicles. They are members of the APUD system of dispersed neuroendocrine cells. They secrete calcitonin which lowers blood calcium.

The thyroid gland is covered by a fibrous capsule with septae dividing it into lobules. These lobules contain follicles lined by follicular cells. The shape of the follicular cells depends on the activity of the gland. They're squamous in the inactive state, cuboidal to columnar in the active state. The cavity of the follicle contains colloid which appears pink in H and E staining.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man who was treated with haloperidol for delirium developed fever, tachycardia, increased blood pressure, muscle stiffness, and altered mental status. Investigations revealed elevated levels of creatine phosphokinase (CPK). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features in a patient who has been administered haloperidol, are most likely suggestive of the neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is a life-threatening complication that can occur anytime during antipsychotic treatment. Haloperidol is known to cause NMS. The condition may occur within 24-72 hrs after initiation of the treatment, and if untreated, may last for 10 to 14 days.

Clinical features include motor and behavioral symptoms like muscular rigidity, dystonia, akinesia, mutism, obtundation, and agita­tion. Autonomic symptoms include fever, diaphore­sis, and increased pulse and blood pressure.

Investigations reveal elevated levels of WBC count, creatinine phosphokinase (CPK), myoglobin, and liver enzymes. Occasionally, myoglobinuria may be seen in patients who develop acute renal failure.

Dantrolene and bromocriptine are commonly used for the treatment. Amantadine may be used in some cases. Electroconvulsive therapy may also be used. 

Other options:

Option A: Serotonin syndrome occurs due to an increase of plasma serotonin to toxic levels, due to concurrent administration of SSRI and an MAO inhibitor, L-tryptophan or lithium. The patients initially present with diarrhea and restlessness. As the condition worsens, they develop extreme agitation, hyperreflexia, autonomic instability, myoclonus, seizures, hyperthermia, uncontrollable shivering, and rigidity. There may be delirium, coma, status epilepticus, cardio­ vascular collapse, and death in the worst cases.

Option B: Tardive dyskinesia is characterized by abnormal, irregular, involuntary choreoathetoid movements of the muscles of the head, limbs, and trunk. Perioral movement is most common. The condition usually develops as a delayed response to antipsychotics, about 6 months after treatment.

Option C: Hypersensitivity reaction to haloperidol may include anaphylactic reaction, angioedema, rash, urticaria, face edema, laryngeal edema, bronchospasm, and laryngospasm.

Related Pearl: Psychiatric emergency: Fever with altered mental status

In a clinical setting of fever with altered mental status, it is important to differentiate between the following.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presented with pain, deformity, and swelling affecting the femur. On examination, she has areas of cafe-au-lait pigmentation on her left shoulder and right forearm. The patient is known to be hyperthyroid and is under treatment for the same.  Radiographs reveal multiple lesions involving the bilateral femur with the characteristic Rind sign. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are most likely suggestive of fibrous dysplasia.

Fibrous dysplasia is a sporadic disorder characterized by the presence of monostotic (one) or polyostotic (many) expanding fibrous skeletal lesions composed of bone-forming mesenchyme. In the rind sign, a lesion is surrounded by a layer of thick, sclerotic reactive bone (i.e. a rind) and is considered to be suggestive of fibrous dysplasia. Classic rind sign is most commonly seen in the proximal femur.

McCune-Albright syndrome (MAS) refers to the association of the polyostotic form of fibrous dysplasia, with café au lait spots and autonomous endocrine hyperfunction. The most common endocrinopathy is isosexual pseudo precocious puberty in girls. Other endocrinopathies may include thyrotoxicosis, Cushing’s syndrome, acromegaly, hyperparathyroidism, hyperprolactinemia, and pseudo precocious puberty in boys.

Fibrous dysplasia is caused by a somatic mutation in GNAS1. It is also associated with cafe-au-lait pigmentation due to activation of signaling through the melanocyte-stimulating hormone receptor and endocrine abnormalities.

Other options:

  • Osteomyelitis is unlikely in the absence of a previous history of infection and does not present with this symptom complex.
  • Osteopetrosis is a systemic rather than local disorder characterized by high bone mass.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child abruptly develops a fever, oliguria, periorbital edema, and smoky cola-colored urine  2 weeks after recovery from a sore throat. Which of the following findings are most likely to be seen in the renal biopsy?

choices.text: Focal glomerular sclerosis on light microscopy
Hypercellular glomeruli with influx of leukocytes on light microscopy
Tram track appearance on PAS staining

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features of fever, oliguria, periorbital edema, and smoky cola-colored are suggestive of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). The classic histologic picture of this disease shows hypercellular glomeruli with the influx of leucocytes (endocapillary proliferation).

PSGN is caused by immune complexes containing streptococcal antigens (M protein of cell wall) and specific antibodies. It is more commonly seen in children and they typically present with malaise, fever, nausea, oliguria, and hematuria (smoky or cola-colored urine) 1 to 2 weeks after recovery from a sore throat. The patients may also have mild proteinuria, periorbital edema, and mild to moderate hypertension.

In adults, the disease is more severe and the presentation and onset are atypical with features such as the sudden appearance of hypertension or edema, frequently with an elevation of BUN (blood urea nitrogen).

The characteristic electron microscopic findings are discrete, amorphous, electron-dense deposits called subepithelial humps (presumably representing the antigen-antibody complexes) and the presence of subendothelial deposits. 

Elevated titers of antibodies against many streptococcal antigens and a decrease in serum complement levels are also seen.

In 95% of the children, this disease is self-limiting. However, in some children and a large number of adults (40%), it may progress to a rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis.

Other options:

Option A: Focal glomerular sclerosis on light microscopy is characteristically seen in focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. It is primarily idiopathic but can occur in association with some conditions like HIV, heroin nephropathy, and morbid obesity. It presents as nephrotic syndrome in children and adults

Option C: Podocyte effacement is characteristically seen with minimal change disease. Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.

Option D: Tram track appearance on PAS staining is seen in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

Related Pearl: Types of Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis

questions.text: A gastroenterologist is studying the role of compound mucous glands present in the first few centimeters of duodenum. Which of the following is correct regarding the functioning of these glands?

choices.text: Helps in the digestion of proteins
Acidic secretion potentiating the action of gastric juices
Alkaline secretion prevents corrosion by gastric juices

questions.solution:
Brunner’s glands are located in the first few centimeters of the submucosa of the duodenal wall. They secrete alkaline mucus which protects the duodenum from highly acidic gastric juices. 

The number of Brunner's glands is maximum in the proximal duodenum and keeps decreasing towards the distal duodenum. It secretes large amounts of alkaline mucus containing HCO3- in response to tactile stimuli on the duodenal mucosa, vagal stimulation, and GI hormones, especially secretin. It is inhibited by sympathetic stimulation.

Mucus secreted by Brunner’s glands helps to protect the duodenal wall as the high HCO3- content of the mucous neutralizes the acidic chyme from the stomach.

Note:

The most alkaline secretion is Brunner’s gland secretion with a pH of 8.0 – 8.9. The second most alkaline secretion in the GI tract is the pancreatic juice.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of AIDS presents to the OPD with fever, chills, weight loss and the cutaneous lesions shown below. The microscopic examination of the lesions revealed predominant neutrophilic infiltration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette of a patient with HIV infections and the violaceous lesions with a neutrophilic infiltrate is suggestive of bacillary angiomatosis.

Bacillary angiomatosis is seen in severely immunocompromised patients and is caused by B. henselae or B. quintana. It is characterized by neovascular proliferative lesions involving the skin. It consists of lobular proliferation of small blood vessels lined by enlarged endothelial cells interspersed with mixed infiltrates of neutrophils and lymphocytes, with a predominance of the former.

Both bacillary angiomatosis and Kaposi's sarcoma can have the clinical presentation mentioned in the question. However, the major differentiating factor is the microscopic examination:

  • Bacillary angiomatosis predominantly has mixed infiltrate accompanied by neutrophils with clumps of bacilli.
  • Kaposi's sarcoma predominantly has plasma cells and lymphocytic infiltrates.

questions.text: As a senior resident in the OBG department, You would consider uterine artery embolization as a treatment option in all of the following cases except ________

choices.text: Prior to the removal of Placenta accreta in Multiparous woman
Patient diagnosed with calcified and pedunculated submucous fibroids

questions.solution:
Uterine artery embolization is indicated in all the above-given cases except in a patient with calcified and pedunculated submucous fibroids.

A calcified fibroid does not shrink with the procedure. The pedunculated fibroids can fall off after the procedure resulting in intrauterine or peritoneal infections.

Hence, the calcified, submucous, and subserous types of fibroids are contraindications for this procedure. 

Other indications for Uterine artery embolization(UAE) include,

  • Postpartum hemorrhage.
  • Placenta accreta to reduce bleeding prior to placental removal, or caesarean delivery.
  • This technique is most suited for menorrhagia in a multiparous woman

Technique:

  • Under local sedation, bilateral UAE is ap­proached through percutaneous femoral catheterization.
  • It is done using polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), gel foam particles or metal coils.

Embolization reduces vascularity and the size of the fibroid in 3–4 months

Advantages of UAE:

  • No major surgery.
  • No intraoperative bleeding.
  • Short hospital stay.
  • Less abdominal adhesions.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female presents with the painful lesions on her face, neck, and arms, as shown below. She also complains of fever, headache and joint pain. Investigations revealed elevated ESR. Biopsy from the lesion shows a dense dermal infiltrate of neutrophils.  Glucocorticoid administration relieved fever and reduced the severity of the lesions. The most common underlying cause for this condition is ____________.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the lesion given above is characteristic of febrile neutrophilic dermatosis (Sweet syndrome) which is most commonly associated with Acute myeloid leukemia .

Sweet syndrome/ Febrile neutrophilic dermatosis is characterised by :

  • Fever, neutrophilia, and dense dermal infiltrate of neutrophils
  • Skin lesions: 
    • Pink-red to red-brown edematous plaques
    • Painful 
    • Usually involves the head, neck, and upper (and lower) extremities
  • Systemic associations of Sweet syndrome include:
    • Acute myeloid leukemia (most common)
    • Inflammatory bowel disease
    • Solid malignancies of the genitourinary tract
    • systemic lupus erythematosus
    • drugs - all-trans-retinoic acid, granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF)
  • Idiopathic Sweet syndrome is common in women following a respiratory tract infection.

Treatment includes high doses of glucocorticoids such as prednisone (60 mg/day) initially, which is followed by tapered doses over the next 2-3 weeks.

questions.text: A medically fit nulliparous woman presents to you with the following finding. She also tells you, that she wishes to retain her childbearing and menstrual functions. You could advise her with all the following surgeries as a treatment option except __________
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the image is suggestive of uterine prolapse in a nulliparous woman. All the above surgeries can be advised in this patient except Le Fort’s repair. It is reserved for the very elderly menopausal patient, who do not want to retain their sexual life, and are unfit for surgeries.

Abdominal sling operations: These are designed for women with type II or III degree prolapse and who are desirous of retaining childbearing function and menstrual function.

Sling operations are best suited to nulliparous prolapse. It includes,

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy.
  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation.
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation.

Note:

The above image shows 2nd degree prolapse where the external os lies at the level of introitus.

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Category Treatment
Nulliparous or congenital prolapse 

Abdominal sling operations:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy
  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation
Pregnancy and postnatal period
  • Ring pessary (up to 16 weeks period of gestation)
  • Pelvic floor exercises
<40 years            
  • Fothergill's repair (Manchester operation)
  • Shirodkar's procedure
>40 years - with completed family  Vaginal hysterectomy and pelvic floor repair 
>60 years - unfit for surgery 
  • Le Fort's repair
  • Colpocleisis

These are done if the patient doesn't want to retain sexual function

questions.text: A known diabetic patient on oral antidiabetic drugs for the past 20 years, now presents with paresthesias and difficulty in walking. Blood investigation showed raised MCV and elevated serum methylmalonate levels. Which drug might have caused these side effects in this patient?
questions.solution:
In this case, metformin can cause vitamin B12 deficiency which may manifest in the neurological symptoms of paresthesias, difficulty in walking, and causes megaloblastic anemia which on blood investigations show raised MCV and serum methylmalonate levels.

The levels of vitamin B12 should thus be monitored. The most common side effect of metformin is mainly GI intolerance like nausea, bloating, abdominal cramps, and diarrhea.

Note: The exact reason why metformin causes vitamin B12 deficiency is not known. The proposed mechanisms include:

  • Alterations in small bowel motility which stimulates bacterial overgrowth and consequential vitamin B12 deficiency
  • Competitive inhibition or inactivation of vitamin B12 absorption
  • Alterations in intrinsic factor (IF) levels and interaction with the cubilin endocytic receptor.
  • Inhibition of the calcium-dependent absorption of the vitamin B12-IF complex at the terminal ileum.

questions.text: Individuals who had subclinical infection and developed carrier state without suffering from overt disease are known as:
questions.solution:
Healthy carriers are those who had a subclinical infection and developed carrier state without suffering from overt disease. However, they still shed the disease agent.

Examples: Poliomyelitis, cholera, meningococcal meningitis, salmonellosis, and diphtheria.

All individuals with a subclinical infection are not considered as carriers. Only those, who disseminate or shed the disease agent are considered as carriers. For example, in polio, the infection may be subclinical, and the person may shed the virus, thus acting as a healthy carrier. In contrast, a patient with tuberculosis may have a subclinical infection but doesn't disseminate the tubercle bacilli. In such case, the individual with subclinical tuberculosis infection is not a carrier.

Other options:

Paradoxical carriers are carriers who acquired the pathogen from another carrier. Example: A carrier with subclinical polio infection, who acquired the pathogen from another household member, who is also a carrier for polio virus.

Incubatory carriers are those who shed infectious agents during the incubation period of the disease. Which means, these carriers transmit the disease before the onset of the illness. Examples: measles, mumps, polio, pertussis, influenza, diphtheria and hepatitis B.

Convalescent carriers are those who continue to shed the disease agent during the period of convalescence. This may occur in cases where the clinical recovery does not coincide with the bacteriological recovery, and the individual may continue to shed the disease agent. Examples: Typhoid fever, dysentery (bacillary and amoebic), cholera, diphtheria and whooping cough.

questions.text: The anti-emetic and prokinetic action of metoclopramide is primarily due to all the actions given below, except:
questions.solution:
Metoclopramide has both antiemetic and prokinetic action. Peripheral D2 antagonism and 5HT4 agonism contribute to the prokinetic action. 5HT3 antagonism may also contribute to anti-emetic action especially at higher doses.

D2 antagonism in the chemoreceptor trigger zone is responsible for anti-emetic effects.

Metoclopramide includes the following action:

  • 5HT4 receptor agonism
  • 5HT3 receptor antagonism
  • D2 antagonism
  • Sensitization of muscarinic receptors on smooth muscles

questions.text: A 3-year-old child develops the following type of skin lesions. What is the type of isomorphic/Koebner response, that would be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows shiny, pearly white, umbilicated papules with a characteristic dimple at the center which is suggestive of Molluscum contagiosum infection, and the PseudoKoebner phenomenon is seen in this condition.

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. If the same response is seen from the spread of an infective agent ( like molluscum contagiosum, viral warts), it's called pseudo-koebner’s phenomenon.

Molluscum contagiosum:

  • The age of peak incidence is reported as between 2 and 5 years.
  • The incubation period is variously estimated at 14 days to 6 months.
  • In children, it is mainly caused by Type I molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV-1).
  • There is a relatively higher incidence of MCV‐2 type in adults and HIV infection.
  • Sexually transmitted Molluscum contagiosum may be present over the genital area.

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
     
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is admitted for multiple skin infections. He also has a history of recurrent bouts of infections with catalase-positive microorganisms such as Staphylococcus aureus, Burkholderia,  and Aspergillus. The nitroblue tetrazolium dye reduction test is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
This patient has chronic granulomatous disease which occurs due to the defect in NADPH oxidase.

The child has had recurrent infections with catalase-positive organisms and has a defect in generating oxygen radicals intracellularly in his phagocytic cells (the negative nitroblue tetrazolium test). This interferes with the killing of bacteria by the oxidative burst. 

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is an inherited defect in microbiocidal activity. In this condition, there is a failure in the formation of reactive oxygen species due to defective phagocytes NADPH oxidase. This leads to the phagocytic inability to kill specific microbes.

Catalase is an enzyme that inactivates hydrogen peroxide. When these patients are infected with catalase-negative organisms, the patient's immune system can use hydrogen peroxide produced by the organism to create reactive oxygen species. However, in catalase-positive organisms, the hydrogen peroxide produced is rapidly destroyed by catalase, and therefore, the patient's immune response cannot use it to produce reactive oxygen species. Thus, most patients present with pneumonia due to catalase-positive organisms like Staphylococcus aureus, Burkholderia cepacia, Serratia marcescens, Nocardia, and Aspergillus species. 

Patients have recurrent bacterial and fungal infections. The symptoms begin within the first two years of life, affecting the pulmonary, gastrointestinal, skin, and lymphatic drainage of these organs. 

Nitroblue tetrazolium is used as a diagnostic test.

Other options:

Option A - X-linked (Bruton) agammaglobulinemia is characterized by the failure of B-cell maturation. It is associated with mutations in a cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase called Bruton tyrosine kinase (Btk). Patients have decreased levels of B cells. They have recurrent infections caused by Haemophilus influenzae, Streptococcus pneumoniae, or Staphylococcus aureus.

Option B - Leukocyte adhesion defect leads to an inability of the leukocytes to migrate to the site of infection. There are two types. Type 1 occurs due to a defect in the β2 chain present in integrins LFA-1 and Mac-1. Type 2 occurs due to the absence of sialyl-Lewis X.  Both of these present with recurrent bacterial infections.

Option C - Job syndrome is characterized by atopic dermatitis, recurrent skin staphylococcal infections, and recurrent pulmonary infections. It is also known as hyper-IgE syndrome. 

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: A 40-year-old male who visited the flood-affected area in North America presents with low-grade fever, chest pain, cough, and haemoptysis. Radiological examination of chest reveals cavity formation with lung abscess. Culture from the abscess at 37°C, shows the appearance given in the image. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Thick-walled yeasts can show Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.
Humans are infected by the inhalation of spores
This disease can mimic pulmonary tuberculosis
It is caused by a dimorphic fungus

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of travel to the flood-affected area in North America suggests the diagnosis of Pulmonary blastomycosis caused by Blastomyces which is a dimorphic fungi. The condition is also called North Amerian Blastomycosis. Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding gives rise to the figure of 8 appearance (not Mickey-mouse or pilot wheel appearance).

The above image shows characteristic thick-walled round yeast cells with a single broad-based bud at 37°C, which is seen with Blastomyces. At room temperature, the fungus culture shows filamentous growth with septate hyphae, containing many round or oval conidia, and at times chlamydospores.

Humans are infected by the inhalation of spores, usually present in wood debris or soil close to rivers or subject to flooding.

Blastomycosis can present in three forms: primary cutaneous, pulmonary, and disseminated.

Pulmonary blastomycosis is very similar to pulmonary tuberculosis. There may be no symptoms, or there may be low-grade fever, chest pain, cough, and hemoptysis. Occasionally, erythema nodosum develops. The pulmonary lesion may resolve, or there may be cavity formation with lung abscess.

It is infact Paracoccidioides that shows a characteristic yeastlike appearance with multiple peripheral budding resembling a pilot's wheel, or, when only two buds around the mother cell, resembling a Mickey Mouse head

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: A permeable membrane separates solutions of 2 different concentrations x and y, such that there is net movement from x to y. What will happen to the rate of diffusion if concentrations of both solutions are doubled?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario, the rate of diffusion doubles.

Fick’s law of diffusion explains passive diffusion along the concentration gradient. 

Fick’s law of diffusion: The magnitude of the diffusing tendency is directly proportional to the cross-sectional area across which diffusion is taking place and the concentration gradient, or chemical gradient, which is the difference in concentration of the diffusing substance divided by the thickness of the membrane.

The concentration gradient initially = x - y (such that net movement is from x to y)

The concentration gradient later = 2x - 2y = 2 (x - y) = (net movement from x to y with double the initial rate)

The question can be better understood with an example. Say the initial concentrations are 4 mol/L on one side and 3 mol/L on other side.

Initial concentration gradient = 4- 3 = 1mol/L

If these concentrations are doubled on both sides. Final concentrations will be 8 mol/L and 6 mol/L respectively.

Final concentration gradient = 8 - 6 = 2mol/L which is double the initial gradient.

 

Related Pearl: Factors influencing the rate of net diffusion of a substance across a membrane

Fick’s Law of Diffusion → J = -DA (Δc/Δx)

where,

J is the net rate of diffusion,

D is the diffusion coefficient,

A is the area, and

Δc/Δx is the concentration gradient.

Factors Effect on diffusion
↑ Thickness of the membrane ↓
↑ Lipid Solubility ↑
↑ Temperature ↑
↑  Size of the molecule ↓
↑  Area of the Membrane ↑
↑ Distribution of Protein Channels ↑

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman diagnosed with osteoarthritis of the knee came for a follow-up visit. On examination, the following findings were noted. Identify the marked lesion.
questions.solution:
The above image showing the knob-like appearance of the proximal interphalangeal joints (PIP) in a patient with OA is suggestive of Bouchard's nodes. They are formed due to the formation of osteophytes and tissue swelling.

Heberden's nodes develop in distal interphalangeal joints (DIP).

The images below show Bouchard's (yellow arrow) and Heberden's nodes (black arrow).

Related Pearl: Joint Involvement in Various Arthritis

 Joint Disorders Joints Commonly Involved

Cervical and lumbosacral spine, PIP, DIP, 1st CMC, hip, knee, 1st MTP, 

 Elbow, Wrist, Ankle, MCP 
Rheumatoid Arthritis Shoulder, Wrist, MCP, PIP, Knee, MTP  DIP 
Ankylosing Spondylitis Sacroiliac joint, intervertebral joints  
Psoriatic Arthritis PIP, DIP Ray distribution* 

*Ray distribution: Joint involvement tends to follow a pattern with all of the joints of one finger involved sparing the adjacent finger completely.

questions.text: The diaphragmatic surface of the heart is shown below. Identify the structures marked X and Y.

choices.text: Posterior interventricular artery and middle cardiac vein
Posterior interventricular artery and small cardiac vein
Right coronary artery and middle cardiac vein
Right coronary artery and small cardiac vein

questions.solution:
The structure marked X is the posterior interventricular artery and the structure marked Y is the middle cardiac vein which can be identified as it drains into the coronary sinus. Both these structures lie in the posterior interventricular sulcus.

Tributaries of coronary sinus include the following:

  • Great cardiac vein
  • Middle cardiac vein
  • Small cardiac vein
  • Posterior vein of the left ventricle
  • Oblique vein(of Marshall) of the left atrium 

Related Pearl: Structures passing through heart sulci

questions.text: You were asked to evaluate a child in a pediatric ward during your internship. You notice, the child was able to make a tower of 6 blocks maximum. What could be the minimum age according to this milestone?
questions.solution:
The milestone of making a tower of  6 blocks is usually attained by 24 months of age.

A child makes a tower of

  • 2 blocks by 15 months
  • 3 blocks by 18 months
  • 6 blocks by 2 years
  • 9 blocks by 3 years

Age Milestone

18 months Scribbles and builds a tower of 3 blocks

questions.text: A senior resident asks you to grade hirsutism using the modified Ferriman Gallwey scoring method in a 25-year-old female patient. After examining all the areas, you assign a score of 3 for each area. The total score in this patient is found to be _______
questions.solution:
The total Modified Ferriman Gallwey score in the above patient is found to be 27.

Modified Ferriman Gallwey scoring system:

  • It is used to quantify the degree of hirsutism
  • In this system, abnormal hair distribution is assessed in nine body areas (Therefore the total score in the above patient is 27) and a score of 0 to 4 is given for each area. Increasing numeric scores correspond to greater hair density within a given area. 
  • The following are the nine areas, which are used to assess hirsutism,
    • Upper lip
    • Chin
    • Chest
    • Upper abdomen
    • Lower abdomen
    • Thighs
    • Back
    • Arms and
    • Buttocks
  • The maximum score is 36
    • A score of 8 to 15 indicates mild hirsutism
    • A score greater than 15 indicates moderate or severe hirsutism.

questions.text: A senior resident shows the following barium enema study done in a 37-year-old male. Which of the following radiological signs is seen in the image below?
questions.solution:
The above-given Barium enema study shows Apple core sign.

Apple core sign/ napkin ring sign - Describes a short segment irregular circumferential stricture of the large bowel that has abrupt “shouldered” margins resembling an apple core. The appearance is classically described on contrast enema studies and is almost always due to a stenosing annular colon carcinoma.

The appearance of the apple-core lesion of the colon also can be caused by other diseases :

  • Villous adenoma
  • Lymphoma with colonic involvement
  • Crohn's disease
  • Chronic ulcerative colitis
  • Ischaemic colitis
  • Chlamydia infection
  • Colonic tuberculosis
  • Helminthoma
  • Colonic amoebiasis
  • Colonic cytomegalovirus

Other options:

  • Sentinel loop sign and Colon cut off sign are X-ray findings in acute pancreatitis.
  • String sign of Kantor is seen with barium small bowel follow-through in a patient with Crohn’s disease

Below image shows String sign of Kantor: tubular narrowing due to spasm or stricture depending on chronicity

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in Acute Pancreatitis

Radiographic findings of acute pancreatitis are non-specific.

The sentinel loop is seen in an X-ray. It is a focal area of adynamic ileus close to an intra-abdominal inflammatory process. A sentinel loop in the upper abdomen indicates pancreatitis.

The sentinel loop sign may aid in localizing the source of inflammation. For example, a sentinel loop in the upper abdomen may indicate pancreatitis, while one in the right lower quadrant may be due to appendicitis.

Colon cut-off sign: Functional spasm at the splenic flexure due to the extension of inflammation to phrenicocolic ligament via transverse mesocolon.

The X-ray given below shows sentinel loop sign (marked as '1') and colon cut-off sign (marked as '2') in a patient with acute pancreatitis:

 

Renal halo sign: Edema around the kidney due to the involvement of paranephric fat resulting in:

  • Obliteration of psoas shadow
  • Localised ground-glass appearance

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman who was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis is on medication consisting of methotrexate 20 mg weekly, folic acid 5 mg weekly and ibuprofen 400 mg 3 times daily. She got recently married and is planning to become pregnant. Which of the following advice would you give with regard to her plans to conceive and her medication?

choices.text: Reduce the dose of methotrexate to 10 mg weekly and ibuprofen to 200 mg 3 times daily
Stop both methotrexate and ibuprofen at least 3 months prior to pregnancy
Stop methotrexate at least 6 months prior to pregnancy, but can continue ibuprofen
Stop ibuprofen at least 6 months prior to pregnancy, but can continue methotrexate

questions.solution:
Methotrexate is a teratogenic drug and should be discontinued at least 6 months before conception. The woman is advised to follow contraceptive measures after stopping methotrexate and avoid pregnancy for the next 6 months.

Also, it is advised that males who are on methotrexate, should follow contraceptive measures for at least 3 months after the last dose of methotrexate.

Ibuprofen is not teratogenic and can be continued. However, NSAIDs should be avoided after 20 weeks.

Safety of antirheumatic drugs during pregnancy:

  • Methotrexate, leflunomide, mycophenolate, and cyclophosphamide are teratogenic and should be stopped before planning a pregnancy.
  • Methotrexate should be stopped 6 months before planning a pregnancy.
  • Leflunomide should be stopped 2 years before planning a pregnancy.
  • NSAIDs are safe up to 20 weeks of pregnancy. Thereafter, they must be discontinued.
  • Sulfasalazine is safe and if administered should be coadministered with folic acid.
  • Glucocorticoids, hydrochloroquine, azathioprine and sulfasalazine are safe, and can all be continued as normal.

questions.text: A patient’s ABG was consistent with the curve X in the nomogram given below with serum Na: 138 mEq/L, serum Cl: 110 mEq/L and serum HCO3-: 19 mEq/L. Which of the following can be a differential diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario shows a normal gap (hyperchloremic) metabolic acidosis, characteristic of RTA (renal tubular acidosis).

The anion gap in this patient can be calculated as Na+ – (Cl- + HCO3-) = 138– (110+19) = 138 - 129 = 9.

The normal anion gap ranges from 6 to 12 mmol/L, with an average of 10 mmol/L. Among the given options, only renal tubular acidosis is associated with normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

All of the other options cause high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Causes of high anion gap metabolic acidosis:

  • Methanol
  • Uremia (chronic kidney failure)
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Paracetamol, Propylene glycol
  • Infection, Iron, Isoniazid
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Ethylene glycol
  • Salicylates

questions.text: A physician recorded diastolic BP in 125 women aged 18 – 60 years and found the mean to be 70 mmHg with standard deviation of 10mmHg. Using z-scores, find the 5th percentile value.
questions.solution:
The z value for the 5th percentile is -1.645.

Using the formula for z scores, z = (X- µ)/σ, we get X = zσ + µ.

In this scenario, X = (-1.645 x 10) + 70 = -16.45 + 70 = 53.55 = 53.6.

Related Pearl: Z Scores

  • Z score indicates the position of any element in a distribution in terms of how many standard deviations it lies from the mean of the distribution.
  • It is also called the standard score.
  • If it lies above the mean, its z score will be positive and if it lies below it, the z score will be negative.
  • For example, if an element lies 1.5 standard deviations below the mean, its z score will be -1.5 and if it lies 0.5 standard deviations above the mean, its z score will be +0.5.
  • The formula for calculating z scores is z = (X- µ)/σ, where x is the element’s value, µ is the mean and σ is the standard deviation. From this, we can also calculate the actual value of the element.
  • Some of the z-values for commonly used percentiles:

questions.text: Your physiology laboratory partner is being examined during a cardiac system practical. Her heart rate is 80 beats/min and her BP is 100/70 mmHg measured in the supine position. Her heart rate increases to 90 beats/min on standing. Which of the following must have prompted the increase in heart rate?
questions.solution:
The decrease in venous return is the likely initial event to have prompted an increase in heart rate.

When a person stands up from a lying down position, it causes pooling of the blood in the legs, due to gravity. This reduces the venous return and causes a decrease in cardiac output. Reduced cardiac output leads to a fall in blood pressure, which in turn causes reduced firing from baroreceptors. As a result, the vagal tone is suppressed, leading to increased heart rate.

 Baroreceptors are mechanoreceptors receptors located in the heart and adventitia of the blood vessels.

  • Types based on location
    • Carotid sinus and aortic arch receptors (high-pressure regions)
    • Cardiopulmonary receptors (low-pressure regions)
  • Afferents
    • Carotid sinus- a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX CN)– the carotid sinus nerve (sinus nerve of Hering)
    • Aortic arch receptor- a branch of the vagus nerve (X CN)– aortic depressor nerve
  • Center for Reflex
    • Medulla (nucleus tractus solitarius)
  • Efferents
    • Sympathetic and parasympathetic neurons to heart and vasculature

Related Pearl: Factors Affecting Heart Rate

Heart rate is accelerated by
  • Decreased activity of arterial baroreceptors
  • Increased activity of atrial stretch receptors
  • Inspiration
  • Excitement
  • Anger
  • Pain
  • Hypoxia
  • Exercise
  • Thyroid hormones
  • Fever

The Heart is slowed by
  • Increased activity of arterial baroreceptors
  • Expiration
  • Grief
  • Stimulation of pain fibers in trigeminal nerve
  • Increased intracranial pressure

questions.text: A patient who was being treated for an arrhythmia presented with palpitations and chest discomfort. His ECG has been given below. Which of the following drugs would be least likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The ECG of this patient shows wide QRS complexes and an undulating baseline suggesting the diagnosis of torsades de pointes. It is associated with prolonged QT interval. Lidocaine does not prolong the QT interval, hence, it is unlikely to cause torsades de pointes. 

Lidocaine belongs to the class IB antiarrhythmic agent. It is considered to have the least arrhythmogenic potential among antiarrhythmic. QT interval is usually unaltered or slightly reduced with lidocaine use.

Among the antiarrhythmics, class Ia and class III drugs prolong action potential duration and thus prolong QT interval and are also prone to cause Torsades de pointes.

Torsade de Pointes is a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. It is characterized by a premature ventricular beat that induces a pause, followed by a sinus beat with a longer QT interval. The T wave is interrupted by a premature ventricular beat, which is the first beat of the polymorphic VT.

Management of a patient with Torsade de Pointes if the tachycardia is stable, includes IV MgSO4, 1-2g over 5-60 minutes, followed by an infusion, which is highly effective for both treatment and prevention, of recurrence of long QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that trigger torsades de pointes. Discontinue the offending drug and correct electrolyte abnormalities. 

If this condition progresses into ventricular fibrillation, the appropriate course of action is to perform defibrillation. 

Related Pearl: Drugs causing QT prolongation and torsades de pointes

  • Amiodarone
  • Quinidine
  • Procainamide
  • Dofetilide
  • Ibutilide

  • Ciprofloxacin
  • Gatifloxacin
  • Moxifloxacin

  • Rilpivirine

  • Desipramine

  • Sertraline
  • Venlafaxine

Antipsychotics:

  • Haloperidol
  • Droperidol
  • Quetiapine
  • Ziprasidone
  • Thioridazine

Others:

  • Cisapride
  • Sumatriptan
  • Zolmitriptan

  • Methadone

questions.text:
You are studying the lung volumes of a patient with COPD using an instrument shown below. Which of the following lung volumes cannot be measured using this instrument?

COPD: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
questions.solution:
The given image shows a spirometer. Residual volume (RV) cannot be measured using this instrument. It also cannot measure any capacity that involves residual volume i.e., functional residual capacity (FRC) and total lung capacity (TLC).

Residual volume is the amount of air remaining in the lung after forceful expiration. As we cannot expire this air, it cannot be directly measured by spirometry.

To measure RV, we need to first measure FRC by the helium dilution technique and then calculate RV by subtracting expiratory reserve volume (ERV) from FRC.

RV = FRC - ERV

A typical basic spirometer consists of a drum inverted over the chamber of water, along with a drum counterbalanced by a weight. When a person breathes into and out of the chamber, the drum rises and falls and recordings are made.

The image below shows a typical basic spirometer.

In the modern dry spirometer, the patient is asked to breathe in and exhale forcefully. The spirometer calculates the volume of air passing through it as a function of time. It hence gives us various parameters useful for the diagnosis of pulmonary/airway disease.

The image below shows the modern dry spirometer.

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

Total lung capacity (TLC)

IRV+TV+ERV+RV

∼5.8 L

Vital capacity (VC)

IRV+TV+ERV

∼4.5 L

Inspiratory capacity (IC)

TV+IRV

∼3.5 L

TV+ERV

∼1.6 L

Functional residual capacity (FRC)

ERV+RV

∼2.3 L

questions.text: A 24-year-old obese male presented with complaints of episodes of eating large quantities of food, even when he is not hungry. He stated that during the episodes, he eats alone, faster than usual, and is unable to control it. There have been such episodes for one or more times every week, for the past 4 months. There are no compensatory behaviours after the episodes. Which of the following psychopharmaceutical agents would be beneficial in this patient along with cognitive behavioural therapy?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of binge eating disorder. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) along with cognitive behavioural therapy, is preferred for the treatment of this condition.

Binge eating disorder is the most common eating disorder. It is commonly seen in obese patients seeking medication. The disorder is associated with recurrent episodes of binge eating during which they eat an abnormally large amount of food over a short time.

The binge-eating episodes are associated with the following:

  • Eating much more rapidly than normal.
  • Eating until feeling uncomfortably full.
  • Eating large amounts of food when not feeling physically hungry.
  • Eating alone because of feeling embarrassed by how much one is eating.
  • Feeling disgusted with oneself, depressed, or very guilty afterwards.

To be diagnosed as binge-eating disorder, such binge eating episodes must occur at least once a week for at least 3 months, and should not be associated with compensatory behavior as in bulimia nervosa and does not occur exclusively during the course of bulimia nervosa or anorexia nervosa.

 

Treatment:

  • Cognitive-behavioural therapy (CBT) is the most effective psychological treatment for binge eating disorder.
  • CBT is usually combined with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) for better results than CBT alone.
  • Commonly used drugs include SSRIs, desipramine, imipramine, topiramate, and sibutramine. Some SSRI medications that are known to improve the mood, as well as binge eating, include fluvoxamine, citalopram, and sertraline.
  • Other treatment methods include Interpersonal psychotherapy (IPT).
  • Self-help groups such as overeaters anonymous (OA) and weight watchers might be helpful for some patients.
