questions.text: A patient undergoing surgery suddenly developed a temperature of 102 F and a pulse rate of 130 bpm. His capnograph shows the following finding. Your senior resident injects intravenous dantrolene immediately. All the following drugs can be used in the treatment of this patient, except ______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia managed with intravenous dantrolene. All the above-mentioned drugs can be used in the treatment of this patient, except calcium channel blockers as they may cause hyperkalemia when used in combination with dantrolene.

The capnograph shows a sudden and progressive increase in EtCO2 which is typical of malignant hyperthermia. 

Dantrolene sodium is the mainstay of therapy for malignant hyperthermia but it is to be reconstituted with sterile distilled water. It is given at a dose of 2.5 mg/kg intravenously and can be repeated every 5-10 minutes (up to 10 mg/kg) till the attack subsides.

Correction of Electrolyte Imbalances:

  • Administer bicarbonate for metabolic acidosis.
  • Hyperkalemia should be treated with insulin.
  • Furosemide may be used to induce diuresis and prevent acute kidney failure.

Other treatment options:

  • All anesthetic agents should be cut off.
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2.
  • If the body temperature is high, it should be brought down using cold intravenous fluids, cooling body cavities with sterile iced fluids, surface cooling with ice packs, and cooling blankets.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

Related Pearl: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

  • Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis
  • Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia
  • Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria
  • Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

  • Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2
  • Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).
  • Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 
  • Cooling the patient

questions.text:
A 54-year-old male comes to the casualty with complaints of bleeding from the nose. The bleeding doesn't settle with the conservative methods, so external carotid artery ligation above the
origin of the superior thyroid artery is performed, as embolization facilities are not available in any accessible hospital. However, the bleeding still continues. Which of the following artery could be the source of this bleed?
questions.solution:
The ethmoidal artery is the likely source of the bleed in this patient.

The ethmoidal artery is a branch of the internal carotid artery whereas the sphenopalatine, greater palatine, and facial artery are branches of the external carotid artery. Hence if bleeding is not controlled by external carotid artery ligation, the ethmoidal artery should be ligated.

Arterial supply of the nose :

Internal carotid system:

  • Branches of the ophthalmic artery
  • Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • Posterior ethmoidal artery

External Carotid System

  • Sphenopalatine artery (branch of the maxillary artery) gives nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches.
  • Septal branch of the greater palatine artery (branch of the maxillary artery).
  • Septal branch of the superior labial artery (branch of the facial artery).

Kiesselbach’s plexus:

Four arteries anastomose at the anterior inferior part of the nasal septum to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach’s plexus.

  • Anterior ethmoidal
  • Septal branch of superior labial
  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine
  • Septal branch of the greater palatine

Ethmoidal vessels are exposed in the medial wall of the orbit by an external ethmoid (Lynch) incision.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents with a cystic swelling in the midline of the neck that moves with deglutition. In a situation where this swelling remains untreated, which of the following is the most probable histological variant of the malignancy likely to develop in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is thyroglossal cyst. Most common cancer arising from a thyroglossal cyst is papillary carcinoma.

Though the most common complication of thyroglossal cyst is infection, 1% of thyroglossal duct cysts are found to be malignant of which the most common type of cancer is papillary (85%). Medullary thyroid carcinomas are not found in thyroglossal duct cysts.

Management:

  • Sistrunk operation (en bloc cystectomy with excision of the central hyoid bone) is the procedure of choice for the surgical management of thyroglossal duct cysts. 
  • To minimize the recurrence of the cyst, the central portion of the hyoid is excised in addition to complete cyst excision including the entire tract.

Thyroglossal cyst.

questions.text: During your ICU posting, your senior resident advises you to extubate the patients, who are on mechanical ventilation and are found to be improving. In order to plan for weaning, the rapid shallow breathing index of the patient should be:
questions.solution:
Rapid shallow breathing index (RSBI) should be less than 100.

Patients with an RSBI <100 are eligible candidates for successful extubation. But, those with an RSBI >120 will need some degree of mechanical ventilator support.

A patient on mechanical ventilation should be tried to wean off when the patient no longer requires the ventilator. This condition usually met when the patient can breathe spontaneously, is hemodynamically stable with adequate arterial oxygen saturation, and when he has a pH >7.25.

Additional criteria include,

  • Inspiratory pressure: -20-30cm H2O
  • Tidal volume: 4-6ml/kg
  • Vital capacity: >10 mL/kg
  • Minute ventilation: <10 L/min
  • Rapid shallow breathing index(RSBI): <100

Patients are weaned off from the ventilator with the help of techniques such as pressure support, synchronized intermittent mandatory ventilation (SIMV), and periods of spontaneous breathing (either on a Τ-piece or on a low setting of CPAP).

Related Pearl: Mechanical Criteria for Weaning or Extubation

  • Inspiratory pressure: -20 to -30cm H2O
  • Tidal volume: 4-6ml/kg
  • Vital capacity: >10 mL/kg
  • Minute ventilation: 10L/min
  • Rapid shallow breathing index: <100

questions.text: During a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the surgeon is attempting to identify the Calot’s triangle. All of the following structures identified by the surgeon are the boundaries of the Calot's triangle except?
questions.solution:
The inferior surface of the liver marked as 4 does not form the boundary of Calot’s triangle. It forms the superior boundary of the hepatobiliary triangle.

The boundaries of Calot’s triangle are 3C's

  • Medially – Common hepatic duct
  • Inferiorly – Cystic duct
  • Superior – Cystic artery

Clinical importance: Identification of Calot’s triangle is important during laparoscopic cholecystectomy for safe ligation and division of cystic duct and cystic artery.

Related Pearl: Calot's triangle and hepatobiliary triangle

Boundaries Calot's Triangle Hepatobiliary Triangle

Superiorly

 Superior border of the cystic artery Inferior surface of the liver

Medially

 Common hepatic duct

Inferiorly

 Cystic duct

Contents of Calot’s triangle:

  • Lymph node of Lund - Sentinel lymph node for the gallbladder
  • Branching of cystic artery from the right hepatic artery

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient is undergoing coronary thrombolysis and requires tenecteplase for fibrinolytic therapy. Which of the following conditions is not an absolute contraindication to starting this drug?

choices.text: Ischemic stroke within the last 3 months

questions.solution:
Tenecteplase is used for fibrinolytic therapy. An active peptic ulcer is a relative contraindication to fibrinolytic therapy. Other options are absolute contraindications.

 Absolute Contraindications to fibrinolytic therapy:

  • Known malignant intracranial neoplasm
  • Prior intracranial hemorrhage
  • Ischemic stroke within the last 3 months
  • Known structural cerebral vascular lesion
  • Suspicion of aortic dissection
  • Active bleeding or bleeding diathesis (excluding menstrual bleeding)
  • Significant closed head trauma or facial trauma within 3 months

Relative Contraindications to fibrinolytic therapy:

  • Uncontrolled hypertension (systolic blood pressure >180 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure >110 mmHg)
  • Active peptic ulcer
  • Noncompressible vascular punctures
  • Traumatic or prolonged CPR or major surgery within 3 weeks
  • Recent (within 2–4 weeks) internal bleeding
  • For streptokinase: prior exposure (more than 5 days ago) or prior allergic reaction to streptokinase
  • Pregnancy
  • Current use of warfarin and INR >1.7

Related Pearl: Plasminogen activators (classification of fibrinolytics)

Fibrin non-specific plasminogen activators

  • Streptokinase - least fibrin specific and has the lowest incidence of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Anistreplase
  • Urokinase

Fibrin specific plasminogen activators

  • Alteplase - has the shortest half-life
  • Tenecteplase - most fibrin specific and given as a single bolus dose
  • Reteplase

questions.text: A ballet dancer spins towards her right. Which of the following will be seen assuming intact vestibulo-ocular reflexes ?

choices.text: Nystagmus with Slow phase towards left and fast phase towards right
Nystagmus with Slow phase towards right and fast phase towards left
Vertical nystagmus  with eyes moving up and down
Cannot be determined from the information given

questions.solution:
In the following scenario, horizontal nystagmus is seen with slow phase towards left and fast phase towards the right.

Nystagmus is the jerky movement of the eyeball in response to head rotation. The direction of the nystagmus is defined by the direction of its fast-phase. Right-beating nystagmus has the fast phase to the right while left beating nystagmus has the fast phase to the left. The fast phase is usually seen in the direction of head rotation.

Intact vestibulo-ocular reflexes allow us to fixate on objects during head movement. When the ballet dancer starts to spin, her eyes are still fixating on the old object and continue to follow it till it is out of the field. This appears as the slow phase of nystagmus. The eyes then quickly snap towards the new fixation point, this is seen as the fast phase of nystagmus towards the direction of head rotation.

In this case, as she is spinning towards the right, her eyes will have a slow phase towards the left and fast phase towards the right.

Once she stops spinning, her eyes will demonstrate post-rotatory nystagmus. It is opposite to the direction of the original nystagmus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient who is HIV positive came to the hospital with complaints of severe non-productive cough, fever, and breathlessness. Transbronchial biopsy of pulmonary tissue demonstrates a foamy alveolar infiltrate and a mononuclear interstitial infiltrates. The treatment of choice in this patient is ________.
questions.solution:
In this case, the transbronchial biopsy of pulmonary tissue demonstrating a foamy alveolar infiltrate and a mononuclear interstitial infiltrates is pathognomonic of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia. Cotrimoxazole or TMP-SMX is considered as the drug of choice for Pneumocystis jeroveci pneumonia 

The treatment of choice for Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX), given either IV or per oral for 14 days to non-HIV-infected patients with mild disease and for 21 days to all other patients.

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole can cause leukopenia, hepatitis, rash, and fever as well as anaphylactic and anaphylactoid reactions. Patients with HIV infection have an unusually high incidence of hypersensitivity to this drug. Serum drug levels should also be monitored if renal function is an issue.

Other drugs used for treatment are :

  • Atovaquone
  • Clindamycin plus Primaquine
  • Pentamidine

Adjuvant agents used in treatment- Prednisone or methylprednisolone

Transbronchial biopsy of pulmonary tissue suggestive of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia.

questions.text: A bullet that causes fire on hitting the target is:
questions.solution:
Incendiary bullets are those filled with explosive (e.g. white phosphorus) at the front end that causes fire on hitting the target.

Frangible bullets are those which are designed to disintegrate into tiny fragments upon target impact.

Dumdum bullets are also called expanding bullets. The tips of these bullets are designed to burst or expand into fragments on impact causing damage over a larger area.

Tandem bullet is a phenomenon seen when two bullets are fired in one shot with one lying right behind the other. It occurs in old, dirty or country firearms. Sometimes an ejected bullet may get lodged in the barrel and comes out when the next shot is fired – in tandem with that bullet.

questions.text: Identify the bacteria which shows beta hemolysis on blood agar, is not sensitive to bacitracin, and shows a positive CAMP test as shown below.
questions.solution:
The bacteria showing beta hemolysis on blood agar, not sensitive to bacitracin disk, and a positive CAMP test, suggests group B streptococci, Streptococcus agalactiae.

They produce zones of hemolysis that are only slightly larger than the colonies (1–2 mm in diameter). The group B streptococci hydrolyze sodium hippurate and give a positive CAMP (Christie, Atkins,Munch-Peterson) test.

The CAMP test is used to identify group B,  β-streptococci based on their ability to form CAMP factor, which causes synergistic hemolysis with β-hemolysin formed from staphylococcus aureus "marked A", when streptococcus agalactiae "marked B" is inoculated perpendicular to a staphylococcus aureus grown on blood agar. This gives characteristic the arrow-head zone of hemolysis. 

S agalactiae (group B streptococci) are important pathogens among pregnant women and neonates.

Other options:

Both S. pneumoniae (pneumococcus) and Streptococcus viridans produce alpha-hemolysis on blood agar. The optochin sensitivity test is done to differentiate Pneumococcus (sensitive) from commensal like Streptococcus viridans (resistant).

Beta-hemolytic streptococci were classified by Lancefield based on group-specific carbohydrate C antigen present on the cell wall, into 20 serological types from Group A to Group V except for I and J.

Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci (Streptococcus pyogenes) are further classified based on protein (M, T, R) antigens present on the cell surface by Griffith typing.

The following table provides important laboratory characteristics that differentiate Streptococcus pyogenes from Streptococcus agalactiae.

Species Lancefield Group Typical Hemolysis Important Lab Characteristics
S.pyogenes A Beta Bacitracin sensitive, PYR test positive
S.agalactiae B Beta Bacitracin resistant, PYR test negative, Hippurate hydrolysis positive, CAMP test positive

Related Pearl: Differentiation between Streptococcus pneumoniae and Streptococcus viridans

Characteristics Streptococcus pneumoniae Streptococcus viridans
Morphology Lanceolate diplococci Cocci in chains
Capsule Capsulated Non-capsulated
Quellung Test Positive Negative
Colonies Initially Dome Shaped, Later Draughtsman Colonies Dome shaped
Growth in Liquid Media Uniform Turbidity Granular Turbidity, powdery deposit
Bile solubility Bile soluble Bile insoluble
Inulin fermentation Positive Negative
Optochin sensitivity Sensitive Resistant
Intraperitoneal inoculation in Mice Fatal infection Non-pathogenic
Hemolysis Alpha-hemolytic (under aerobic conditions) or Beta-hemolytic (under anaerobic conditions) Alpha hemolytic or non-hemolytic

questions.text: During your internship, you notice a cylinder attached to an anesthetic machine present in the OT, as shown in the image below. What is the pin index given for this cylinder?
questions.solution:
The given image shows blue cylinders used to store nitrous oxide. The pin index of these cylinders is 3, 5.

Pin index safety system is used to prevent accidental connection of a wrong gas cylinder in an anesthetic workstation.

Other options:

Option A: Pin index of 2,5 is specific for oxygen-containing cylinders with black bodies and white shoulders.

Option C: Pin index of 1,5 is specific for air-containing cylinders with grey/black bodies and white/black shoulders.

Option D: Pin index of 7 is specific for Entonox-containing cylinders with blue bodies and white/blue shoulders.

Related Pearl: Pin index safety system (PISS):

Note:

  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with more than 7% CO2: 1,6
  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with less than 7% CO2: 2,6

Related Pearl: Characteristics of medical gas cylinders

questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of the procedure shown in the image over its midline counterpart?

choices.text: Lesser chance of anal sphincter involvement

questions.solution:
The above image shows mediolateral episiotomy. The primary advantage of mediolateral episiotomy over midline episiotomy is that there is a lesser chance of anal sphincter involvement due to extension. 

An episiotomy is an intended incision of the perineum with the goal of enlargement of the vaginal opening for birth. Prior to episiotomy, analgesia is provided by existing labor regional analgesia, bilateral pudendal nerve block, or local infiltration with 1% lignocaine. Typically, an episiotomy is completed when the head is visible during a contraction to a diameter of 4 to 5 cm.

Midline episiotomy begins at the fourchette, incises the perineal body in the midline, and ends well before the external anal sphincter. Mediolateral episiotomy begins at the midline of the fourchette and is directed to the right or left at an angle of 60 degrees off the midline. This angle accounts for the stretch distortion of the perineal anatomy during crowning. After delivery and resolution of the distortion, it ultimately yields an incision 45 degrees from the midline for suturing.

Midline episiotomy Mediolateral episiotomy
Surgical repair is easy Surgical repair is difficult
Blood loss is less Blood loss is more
Healing is superior Healing is not so good
Dyspareunia is rare Dyspareunia is comparatively more

Postoperative pain is less

Postoperative pain is more

Extension, if occurs, may involve the anal sphincter

Extension, even if it occurs, will not involve the anal sphincter

 

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with complaints of hard of hearing in his right ear. On otoscopic examination, the tympanic membrane appears adherent to the promontory, prompting you to suspect adhesive otitis. You would grade the retraction in this patient as
questions.solution:
According to Sade's classification, tympanic membrane adherent to the promontorium is classified as  Grade IV retraction.

Sade classification of atelectasis/ retraction of the pars tensa.

  • Grade 1 – Retracted ear - Slight retraction of the tympanic membrane incus
  • Grade 2 – Severe retraction - Retraction of the tympanic membrane, touching the incus or the stapes
  • Grade 3 – Atelectasis - Tympanic membrane touching the promontorium
  • Grade 4 – Adhesive otitis - Tympanic membrane adherent to the promontorium

Another related classification that is relevant clinically is the Tos's classification which is as follows:

Tos’s classification of retraction of Pars Flaccida

  • Stage 1 – Pars flaccida is dimpled and more retracted than normal but not adherent to the malleus
  • Stage 2 – The retraction is adherent to the neck of the malleus and the full extent of the retraction can be seen
  • Stage 3 – Part of the retraction is out of view and there may be partial erosion of the bony attic wall
  • Stage 4 – Definite erosion of the attic wall with the full extent of the retraction being uncertain because it is out of view

questions.text: While evaluating a child with glomerulonephritis, you notice the renal biopsy specimens show ANCA-positive glomerulonephritis with the absence of granulomatous inflammation. Which of the following small vessel vasculitis is this child likely to be suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of microscopic polyangiitis. The absence of granulomatous inflammation differentiates microscopic polyangiitis from other forms of ANCA-associated vasculitis. 

Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA)-associated vasculitis is categorized into 3 distinct forms: 

  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA; formerly Wegener granulomatosis)
  • Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA)
  • Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, formerly called Churg–Strauss syndrome (CSS) 

Necrotizing vasculitis is the cardinal histologic feature in both GPA and MPA. Kidney biopsies typically demonstrate crescentic glomerulonephritis with little or no immune complex deposition. hence the name “pauci-immune vasculitis.”

Granulomatous inflammation is typically absent in MPA but is common in both GPA and CSS.

ANCA-associated vasculitis (AAV) comprises a group of multi-systemic diseases affecting small-to-medium-sized vessels. It is characterized by the presence of ANCA with specificity for either proteinase-3 (PR3) or myeloperoxidase (MPO).

Other options:

Wegener granulomatosis: It is now known as Granulomatosis with polyangiitis(GPA). It is a necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis affecting the small and medium-sized vessels. It usually targets the respiratory tracts(both upper and lower) and the kidneys.

Churg-Strauss syndrome: It is necrotizing granulomatous small vessel vasculitis with a history of bronchial asthma and peripheral eosinophilia.

Henoch–Schonlein purpura: It is the most common vasculitis of childhood. It is characterized by leukocytoclastic vasculitis and IgA deposition in the skin, kidney, joints, and GIT. The clinical manifestations include palpable purpura, joint involvement in the form of arthritis or arthralgias, diarrhea, vomiting, renal involvement in the form of microscopic hematuria, proteinuria, etc.

Related Pearl: Microscopic polyangiitis v/s granulomatosis with polyangiitis

Both microscopic polyangiitis and granulomatosis with polyangiitis are small vessel vasculitides that are mainly caused due to antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA). Therefore, they share common clinical features with some differences.

Features Microscopic polyangiitis Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
Vessels affected Small and medium vessel vasculitis Small vessel vasculitis
Principal organs involved

Lungs (hemoptysis)

Kidney

GIT

Skin (cutaneous vasculitis)

Nerves (Mononeuritis multiplex)

Upper respiratory tract

Lungs (hemoptysis)

Kidney

Eye

Skin

Upper airway involvement

 Less common

More common

(Sinusitis, otitis media, hearing loss, septal perforation)
Nodular cavities in the lungs Absent Present
ANCA pANCA (mainly) cANCA(mainly)
Granuloma Absent Present
Necrosis Present Present
Kidney Glomerulonephritis Glomerulonephritis

 

Related Pearl: ANCA Antibodies

The antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are the antibodies that are targeted against the specific proteins present in neutrophils and monocytes. They can be further classified as:

 

Cytoplasmic ANCA (cANCA)

 Perinuclear ANCA (pANCA)

Directed against

Proteinase 3 (PR3)

 Myeloperoxidase (MPO)

Predominantly positive in

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis)

Microscopic polyangiitis

Churg–Strauss syndrome 

Crescentic glomerulonephritis

Inflammatory Bowel Disease

Staining pattern

Granular cytoplasmic staining

Perinuclear or nuclear staining

questions.text: A patient presented with a 3-week history of dry cough and dyspnea on exertion. Gallium-67 nuclear scan of this patient showed the lambda sign. This sign involves all the following structures except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the lambda sign on the gallium-67 scan suggest that the patient has sarcoidosis. Gallium-67 scan does not involve the left paratracheal nodes.

The image given below shows the panda sign (A) and the lambda sign (B) on the gallium-67 scan seen in sarcoidosis.

The lambda sign seen on gallium-67 scans is the gallium equivalent of the 1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign seen in the setting of thoracic sarcoidosis. It involves:

  • Right paratracheal nodes
  • Right hilar nodes
  • Left hilar nodes

1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign is a lymph node enlargement pattern on chest X-rays. It is also known as the Garland triad and involves the same three groups of lymph nodes. It is shown below.

The chest radiograph is the preferred tool used to stage sarcoidosis.

Stage 1 Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy (usually symmetrical); right paratracheal nodes often enlarged
Stage 2  Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and parenchymal infiltrates
Stage 3 Parenchymal infiltrates without bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy
Stage 4  Pulmonary fibrosis

questions.text: A senior pediatric resident uses Silverman Anderson scoring system to assess respiratory distress in newborns. Which of the following components is given a score of 1?

choices.text: Upper chest movement showing inspiratory lag

questions.solution:
According to Silverman Anderson's score, upper chest movement showing inspiratory lag is given a score of 1. 

Expiratory grunting that is audible without a stethoscope and markedly visible xiphoid retractions are given a score of 2. An absence of nasal flaring would be given a score of 0.

Silverman Anderson's score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in neonates. Components of this scoring system include:

    Score    0      1       2

1. Upper chest retraction

(Chest movement)

 Synchronized Lag on inspiration See-saw

2. Lower chest retraction

(Intercostal retraction)

 None Just visible Marked
3. Xiphoid    retraction None Just visible Marked
4. Nasal flaring None Minimal Marked
5. Grunt Not audible Audible with Stethoscope Audible with naked ear

 

The Silverman Anderson Retraction Score is more suited for preterms, however, the Downes’ Score can be applied to any gestational age and condition. Components of Downes' score are respiratory rate, cyanosis, air entry, grunt, and retractions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman having an obstetric score of G2P1 comes to you for a regular antenatal check-up. A diagnosis of gestational hypertension can be made in this patient if  ______

choices.text: Her BP is ≥ 140/90 mm Hg during first trimester with proteinuria
Her BP is ≥ 140/90 mm Hg during first trimester without proteinuria
Her BP is ≥ 140/90 mm Hg for first time after 20 weeks of gestation with proteinuria
Her BP is ≥ 140/90 mm Hg for first time after 20 weeks of gestation without proteinuria

questions.solution:
The diagnosis of gestational hypertension can be made in the above patient if her BP is ≥ 140/90 mm Hg after 20 weeks of gestation without proteinuria. 

Hypertensive disorders in pregnancy:

 Gestational Hypertension

 Pre-Eclampsia

 Chronic Hypertension in   pregnancy

 Rise in BP >140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks of pregnancy

 Rise in BP >140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks of pregnancy

 Previously known hypertensive or BP >140/90 mmHg before 20 weeks of gestation

 No Proteinuria

 Proteinuria present(>300 mg in 24 hrs urine or >30 mg/dl in the random urine sample or urine dipstick 1+)

 No proteinuria

 BP returns to normal within 12 weeks of delivery

 BP returns to normal within 12 weeks of delivery

 BP does not come to normal within 12 weeks of delivery

 

Note:

  • Hypertension in pregnancy is defined as BP of >140/90 mmHg measured 2 times with at least 6-h intervals.

questions.text: A  researcher focussing on genodermatology was studying the anomalies of DNA repair mechanisms and the associated diseases. He was evaluating an 8-year-old girl with the following lesions who was undergoing treatment for squamous cell carcinoma of the skin. What is the underlying defect in this case?

choices.text: Inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV radiation
Defect in Nonhomologous End Joining of chromosomes
Defect in the functioning of DNA helicase

questions.solution:
The following image shows an eight-year-old girl with xeroderma pigmentosum. Xeroderma pigmentosum is an example of defective DNA nucleotide excision repair where there is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure.

The image shows large hyperkeratotic lesions on her face, with some induration, suggestive of actinic keratosis and early squamous cell carcinoma. There are also multiple hyper-pigmented lentigos and xerosis on the entire front of the face. Marked corneal scarring and injection can also be seen.

UV radiation leads to pyrimidine dimerization in DNA strands, preventing further replication by DNA polymerase. The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects the dimer formation in DNA. There is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure.

Option D: Patients with Werner syndrome show premature aging which is a disease of defective Homologous Repair. The defective gene product is DNA helicase, a protein involved in DNA replication, repair, and other functions that require DNA unwinding. The defect causes the rapid accumulation of chromosomal damage that may mimic injury that normally accumulates during cellular aging.

Related Pearl: Human Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

DNA damage repair type

Diseases

Defective Nonhomologous End Joining Repair (NHEJ)

Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID)

Radiation sensitive severe combined immunodeficiency disease(RS-SCID)

Defective Homologous Repair (HR)

AT-like disorder (ATLD)

Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS)

Bloom syndrome (BS)

Werner syndrome (WS)

Rothmund-Thomson syndrome (RTS)

Breast cancer suspectibility 1 and 2 (BRCA1, BRCA2)

Defective DNA Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER)

Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP)

Cockayne syndrome (CS)

Trichothiodystrophy (TTD)

Defective DNA Base Excision Repair (BER)

MUTYH-associated polyposis (MAP)

Defective DNA Mismatch Repair (MMR)

Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with a painless lump on the upper side of her left breast following an injury.  Skin tethering and nipple retraction are also present. Which of the following is best suited to differentiate whether this lump is due to traumatic fat necrosis or due to carcinoma?
questions.solution:
A biopsy is required to differentiate traumatic fat necrosis from carcinoma of the breast.

Traumatic fat necrosis mimics breast carcinoma. As it may present with:

  • Skin tethering
  • Nipple retraction
  • Lump in the breast(often painless).
  • Mammographic densities or calcifications

Histologically, fat necrosis is composed of lipid-laden macrophages, scar tissue, and chronic inflammatory cells.

Grossly ill-defined, firm, gray-white nodules containing small chalky-white foci are seen.

The mammogram shows egg-shell calcification. It has no malignant potential.

Note: A history of trauma is not diagnostic as this may merely have drawn the patient’s attention to a pre-existing lump and biopsy is required for diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common subtype of acute myeloid leukemia encountered in a child with Downs syndrome?
questions.solution:
Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia is the most common subtype of acute myeloid leukemia encountered in a child with Down syndrome.

Children with trisomy 21 have a 10-fold to 20-fold increased risk of developing acute leukemia. Both acute lymphoblastic leukemia and acute myeloid leukemia can occur.

questions.text: A neonate has a cardiac murmur and the eye finding shown in the image below. Investigations revealed bilateral hearing defect. The mother gives a history of viral exanthem during the first trimester of the pregnancy. The most common cardiac defect seen in such neonates is:
questions.solution:
Maternal history of viral exanthem in the first trimester and the image showing the presence of bilateral congenital cataract and hearing defect is suggestive of congenital rubella syndrome. Patent ductus arteriosus is the most common cardiac defect associated with this condition.

Congenital rubella syndrome is associated with rubella infection in mothers in early pregnancy. The classic triad of congenital rubella syndrome includes:

  • Sensorineural hearing loss
  • Congenital cataract
  • Congenital heart disease (most commonly: patent ductus arteriosus)

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with the following pruritic lesion 2 days after developing a fever. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows small, closely grouped vesicles on an inflamed base which are suggestive of herpes labialis or cold sore.

It is caused by HSV-1 (less frequently HSV-2) and commonly affects the face.

The lesions are painful and pruritic. Fever is often present which subsides in 3–5 days followed by the initial vesicular lesions becoming pustular and then crusted before healing in 7–10 days without scarring. Recurrent herpetic lesions are vesicular and ulcerative and tend to occur in the same region.

Treatment: Oral acyclovir 200 mg and topical 5% acyclovir can be used for treatment. In case of resistance to acyclovir, foscarnet or cidofovir can be used.

Option A: Varicella presents with papules and vesicles with a centripetal distribution associated with systemic symptoms of fever and malaise.

Option C: Molluscum contagiosum presents with shiny, pearly white umbilicated papules.

Option D: Whitlow presents with painful swelling of the fingertips and periungual area due to herpes infection by inoculation.

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with diphtheria and diphtheria antitoxin is administered to him. After 10 days, he presents with urticarial rashes, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and a palpable spleen. Which of the following statements is not true about the type of hypersensitivity seen in this condition?

choices.text: This is a systemic form of  hypersensitivity
Can be seen following an injection of penicillin
It is a type II hypersensitivity reaction
A single injection can cause a hypersensitivity reaction

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of serum sickness, which is an example of a type III hypersensitivity reaction. It is a systemic form of type III hypersensitivity.

This appears 7-12 days following a single injection of a high concentration of foreign serum such as the diphtheria antitoxin. The clinical syndrome consists of fever, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, arthritis, glomerulonephritis, endocarditis, vasculitis, urticarial rashes, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.

Serum sickness differs from other types of hypersensitivity reactions in that, a single injection can serve both as the sensitizing dose and the shocking dose. It is more commonly seen following an injection of penicillin or other antibiotics.

In type III hypersensitivity, immune complexes may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating the complement system. The inflammatory reaction causes tissue injury.

The pathogenesis of systemic immune complex disease can be divided into three phases:

  • Formation of immune complexes
  • Deposition of immune complexes
  • Inflammation and tissue injury.

Examples of type III hypersensitivity reactions:

  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • Serum sickness
  • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type

Immune Mechanisms

Histopathological lesions

Immediate
 hypersensitivity
(type I)

  • Anaphylaxis
  • Allergies
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Atopic dermatitis

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Antibody-mediated hypersensitivity
(type II)

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

Immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity
(type III)

  • SLE
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

Inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis)

Cell-mediated hypersensitivity
(type IV)

  • Contact dermatitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Type 1 diabetes
  • Tuberculosis

Activated T lymphocytes →

1. Release of cytokines, inflammation, and macrophage activation

2. T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity

Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

questions.text: The region marked corresponds to the surface marking for a part of the heart. What ECG abnormality is specifically associated with the enlargement of the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The region marked corresponds to the surface marking for the right atrium and p pulmonale on ECG denotes enlargement of the right atrium.

P mitrale on ECG denotes enlargement of the left atrium.

QT prolongation is a measure of delayed ventricular repolarisation.

ST-elevation is an ECG finding seen in myocardial infarction.

The costal margin, xiphoid process, and the mid-clavicular line are seen in this image. The examiner draws a laterally convex line that extends from a level below the 2nd costal cartilage (as clued in by the sternal angle) - i.e., 3rd costal cartilage to about 3 spaces below - i.e., the 6th costal cartilage. This line is about 1.2 cms lateral to the sternal edge. These suggest that the region marked corresponds to the surface marking for the right atrium.

The projection of the cardiac borders, of an average adult, on to the anterior thoracic wall forms a trapezoid.  This can be mapped out using the percussion method by looking for cardiac dullness. 

The varying heart borders and the corresponding surface markings are as follows:

  • The upper border slopes gently from the second left costal cartilage to the third right costal cartilage. It corresponds to the left atrium.
  • The right border is convex to the right and runs from the third to the sixth right costal cartilages, 1–2 cm lateral to the sternal edge. It corresponds to the right atrium.
  • The inferior border, also known as the acute border runs leftwards from the 6th right costal cartilage to the cardiac apex which is located approximately 9 cm lateral to the midline, often in the left 5th intercostal space or level with the 5th or 6th rib. It corresponds to the right ventricle.
  • The left border, also known as the obtuse border, is convex laterally on the left. It extends superomedially from the cardiac apex to meet the second left costal cartilage about 1 cm from the left sternal edge. It corresponds to the left ventricle.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a skeletal manifestation of Langerhans cell histiocytosis?

choices.text: Mosaic bone pattern of lamellar bones

questions.solution:
All of the above lesions can be seen in Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis except the mosaic pattern of lamellar bones which is seen in Paget's disease.

Following are skeletal and radiological manifestations of Langerhan's cell histiocytosis:

Skull:

  • Solitary or multiple punched-out lytic lesion without sclerotic rim.
  • Double contour or beveled edge appearance ( hole within a hole sign).   
  • Button sequestra representing residual bone.
  • Geographic skull.

Mandible:

  • Floating tooth: loss of lamina dura.

Spine:

  • Vertebra Plana: Most common cause of vertebra plana in children; mostly seen in thoracic spine.

Skull in LCH, Vetebra plana:

questions.text: As per the Bowditch effect, you would expect to see which of the following manifestation following an increase in heart rate?

choices.text: With increasing HR, strength of contraction increases
With increasing HR, more cardiac fibres are recruited
With increasing HR, there is decrease in stroke volume to maintain constant cardiac output
With increasing HR, the blood pressure drops

questions.solution:
Bowditch effect of the heart explains that with an increase in heart rate, the strength of contraction increases.

The below image shows the strength of cardiac contraction in 2 different cases. 

Bowditch effect is the mechanism by which we get more cardiac output during exercise. Repeated stimulation or faster heart rate increases the calcium that enters in cardiac cell with each action potential. It is due to the increased cytoplasmic calcium which accumulates with each contraction and binds to cause more powerful contraction. 

Another effect, with a similar mechanism of action, is post-extrasystolic potentiation. After an extra-systole(sudden extra ventricular beat)the beat that immediately follows extra systole has increased amplitude. This is because the sarcoplasmic reticulum accumulates the extra calcium and hence the immediate next beat has a higher amplitude

 

Other options:

Cardiac muscle is a functional syncytium and every time it contracts, all the cardiac fibres contract, as they get the depolarization wave. There is no scope of additional cardiac fibres to be recruited, unlike skeletal muscle.

Every time stroke volume decreases, HR is increased to maintain cardiac output. But if HR increases during exercise, it is over and above the existing stroke volume, to meet the cardiac output demands. It doesn’t lead to a decrease in stroke volume. ( But vice versa is not true. Athletes have a higher stroke volume due to years of training and have a lesser resting heart rate). Athletes have a lesser resting heart rate due to prominent vagal tone and remodelling of the sinus node.

Fall in blood pressure with increasing heart rate is known as Marey’s law.

questions.text: Visual field testing of a patient revealed the following type of loss. Where is the likely site of lesion in optic pathway?
questions.solution:
The image shows homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. The likely site of the lesion is occipital lobe.

Homonymous hemianopia (HH) involves loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. HH is characteristically seen in lesions involving the visual pathway posterior to the optic chiasma.

HH may be either complete or incomplete. 

  • A complete HH is characterised by loss of entire hemifield on the same side in both eyes.
  • An incomplete HH is characterised by partial loss of visual field on the same side in both eyes. Incomplete HH is further classified as congruous or incongruous, depending on whether the extent of partial loss of visual field in both the eyes is same or different, respectively.

Lesions involving occipital lobe usually shows macular sparing because macular representation is seperate and quite large as compared to peripheral vision. Moreover, macular area in occipital lobe is supplied both by posterior and middle cerebral artery. In case of vascular lesions (eg stroke) affecting occipital lobe, it is less likely to involve both these arteries.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: Which of the following receptors is not matched correctly with the appropriate substances, agents, or microbes they recognize?

choices.text: NOD-like receptor - uric acid and released ATP

questions.solution:
RIG-like receptors (RLRs) are present in the cytosol of a majority of cells and detect nucleic acids of viruses that replicate in the cytoplasm of the infected cells. These receptors also stimulate the production of antiviral cytokines.

NOD-like receptors (NLRs) are present in the cytosol, which recognize products released from damaged/necrotic cells(uric acid and ATP), ion disturbances (like loss of K+), and a few microbial products. Most of the NLRs signal via a cytosolic multiprotein complex called the inflammasome. This activates the enzyme caspase-1 that generates the biologically active form of cytokine interleukin-1 (IL-1). IL-1 is a mediator of inflammation that acts by recruiting leukocytes and inducing fever. Gain-of-function mutations in NOD-like receptor results in periodic fever syndromes, also known as autoinflammatory syndromes. These syndromes respond very well to treatment with IL-1 antagonists. The NLR-inflammasome pathway also plays a role in the recognition of urate crystals (inflammation associated with gout) and the detection of lipids and cholesterol crystals.

C-type lectin receptors (CLRs) are present on the plasma membrane of macrophages and dendritic cells which detect fungal glycans and elicit an inflammatory response to different fungi.

Mannose receptors recognize microbial sugars that contain terminal mannose residues and induce phagocytosis of these microbes.

questions.text: A patient is able to speak easily and fluently, but he is using incorrect words like 'den' for 'pen', associated with neologism and sentences which are incomprehensible. Which type of aphasia is likely in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The patient is most likely suffering from Wernicke's aphasia. The speech is easy and fluent but there are difficulties related to the output of language like  paraphasia (substitution of similar-sounding, non-words, or incorrect words) and neologisms (non-existent words).

It is a type of fluent aphasia which is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus due to the involvement of the Wernicke's area. The speech is full of jargon and neologisms that make little sense.

Other options: 

Option B- Broca's or motor/non-fluent aphasia is seen in lesions of the inferior frontal gyrus which contains the motor speech area. Speech is non-fluent and interrupted, with a paucity of functional words.

Option C- Comprehension of written language and the ability to name objects are compromised in anomic aphasia. This aphasia is caused by damage to the angular gyrus that disrupts visual information processing and transmission to the Wernicke area.

Option D- Conduction aphasia is seen in lesions of the arcuate fasciculus, the bundle of nerve fibers connecting the Wernicke and Broca's areas. Repetition of words is impaired and paraphasias are observed, though not as much as in Wernicke aphasia.

Related Pearl: Aphasias and Related Conditions

  Comprehension Repetition of Spoken language Naming Fluency
Wernicke's Impaired Impaired Impaired Preserved
Broca's Preserved Impaired Impaired Decreased
Global Impaired Impaired Impaired Decreased
Conduction Preserved Impaired Impaired Preserved
Anterior (nonfluent) transcortical Preserved Preserved Impaired Impaired
Posterior (fluent) transcortical Impaired Preserved Impaired Preserved
Isolation Impaired Echolalia Impaired No purposeful speech
Anomic Preserved Preserved Impaired Preserved except for word finding pauses
Pure Word Deafness Impaired only for spoken language Impaired Preserved Preserved
Pure Alexia Impaired only for reading Preserved Preserved  Preserved

questions.text: Which of the following types of fibers is seen in the structure marked by the yellow arrow in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is Fornix, they contain association fibres.

Association fibres connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere whereas commissural fibres connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres. 

Fornix arises from the hippocampus and ends in the mamillary body of the hypothalamus. It is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery. The function of the commissure of the fornix is to connect the hippocampal formations of the two sides.

Arcuate fasciculus/U fibres have short association fibres.

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman had undergone breast implantation one year back. She now presents to you with pain in the left breast. MRI imaging shows the following finding. It is indicative of:

choices.text: Stepladder sign indicating Intra-capsular implant rupture
Stepladder sign indicating extra-capsular implant rupture
Linguine sign indicating Intra-capsular implant rupture
Linguine sign indicating Extra-capsular implant rupture

questions.solution:
The given breast MRI shows linguine sign which is seen in intra-capsular rupture of a breast implant. It is due to the free-floating shell within the implant.

After implantation of a silicone or saline breast implant, a fibrous capsule (scar) forms around the implant shell. In an intracapsular rupture, the contents of the implant are contained by the fibrous scar, while the shell appears as a group of wavy lines. This has been termed the "linguine sign". It is seen in intra-capsular rupture of a breast implant. It is best seen on MRI.


Note:

  • Stepladder sign is analogous to the "linguine sign," which is seen on the USG of the breast. It is identified as multiple, discontinuous, parallel, linear echoes in the lumen.
  • Snowstorm sign on USG is seen in extracapsular rupture due to silicone granuloma.

questions.text: Which of the following color-coded kits is recommended for the syndromic management of patients with anorectal discharge in sexually transmitted infections (STIs)?
questions.solution:
Kit 8 / Brown kit is recommended for the syndromic management of patients presenting with anorectal discharge.

NACO color-coded kits for syndromic management of STIs:

Kit Syndrome/s
Kit 1 (Grey)

Urethral discharge

Cervical discharge

Painful scrotal swelling
Kit 2 (Green) Vaginal discharge / Vaginitis
Kit 3 (White) Non-herpetic genital ulcers
Kit 4 (Blue)

Non-herpetic genital ulcers if allergic to penicillin
Kit 5 (Red) Herpetic genital ulcers
Kit 6 (Yellow) Lower abdominal pain
Kit 7 (Black) Inguinal bubo
Kit 8 (Brown) Anorectal discharge syndrome

 

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the diagnosis of myocardial infarction?

choices.text: Chest pain on palpation is suggestive of myocardial infarction
Normal ECG at presentation excludes myocardial infarction
Normal baseline troponin and elevated 6-hour troponin suggests myocardial infarction

questions.solution:
A normal baseline troponin and elevated 6-hour troponin suggests myocardial infarction is the true statement.

Patients presenting with symptoms suggestive of myocardial infarction should undergo measurement of cardiac biomarkers. The preferred biomarker is cardiac troponin T (cTnT) or I (cTnI).

The admission troponin level may be normal if the patient presents early after the onset of symptoms. The troponin levels are assessed at the time of presentation, and 3-6 hrs after the onset of symptoms. If the 6-hour troponin level is normal then acute coronary syndrome is unlikely to explain the patient's chest pain. Patients with diabetes mellitus are more likely to present with painless STEMI.

An elevated troponin level is most likely suggestive of myocardial infarction and should be interpreted along with other investigations such as electrocardiographic changes and cardiac imaging to confirm the diagnosis. Levels of cTnI and cTnT may remain elevated for 7–10 days after STEMI.

Other options:

Option A: Chest pain reproducible on palpation is unlikely due to myocardial infarction. It is usually suggestive of a neuromuscular condition such as costochondritis, or trauma/strain.

Option B: A normal ECG at the time of presentation alone does not exclude myocardial infarction. In the case of normal ECG, other investigations including cardiac biomarkers and imaging are done.

Option D: The likelihood of myocardial infarction based on T-wave inversion is high, if ≥0.2 mV, and intermediate, if >0.1 mV.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with stage 4 pelvic inflammatory disease was brought to you for further management. Which of the following conditions is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Stage IV of pelvic inflammatory diseases is associated with ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess.

It usually presents with sudden worsening of the patient's condition. The delay in surgical debridement and drainage increases the rate of associated mortality.

Depending upon the severity of tubal damage, five stages of PID have been described,

Stages of PID:

Stage

Condition

Stage I 

Acute salpingitis without peritonitis—no adhesions

Stage II 

Acute salpingitis with peritonitis—purulent discharge

Stage III 

Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex 

Stage IV 

Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess

Stage V  

Tubercular salpingitis

questions.text: A patient with prolactinoma has been prescribed bromocriptine. Which of the following would you advise her regarding the use of this drug?

choices.text: It can worsen her glycemic control
Headache and hypertension can occur on initial use.
It should be started at a low dose, orally administered at bedtime with a snack.
Single oral dose in the morning is sufficient as elimination is very slow.

questions.solution:
Bromocriptine is used in the management of prolactinoma. It should be started at a low dose administered at bedtime with a snack to avoid the side effects on initial use.

It is a semisynthetic ergot alkaloid with D2 receptor agonism. The oral absorption of bromocriptine is good but only 7% of the dose reaches the systemic circulation because of extensive first-pass metabolism in the liver. Bromocriptine has a short elimination t 1/2 (between 2 to 8 hours) and thus it should be given in multiple divided doses. A slow-release formulation of bromocriptine is also available now which can be used vaginally (2.5 mg once daily).

Side effects of bromocriptine:

  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Headache
  • Postural hypotension (occurs on initial use)
  • Nasal congestion
  • Digital vasospasm (Should be avoided in peripheral vascular diseases)
  • CNS effects such as psychosis, hallucinations, nightmares, or insomnia  

The adverse effects can be avoided by starting at a low dose (1.25 mg) administered at bedtime with a snack and then slowly increasing the dose as required by monitoring the prolactin levels. Patients often develop tolerance to the adverse effects after a period.

Uses of bromocriptine:

  • Hyperprolactinemia due to macroprolactinomas causing galactorrhoea, amenorrhea, and infertility in women
  • Parkinsonism 
  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus (improves glycemic control along with diet and exercise)
  • Supression of lactation

questions.text: A public health official wants to determine if there are coliforms in food or water samples in the locality he is inspecting. He sends a few samples to the laboratory for tests and culture. He gets the following result from one of the samples which shows _____

choices.text: Escherichia coli colonies on EMB agar
Escherichia coli colonies with a positive MUG test
Salmonella colonies on triple-sugar iron agar

questions.solution:
The above image shows Escherichia coli colonies on EMB agar which appear as dark blue-black colonies with an iridescent green metallic sheen because they are lactose fermenters.

 

EMB agar or Eosin methylene blue (EMB) agar is a selective, differential medium.

It is selective because it allows the growth of gram-negative rods and inhibits the growth of gram-positive organisms. Its differential property is based on the fact that Salmonella and Shigella do not ferment lactose while other enteric gram-negative rods do.  

Other options:

Salmonella and Shigella produce a colorless colony in the eosin methylene blue agar because they do not ferment lactose. Since both Salmonella and Shigella appear colorless, triple-sugar iron agar is used to differentiate Salmonella from Shigella. 

A positive MUG test is also characteristic of Escherichia coli.  More than 90% of E. coli isolates are positive for the enzyme β-glucuronidase. This enzyme uses the substrate MUG (4-methylumbelliferyl-β-glucuronide), in a test known as the MUG test. Isolates from anatomic sites other than urine with the characteristic colony features (plus a negative oxidase test ) can be confirmed as E.coli with a positive MUG test.

Electric blue fluorescence indicates a positive test.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the weekly iron and folic acid supplementation (WIFS) scheme?

choices.text: Weekly administration of 150mg of elemental iron
Biannual de-worming to control helminthic infection
Weekly administration of  200 μg of folic acid

questions.solution:
Biannual de-worming to control helminthic infection is one of the interventions in the WIFS scheme. All the other options are incorrect.

 

Weekly iron and folic acid supplementation scheme (WIFS) was introduced to curb the high prevalence and incidence of anemia among adolescent boys and girls.

Key interventions:

  • Supervised weekly administration of 100mg of elemental iron and 500 μg of folic acid.
  • Biannual de-worming by the administration of Albendazole 400mg, to control helminth infection.
  • Screening of target groups for moderate/severe anemia and referral to appropriate health facility if needed.
  • Information and Counseling to improve dietary intake and prevent intestinal worm infestation.

 

Note: Anemia Mukt Bharat, is an initiative launched in 2018, to reduce the prevalence of anemia by 3 percentage points every year, among children, adolescents, women in the reproductive age group, pregnant, and lactating women. The recommended dosage of IFA for adolescent boys and girls under this scheme is 60mg iron + 500 μg folic acid, weekly.

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme, giving IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of their anemia status, is a key intervention.

Note 1: Prophylaxis with iron should be withheld in case of acute illness (fever, diarrhea, pneumonia, etc.) and in a known case of thalassemia major/ history of repeated blood transfusion. In cases of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), IFA supplementation should be continued as per the SAM management protocol.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

questions.text: Which of the following components is a part of the Physical Quality of Life Index?
questions.solution:
Literacy rate is one of the components of the Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI). All other options are components of the human development index (HDI).

Physical Quality of Life Index measures three indicators:

  • Infant mortality rate
  • Life expectancy at age one
  • Literacy rate

For each indicator, the performance of a country is rated from 0 to 100, where 0 is the worst performance and 100 is the best performance. PQLI is calculated by taking the average of the three indicators, with equal weightage for each of the indicators. 

The index is used for international and national comparisons. It measures the results of social, economic, and political policies. The PQLI does not take into account the per capita income of the country. Therefore, the Middle Eastern countries that are rich, have a lower PQLI compared to Sri Lanka or the state of Kerala in India.

Related Pearl: HDI vs. PQLI

 

Human Development Index (HDI)

 Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI)
Components

Longevity (Life expectancy at birth)

A decent standard of living (Real GNI per capita in PPP US$)

Knowledge (mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling)

Life expectancy at 1 year of age 

Infant Mortality rate

Literacy rate
Range 0 to +1 0 to 100

questions.text: A multiparous woman has a previous history of birth trauma with injury to the uterosacral and cardinal ligaments. Which of the following is likely to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
Uterosacral and cardinal ligaments form the level 1 support of the genital organs. Level 1 damage can lead to enterocele, uterine descent, vault descent.

DeLancey introduced three-level systems of genital tract supports,

  • Level I includes uterosacral and cardinal ligaments and its damage leads to uterine descent, enterocoele, and vault prolapse.
  • Level II includes pelvic fascia, paracolpos, arcus tendinous, pubocervical and rectovaginal fascia, and its damage leads to cystocele and rectocele.
  • Level III includes levator ani muscle and its damage leads to urethrocele, gaping introitus, and deficient perineum.

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

 

Related Pearl: Supports of the uterus

A. Primary supports

  • Muscular or active support of the uterus:
    • Pelvic diaphragm
    • Perineal body
    • Urogenital diaphragm
  • Ligamentous (fibromuscular or mechanical) support:
    • Transverse cervical ligaments of Mackenrodt or cardinal ligament
    • Uterosacral ligament
    • Round ligament of the uterus
    • Pubocervical ligament
    • Uterine axis

B. Secondary supports formed by peritoneal ligaments:

  • Broad ligament
  • Uterovesical fold of peritoneum
  • Rectovaginal fold of peritoneum

questions.text:
A 45-year-old traffic policeman came to the surgical outpatient department with tortuous swellings on his lower limb. He then presents 3 months later with physical examination findings as shown in the image given below. Choose the option that correctly represents his findings under the 2020 revised CEAP classification.

CEAP - Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology
questions.solution:
The given image is characteristic of atrophie blanche, which is classified as C4B under CEAP guidelines.

Atrophie blanche is a localized white atrophic skin frequently surrounded by dilated capillaries and hyperpigmentation, usually seen around the ankle. This is a sign of severe chronic venous disease.

The clinical class of C4 under CEAP includes Changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary to chronic venous disease. It is further classified as follows:

  • C4a-Pigmentation or eczema
  • C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche
  • C4c-Corona phlebectatica

Recent 2020 update on the CEAP system includes,

  • C2r for recurrent varicose veins
  • C4c for corona phlebectatica
  • C6r for recurrent active venous ulcer

Related Pearl: CEAP Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology)

C1

C2

C2r

C3

Changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary

to chronic venous disease

C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche

C4c-Corona phlebectatica

C5

Healed ulcer

C6

C6r

Active ulcer

Recurrent active venous ulcer

S

With symptoms attributable to venous disease

A

Absence of symptoms attributable to venous disease

Ec

Congenital (Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome)

Ep
