Note:

  • The descriptor A (asymptomatic) or S (symptomatic) is placed after the C clinical class.
  • Telengiactesia refers to tiny intradermal venules <1 mm in diameter.
  • Reticular veins refer to small dilated subdermal blue veins of 1 to 2.9 mm
  • Varicose veins refer to dilated tortuous veins >3 mm in diameter

questions.text: Which among the following is the narrowest constriction of the ureter where a ureteric stone is most likely to be lodged?
questions.solution:
The stone is most likely to be lodged in the vesicoureteric junction marked as D in the image as it is the narrowest part of the ureter.

The ureter is constricted at 5 places:

  1. At the pelvi-ureteric junction
  2. At the brim of the lesser pelvis (as it crosses the common iliac artery)
  3. At the site of crossing of the ureter by ductus deferens or broad ligament of the uterus.
  4. Vesico-ureteric junction
  5. At its opening in the lateral angle of the trigone

These are regarded as surgical constrictions of the ureter. However, the anatomical constrictions are only three of them (1, 2, and 4).

questions.text: You are a part of a water purification program, where you are explaining chlorine as a disinfectant. Which among the following is the most effective form of chlorine for water disinfection?
questions.solution:
Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine for water disinfection.

Action of chlorine:

When chlorine is added to water, there is the formation of hydrochloric acid (HCl) and hypochlorous acids (HOCl), as follows.

H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl

The hydrochloric acid is neutralized by the alkalinity of the water.

The hypochlorous acid (HOCl) ionizes to form hydrogen ions (H+) and hypochlorite ions (OCl-), as follows:

HOCl → H+ + OCl-

The disinfecting action of chlorine is mainly due to hypochlorous acid, which is 70-80 times more effective than the hypochlorite ions.

The formation of hypochlorous acid is predominant, when the pH of the water is around 7. If the pH exceeds 8.5, chlorine is unreliable as a disinfectant, as about 90% of the hypochlorous acid that is formed gets ionized to hypochlorite ions.

Most waters have a pH between 6 to 7.5.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male who is a known case of type 2 DM having a BMI of 36 kg/m2 is enquiring regarding bariatric procedures. Which of the following bariatric procedures would you tell him, has the lowest rate of diabetes remission?
questions.solution:
Gastric banding shows the lowest rate of diabetes remission among the given procedures.

The 3-year percentage of diabetes remission for gastric banding is 20 %. 

Different Bariatric surgeries and their Outcomes :

  3 yr % Diabetes remission 3 year % Excess Weight Loss (EWL) Protein/Calorie Malabsorption
Gastric band 20%

40 -50 %

 No
Gastric bypass 50% 50 - 60 % No
Sleeve gastrectomy 50% 60 - 70 % No
Biliopancreatic diversion / Duodenal switch  80% 70 -80 % Yes 
  

Purely malabsorptive procedures, Biliopancreatic division (BPD) and Duodenal switch (DS), cause maximum weight loss.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man develops pulmonary tuberculosis and is started on ATT. After a year, he develops a sudden decrease in vision of both eyes. On examination, vision in both eyes is 3/60. He finds it difficult to read Ishihara’s chart. He also has pain while moving his eyeballs. On fundus examination, the discs and vessels were normal. What is the most probable drug which can be implicated in this complication?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of retrobulbar neuritis, as the patient has a sudden deterioration in his vision, painful extraocular movements, and poor color discrimination. The antitubercular drug, ethambutol can cause retrobulbar neuritis and red-green color blindness.

Optic neuritis resulting in decreased visual acuity and loss of ability to differentiate red from green is the most serious adverse effect of ethambutol. It is a dose-dependent adverse effect that can be unilateral or bilateral. The intensity of the visual difficulty is related to the duration of therapy.

Tests of visual acuity and red-green discrimination before the start of therapy and periodically thereafter are recommended.

Ethambutol is used for the treatment of tuberculosis, disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex, and Mycobacterium kansasii infection. It inhibits arabinosyl transferase III, thereby disrupting the transfer of arabinose into arabinogalactan biosynthesis. This disrupts the assembly of the mycobacterial cell wall. Resistance occurs due to mutations in the embB gene.

Since 80% of the drug is eliminated through the kidney unchanged, its dosing should be decreased in renal failure to avoid toxicity. Ethambutol should be given 15-25 mg/kg three times a week, instead of daily in patients with renal failure.

Other side effects are pruritus, joint pain, GI upset, abdominal pain, malaise, headache, dizziness, mental confusion, disorientation, possible hallucinations, and decreased renal excretion of uric acid.

Related Pearl: Key points on the first line drugs used in the treatment of TB

Drugs Isoniazid Rifamycins Pyrazinamide Ethambutol
Mechanism of action

Bactericidal

Blocks mycolic acid synthesis.

Bactericidal (maximum)

Inhibition of RNA polymerase, leading to the inhibition of RNA synthesis.

Bactericidal

Inhibition of fatty acid synthase-I, leading to the inhibition of the cell membrane.

Bacteriostatic

Inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, leading to a reduction in arabinogalactan needed for the cell wall.
Location of Mycobacteria Intracellular +  Extracellular Intracellular +  Extracellular  Intracellular  Extracellular
Metabolism Liver  Liver (maximum)  Liver  Kidney
Unique side effects

Shoulder hand syndrome and CNS side effects.

 Orange urine, sweat, and tears. Flu-like symptoms with intermittent dosing.

The most hepatotoxic drug. It also causes hyperuricemia.

Optic neuritis and hence, not preferred in children.
Mechanism of resistance

Kat G mutation- the most severe form of resistance.

Inh a gene overexpression-  confers cross-resistance with ethionamide.

Mutation in rpoB- the gene coding for the β subunit of RNA polymerase.

 Mutation of the Pnca gene.

Mutations in the embB gene.

questions.text: All of the following are true about expert witness except:

choices.text: Witness Bata may be paid to Doctors even in Criminal Cases
Has the knowledge to draw conclusions from the facts available

questions.solution:
The first-hand knowledge Rule is applicable to common witness, not an expert witness.

A common witness is a person who gives evidence about the facts observed or perceived by him based on the first-hand knowledge rule (only facts perceived by him).

Section 45 of the Indian Evidence Act defines an expert witness. An expert witness is one who has acquired special knowledge, skill or experience in any science, art, subject, or profession. He could have acquired such knowledge by practice, observation, or careful studies.

If the witness is a doctor in private practice, he may request the court for conveyance charges and daily allowance according to the Government rules(even in criminal cases). As per law (Section 312 CrPC), he or she will be paid the travel allowances (TA) by the court. This is referred to as "Witness Bata".

The chemical examiner is also an expert witness

Also note:

A hostile witness is a person who is supposed to have some interest or motive for concealing a part of the truth or for giving completely false evidence.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman has the following flow pattern of umbilical arteries on a doppler. What does this pattern indicate?
questions.solution:
The given image represents a reversal of end-diastolic flow in the umbilical arteries, which is seen in impending intrauterine death.

Abnormal flow patterns in the umbilical artery:

  • Reduced End diastolic flow indicate uteroplacental insufficiency
  • Absent End diastolic flow indicate fetal compromise
  • Reverse end diastolic flow indicate impending doom of fetal death

The below image shows various Doppler velocity waveforms.

A: Normal waveform with normal systole to diastolic ration (normal diastolic flow )

B: Absence of end diastolic flow seen in IUGR.

C: Reversal of end diastolic flow seen in impending IUD .

questions.text: A factory involved in the manufacturing of certain goods is associated with the occupational hazard of exposure to lead. You are deployed as a factory medical officer to conduct pre-placement examinations for workers, before confirming their employment. Which of the following conditions would you deem as undesirable for work in this factory?
questions.solution:
Workers with peptic ulcers are deemed undesirable for work in factories that have the occupational hazard of lead exposure.

A pre-placement examination is done at the time of employment. The examination includes:

  • Worker's medical, family, occupational and social history.
  • Thorough physical examination
  • Biological and radiological examination (Ex: Blood and urine examination, chest X-ray, ECG, etc.)

The following is the list of some occupations associated with exposure to a hazardous substance, in which, it is risky to employ workers with certain undesirable conditions.

Hazard Undesirable conditions
Lead

Anemia. hypertension, nephritis, peptic ulcer
Dyes

Asthma; skin, bladder, and kidney diseases; precancerous lesions

Solvents

Liver and kidney disease, dermatitis, alcoholism

Silica

Healed or active tuberculosis of lungs, chronic lung disease

Radium and X-rays

 Signs of ill-health, especially any blood disease.

questions.text: You observe that the arms of an infant extend spontaneously when the senior resident tries to elicit the following reflex by holding the infant’s trunk and then suddenly lowering the infant as if he or she were falling. All the following options regarding this reflex are true, except ______.

choices.text: This reflex is  a prerequisite to walking.
This reflex starts to appear by 7–8 months of age.
This reflex disappears by 18 months of postnatal period.

questions.solution:
The reflex being elicited in the given scenario is the parachute reflex, and this reflex remains throughout life.

The parachute reflex can be evoked by holding the infant's trunk and then suddenly lowering it as if it were falling. This will cause the infant's arms to extend in order to break the fall. Thus, it is a prerequisite for walking. The onset of this reflex is at 7-8 months of age; it fully develops by 10-11 months and persists for life. 

The parachute reflex is a primitive reflex. Primitive reflexes appear and disappear at specific times during a child's development. Any persistence or absence of these reflexes is significant for central nervous system dysfunction.

Related Pearl: Timeline for primitive reflexes

32 weeks of gestation
2-3 months postnatal
Rooting
32 weeks of gestation

Less prominent after 1 month postnatal
Moro

37 weeks of gestation
5-6 months postnatal
Tonic neck
35 weeks of gestation
1 month postnatal
3-4 months postnatal
Parachute

10-11 months postnatal
Remains throughout life

 

According to Ghai Essential Paediatrics, 9th edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 4 months of age. According to Nelson Paediatrics, 21st edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 6 months of age. Hence, the answer depends on the reference chosen by the examiner.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male was brought to the hospital with sudden onset abdominal pain and vomiting. During clinical examination, maximum tenderness was present over McBurney's point. Which of the following imagining studies is highly effective as well as accurate in diagnosing the given condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of acute abdominal pain with maximal tenderness over McBurney's point is suggestive of acute appendicitis. A CT scan is the most effective and accurate imaging modality used to diagnose this condition.

The diagnosis of appendicitis on CT is based on the appearance of a thickened, inflamed appendix with surrounding “stranding” indicative of inflammation. The thickened inflamed wall and mural enhancement give an appearance known as a target sign. CT scans are operator-independent and they are easy to interpret.

Ultrasound provides the advantage of avoiding ionizing radiation but it is highly operator dependent. In pediatric and pregnant patients, ultrasound can be preferred to avoid the risk of radiation exposure. MRI is typically reserved for use in pregnant patients.

Acute appendicitis typically presents with abdominal pain that is initially difficult to localize. This pain arises from discomfort in the midgut due to inflammation and blockage of the appendix. It often begins in the periumbilical region and is accompanied by loss of appetite, feelings of nausea, and typically one or two instances of vomiting that occur after the pain starts. Loss of appetite is a consistent and helpful symptom, especially in children who almost always experience vomiting.

The tenderness associated with acute appendicitis is located at a point called McBurney point, which is positioned one-third the distance between the anterior superior iliac spine and the umbilicus. Pointing sign, Rovsing's sign, Psoas sign, and Obturator sign are some of the signs to be elicited in a patient with appendicitis.

The Alvarado scoring system is the clinical scoring system used in the diagnosis of appendicitis. 

Related Pearl: Alvarado Scoring System

Findings

Points

Migratory right iliac fossa pain

1

Anorexia

1

Nausea / vomiting

1

Tenderness in right iiliac fossa

2

Rebound tenderness right iliac fossa

1

Elevated temperature ≥ 37.3°C

1

Leukocytosis ≥ 10⨯109 cells/L

2

Shift to the left of neutrophils

1

 

A score of 4-5 or below rules out the diagnosis of acute appendicitis in children, and in adults, a score of 8-9 or higher rules in the diagnosis.

If the score is 4-6, an an adjunctive CT scan would be recommended to confirm the diagnosis.

If the score is 7 or higher, surgery is recommended.

Related Pearl: Signs in appendicitis

Sign

Seen in

Pain on internal rotation of hip

Pelvic appendicitis

Ilio-Psoas sign

Pain on extension of hip

Retrocaecal appendicitis

Aaron sign

Pain or pressure in epigastrium or anterior chest with persistent firm pressure applied to McBurney’s point

Acute appendicitis

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic lady presents to the casualty with abdominal pain and vomiting. Her RBS is 400mg/dl and urine dipstick for ketones is positive. Her ABG shows pH-7.2, PaCO2 - 24mmHg, HCO3- 12mEq/L. Which of the following is true regarding her respiration?

choices.text: Increase in H+ concentration inhibits medullary chemoreceptors
Decrease in pH stimulates medullary chemoreceptors
Decrease in PaCO2 inhibits medullary chemoreceptors

questions.solution:
The given case scenario is of a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis. Acidosis (decrease in pH) causes stimulation of medullary chemoreceptors and in turn causes hyperventilation.

Points in history suggestive of DKA (Diabetic ketoacidosis) - increased blood sugar, ketonuria (serum assays are preferred), clinical features of vomiting and pain abdomen. 

ABG points towards acidosis (pH < 7.35) of metabolic origin ( HCO3- is decreased). 

In this case, decreased pH (due to excess of H+ ions), stimulates the central chemoreceptors. This causes increase in ventilation and CO2 washout. This typical respiration is known as Kussmaul's respiration.

Since alveloar PaCo2 is more than the atmospheric PaCO2, increase in the ventilation rate, will decrease the PaCO2 in alveolus and in turn in blood.

Related Pearl: Central and Peripheral Chemoreceptors

  Central chemoreceptor Peripheral chemoreceptor
Location Ventral aspect of medulla Carotid bodies (Bifurcation of common carotid artery) and aortic bodies (Arch of aorta)
Stimulus Arterial PCO2 and H+ ions (Sensitive to changes in arterial PCo2 but stimulus is H+ ions in CSF) Arterial PO2 (dissolved form), PCO2 and H+ ions

questions.text: A 45-year-old man was posted for open inguinal hernia repair. He is a known hypertensive for the past 6 years and is poorly controlled on medications. Which of the following muscle relaxant can exacerbate hypertension in this patient?
questions.solution:
Pancuronium can exacerbate hypertension in poorly controlled patients by inducing vagal blockade and neural release of catecholamine leading to sympathetic stimulation.

For the same reason, large bolus doses of pancuronium are to be cautiously used in patients with coronary artery disease, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and aortic stenosis.

Pancuronium is a steroidal non-depolarizing muscle relaxant. It is metabolized in the liver and primarily excreted through the kidney.

In predisposed individuals, it causes increased atrioventricular conduction and catecholamines release resulting in ventricular arrhythmia. Individuals who are hypersensitive to bromide can exhibit allergic reactions to pancuronium. 

Other options:

Option B- Atracuronium causes hypotension due to a drop in systemic vascular resistance.

Option C- Vecuronium is devoid of significant cardiovascular effects.

Option D- Rocuronium is cardio stable and shows no changes in heart rate and blood pressure.

Related Pearl: High yield in muscle relaxants

  • Shortest acting non-depolarizing muscle relaxant:
    • Gantacurium (Not FDA approved)
    • Mivacurium: 12-20 minutes. (FDA approved)
  • Shortest acting depolarizing muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine (3-6 minutes)
  • Muscle relaxant having the maximum duration of action: Doxacurium (benzylisoquinoline) > Pancuronium (Aminosteroid)
  • Muscle relaxant causing pain on IV injection site: Rocuronium
  • Muscle relaxant which crosses placenta: Gallamine
  • Muscle relaxant acting directly on muscle: Dantrolene
  • Muscle relaxants with central action: benzodiazepine, mephenesin, baclofen, carisoprodol, metaxalone
  • Muscle relaxant and mode of clearance:
    • Hepatic clearance: Pancuronium, rapacuronium and vecuronium
    • Biliary clearance: Vecuronium and rocuronium
    • Renal clearance: Doxacurium, pancuronium, vecuronium, and pipecuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with sympathetic stimulation:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with vagolytic activity:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
    • Rocuronium (mild)

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium
  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)
    • Atracurium
    • Cisatracurium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)
    • Pancuronium
    • Doxacurium
    • Pipecuronium

questions.text: The given area of the anterior surface of the left kidney is related to :
questions.solution:
The given area on the anterior surface of the left kidney is related to the jejunum.

 The anterior relations of the right kidney include:

  • Right suprarenal gland
  • Second/descending part of the duodenum
  • Liver
  • Hepatic flexure of the colon
  • Small intestine

The anterior relations of the left kidney include:

  • Left suprarenal gland 
  • Stomach
  • Pancreas
  • Jejunum
  • Spleen
  • Splenic flexure and the beginning of the descending colon

The posterior relations of the kidneys are as follows:

  • Vessels (1): Subcostal vessels
  • Ligaments (2): Medial and Lateral Arcuate ligaments
  • Nerves (3): Subcostal, Iliohypogastric, and Ilioinguinal nerves
  • Muscles (4): Diaphragm, Psoas major, Quadratus lumborum, and Transverses abdominis.
  • The right kidney is related to the 12th rib and the left kidney is related to the 11th and 12th ribs

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman diagnosed with unruptured tubal pregnancy was referred to you for further management. The presence of all the following features indicates considering medical management over surgery in this patient except______

choices.text: TVS showing normal fetal cardiac activity

questions.solution:
All the above features indicate considering medical management over surgery except the presence of fetal cardiac activity on trans vaginal sonography, which is an indication for surgical management.

Indications for medical management of unruptured ectopic pregnancy:

  • Gestation sac size <4 cm
  • Serum beta HCG levels should be <3000 IU/L
  • No signs of fetal cardiac activity / absent fetal heart rate (FHR)
  • Patient should be hemodynamically stable

Indications for surgical management

  • Cases not fulfilling the criteria of medical therapy.
  • Cases where beta-hCG levels are not decreasing despite medical therapy.
  • Presence of fetal cardiac activity

Note:

Medical management: The drugs commonly used for are methotrexate, potassium chloride, prostaglandin(PGF-2alpha), hyperosmolar glucose, or actinomycin. 

Expectant management means that only observation is done hoping for spontaneous resolution.

Monitoring is done by measuring serum beta-hCG on Day 4 and Day 7. When the decline in hCG between D4 and D7 is greater than or equal to 15%, the patient is followed up weekly with serum hCG until hCG less than 10 mIU/mL. If the decline is less than 15%, the second dose of methotrexate is given on Day 7.

questions.text: A patient with a history of humerus fracture treated with open reduction and internal fixation 9 months back presents to the OPD with complaints of persistent pain at the fracture site. On examination, there was mobility at the fracture site. An X-ray was performed and is given below. Bone scan revealed cold spots. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of open reduction and internal fixation for a humerus fracture with the X-ray showing a persistent fracture line and cold spots on the bone scan is suggestive of atrophic nonunion.

Atrophic nonunion is characterized by the presence of a persistent fracture line with no callus formation despite adequate fixation at the fracture site. This lack of healing response can be due to open fracture injuries, subsequent surgical treatment, or host factors like diabetes, smoking, etc. Clinical features in a case of nonunion include persistent pain at the fracture site, pain on stressing the fracture, and mobility at the fracture site. A bone scan is used to differentiate atrophic nonunion from oligotrophic nonunion. Bone scan shows hot spots in oligotrophic nonunion whereas it shows cold spots in atrophic nonunion. Management includes autologous bone grafting or bone morphogenic protein to stimulate fracture healing.

Based on the biological activity at the fracture site, non-union can be classified as:

  • Atrophic nonunion: Poor healing response with no callus formation due to little or no active bone-forming cells at the fracture site. The blood supply is typically poor. On radiography, there is an absence of bone reaction.
  • Oligotrophic nonunion: There is minimal callus formation, often due to inadequate approximation of fracture surfaces. On radiography, there is minimal bone healing reaction. It is differentiated from an atrophic nonunion by a bone scan. There will be increased uptake in oligotrophic nonunion, but an atrophic nonunion would be relatively cold on the bone scan.
  • Hypertrophic nonunion: These fractures have an adequate healing response and good vascularity. There is a lack of adequate stability for the union to occur. On radiography, there is usually abundant callus formation that doesn't bridge the fracture site. It can occur after initial nonoperative management or in some cases after initial operative management where there was inadequate stabilization.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with an ovarian tumor. Histopathological examination of tumor specimen reveals sheets of mucin-producing signet ring cells as seen below.  Identify the true statement regarding this ovarian tumor.

choices.text: Normal shape of ovary is retained
Ovary is attached to nearby viscera and becomes immobile

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with histopathology showing signet ring cells is suggestive of Krukenberg tumor and in this ovarian tumor, the normal shape of the ovary is retained.

Krukenberg tumor: These are secondary growth in the ovary and most often arise from a primary carcinoma of the stomach (70%), large bowel (15%), and breast (6%).

Features:

  • Usually bilateral (Option D)
  • Have a smooth surface
  • They retain the shape of the normal ovary.
  • There is no tendency to form adhesions with neighboring viscera and they are freely movable in the pelvis. (Option C)
  • There is no infiltration through the capsule (Option A)
  • Have a waxy consistency

Histologically, Numerous signet-ring cells with pale cytoplasm are seen.

questions.text: A 35 -year-old male presented with a chronic non-healing ulcer over the leg. He gives a history of gall stones, attacks of severe pain in the digits of hands and feet. His medical records reveal he has had an episode of salmonella osteomyelitis. His peripheral smear is shown in the figure. What is the most likely underlying defect?

choices.text: Nonsense mutation causing premature termination of β-globin gene translation
Point mutation in the sixth codon of β-globin

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with repeated vaso-occlusive crises, gall stones, and salmonella osteomyelitis, and the peripheral smear showing sickle cells, target cells, and polychromasia are suggestive of sickle cell anemia. Sickle cell disease is caused by a point mutation in the sixth codon of β-globin that leads to the replacement of a glutamate residue with a valine residue.

HbS molecules stack into polymers when deoxygenated. With continued deoxygenation HbS molecules assemble into long needle-like fibers within red cells, producing a distorted sickle or holly-leaf shape. Polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin, leading to red cell distortion, hemolytic anemia, microvascular obstruction, and ischemic tissue damage.

Peripheral blood smear demonstrates -  Irreversibly sickled cells, reticulocytosis, and target cells, which result from red cell dehydration with Howell-Jolly bodies.

The major pathologic manifestation is chronic hemolysis, microvascular occlusions, and tissue damage. Increased breakdown of hemoglobin is responsible for pigment gallstones and hyperbilirubinemia. Splenomegaly can be seen in early childhood, but fibrosis and progressive shrinkage of the spleen may occur in adolescence known as autosplenectomy. Priapism affects up to 45% of males. Leg ulcers may also be seen. Stroke and retinopathy leading to loss of visual acuity and even blindness.

Vaso-occlusive crises, or pain crises are characterized by episodes of hypoxic injury and infarction that cause severe pain in the affected region, hand-foot syndrome, or dactylitis. Osteomyelitis in a sickle cell anemia patient is commonly caused by Salmonella and it most likely affects the diaphysis of bones. Acute chest syndrome is a vaso-occlusive crisis involving the lungs with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates. Sequestration crises is seen in children with intact spleens. Massive entrapment of sickle red cells leads to rapid splenic enlargement, hypovolemia, and sometimes shock. Aplastic crises occur due to the infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient arrest of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia.

Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms is another risk due to altered splenic function. Pneumococcus and Haemophilus influenzae septicemia and meningitis are common, particularly in children, but can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics. Hemoglobin electrophoresis is also used to demonstrate the presence of HbS.

Other options:

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a disease that results from acquired mutations in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A gene (PIGA), which is required for the synthesis of phosphatidylinositol glycan (PIG). These cells lack the ability to synthesize proteins that limit the activity of complement. As a result, they are sensitive to lysis by the complement C5b-C9 membrane attack complex

Hereditary spherocytosis is caused by mutations that most frequently involve ankyrin, band 3, or spectrin (i.e. inherited defects in the membrane skeleton).

A nonsense mutation is a point mutation in a sequence of DNA that results in a premature stop codon. For example, a point mutation affecting the codon for glutamine (CAG) creates a stop codon (UAG) if U is substituted for C. This change leads to premature termination of β-globin gene translation, and the short peptide that is produced is rapidly degraded. The resulting deficiency of β-globin chains can give rise to a severe form of anemia called β0 thalassemia.

questions.text: A teenager presents with fever, malaise, skin rash and hepatomegaly. He is diagnosed with a rickettsial infection and the vector implicated in the disease is shown below. The vector can transmit all of the following diseases except:
questions.solution:
The vector shown in the image is a louse. It can transmit all diseases except endemic typhus. The vector for endemic typhus is rat flea. 

The table below shows diseases transmitted by the louse, and the causative agent:

Disease transmitted by louse   Causative agent
Epidemic typhus Rickettssia prowazeki
Relapsing fever Borrelia recurrentis
Trench fever Bartonella quintana
Pediculosis Infestation with the louse

Rickettsial infections are classified based on clinical features and epidemiology as follows:

Group

Zoonotic disease

 Vector
Typhus group  

Epidemic typhus

 Louse

Murine typhus

Flea

Scrub typhus

 Mite
Spotted fever group  

Indian tick typhus

Tick

Rocky Mountain spotted fever

 Tick

Rickettsialpox

 Mite
Others 

Q fever 

 -
Trench fever Louse

Rickettsial infections present with fever, malaise, headache, prostration, hepatosplenomegaly and a skin rash. Q fever does not have skin lesions. Tetracycline is the drug of choice for all rickettsial infections. 

Related Pearl: Lice

  • There are 3 kinds of lice. They are:
    • Head lice (Pediculus capitis)
    • Body lice (Pediculus corporis)
    • Crab louse (pubic louse – Phthirus pubis).
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a pair of antennae, three pairs of legs attached to the thorax, and a segmented abdomen.
  • The stages in their life cycle are eggs (nits), larva (nymph), and the adult, which live for 30 to 50 days.
  • They are spread by direct or indirect contact.
  • They are vectors for epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, and pediculosis.
  • Insecticidal control of lice is mainly by malathion in the form of lotion or powder.
  • There are reports of resistance to DDT and HCH.
  • Personal hygiene is of utmost importance to prevent infestation.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

questions.text:
In case of electric burns, who amongst the following will have the most fatal result?
  1. A person touching a 240 volt conductor while standing on a carpeted wooden floor upstairs
  2. A person touching the neutral and live wires with the same finger a few centimetres apart while standing on a carpeted wooden floor upstairs
  3. A person touching a 240 volt conductor with one hand while standing on a carpeted wooden floor upstairs and opening a water pipe with the other hand
  4. A person touching a 240 volt conductor with right hand while standing with damp shoes on a wet concrete floor
questions.solution:
A person touching a 240-volt conductor while standing with damp shoes on a wet concrete floor will have the most fatal result.

In this case, appreciable current will pass from hand to feet. It has been claimed that the most dangerous current path is contacted with the right hand and exit through the left foot, as this causes the maximum (up to 8.5 percent) of the total body current to flow through the heart. 

 

Electric injury -

The current enters at one point and then leaves the body at an exit point, usually to the earth or the neutral conductor of the electricity supply.  

It tends to take the shortest route between entry and best exit, irrespective of the varying conductivity of different internal tissues.

When a hand is brought into contact with a live conductor, and the body is earthed either through the feet or the opposite hand, the most common passage of current is across the heart.

It has been claimed that the most dangerous current path is contacted with the right hand and exit through the left foot, as this causes the maximum (up to 8.5 percent) of the total body current to flow through the heart when compared with head to feet (up to 5.9 percent), left hand to feet (up to 5.1 percent), hand to hand (up to 4.4 percent) or foot to foot (up to 0.4 percent)

Direct current (d.c.) is less dangerous than alternating current (a.c.).

Most deaths from electricity are from cardiac arrhythmias, usually, ventricular fibrillation ending in cardiac arrest.

It is commonly said that tolerance can be gained to electric shock and that professional electricians often work on live 240 V conductors with impunity.

In case of the person touching a 240-volt conductor while standing on a carpeted wooden floor upstairs, the poor earth will allow only a small current to flow and all that may be suffered is a painful muscular spasm.

The person touching the neutral and live wires with the same finger a few centimeters apart may suffer from a severe local burn but no danger to life.

questions.text: An international traveler, who tested COVID-19 positive, was advised home quarantine. Which of the following biomedical waste must not be disposed of in a yellow bag?

choices.text: Gloves used by the family in contact with patient
Triple layered mask used by the patient

questions.solution:
Gloves used by the family in contact with the patient should not be discarded in the yellow bag. They must be kept in a paper bag for 72 hours before discarding them with general waste.

For COVID-19 positive patients in home quarantine, the used masks, tissues, swabs, syringes, medicine must be considered as biomedical waste. They must be disposed of in yellow bag.

Related Pearl: Biomedical Waste (BMW) Management -COVID 19

In addition to the current BMW Management rules, the following measures are proposed

  • To report opening/operation of COVID 19 Ward/ICU/Lab/Collection Centre to SPCB (State Pollution Control Board) and CBWTF (Common Biomedical Waste Treatment Facility) in that area
  • Dedicated sanitation workers deputed only to collect COVID 19 BMW
  • It is mandatory for all BMW bags and containers from COVID 19 areas to carry "COVID 19 WASTE" label
  • Keep separate colour coded bins with foot operated lids
  • The inner and outer surfaces of these containers must be disinfected daily with 1% sodium hypochlorite solution
  • To ensure no leaks, double layers (2 bags) are used
COLOUR OF THE BIN PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT(PPE) OTHER WASTE
Red Bin
  • Goggles
  • Face shield 
  • Splash-proof apron
  • Plastic coverall
  • Hazmat suit
  • Nitrile gloves
  • Used gloves

Laboratory waste

  • Pre-treated viral transport media
  • Plastic vials and cryovials
  • Vacutainers
  • Eppendorf tubes
  • Pipette tips
Yellow Bin
  • Used mask(triple layer mask, N95 mask)
  • Head cover/Cap, Shoe cover
  • Disposable linen gown 
  • Non-plastic/Semi-plastic coverall

 

  • Diapers with feces of immobile COVID 19 patients

questions.text: Which of the following is the largest branch of the artery marked in the image as 'X'?
questions.solution:
The marked vessel is the vertebral artery. The posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) is its largest branch.

The vertebral artery is a branch of the first part of the subclavian artery. It enters the skull through the foramen magnum and terminates by joining the vertebral artery on the opposite side forming the basilar artery. The branches of the cranial portion of the vertebral artery are:

  • Meningeal branches - supplying dura of posterior cranial fossa
  • Posterior spinal arteries - supply posterior one-third of the spinal cord
  • Anterior spinal arteries - supply the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) - the largest branch. It supplies the lateral part of the medulla, the cerebellar hemisphere, and choroid plexus of the fourth ventricle.
  • Medullary branches - supplying the medulla

Clinical importance - A disruption in blood supply in the PICA leads to lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: A barking dog position will not be suitable for which of the following procedures?
questions.solution:
The barking-dog position is a surgical position in which the head is elevated by 10–15 cm by placing a pillow under the occiput, the neck is flexed on the thorax and the head is extended on the atlantooccipital joint. This position is used during laryngoscopy, bronchoscopy, and esophagoscopy.

The purpose of this position is to attain the axes of the mouth, pharynx, and esophagus in a straight line to pass the rigid tube easily.

 

The Barking Dog Position

For the flexible fibreoptic oesophagoscopy, the patient lies in the left lateral position and the fibrescope is passed through a plastic mouth prop

questions.text: The major action of the muscle marked as "X" in the diagram below is:
questions.solution:
The muscle marked "X" in the above image is the Teres minor as it is related between infraspinatus and Teres major muscles. Its action is to laterally rotate the humerus.

Teres minor arises from the dorsal surface of the axillary border of the scapula for the upper two-thirds of its extent, and from two aponeurotic laminae, one of which separates it from the infraspinatus muscle, the other from the teres major muscle. It inserts on the inferior facet of the greater tubercle of the humerus. It laterally rotates the humerus and is a component of the rotator cuff.

Muscle Action
Deltoid Major abductor of arm
Infraspinatus Rotator cuff muscle; lateral rotation of the arm
Teres Minor Rotator cuff muscle; lateral rotation of the arm
Teres major Medial rotation and extension of the arm
The long head of triceps brachii  Extension of the forearm; accessory adductor and extensor of the arm 
 Trapezius  Elevates the scapula; rotates the scapula during abduction of humerus above horizontal; middle fibres retract scapula; lower fibres depress scapula
Latissimus dorsi  Extends, adducts, and medially rotates humerus

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic male patient presented with arthralgia and skin pigmentation. On examination, he was found to have hepatomegaly, arthropathy involving small joints, excessive skin pigmentation with characteristic slate-grey hue, and hypogonadism. What will be the best treatment for this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to hemochromatosis, and the best treatment for this iron-overload state is phlebotomy. One 500-mL unit of blood contains 200–250 mg of iron. Iron removal can be accomplished by weekly or twice-weekly phlebotomy of 500 mL.

With repeated phlebotomy, the following changes occur:

  • Liver decreases in size
  • Liver function improves
  • Hepatic fibrosis may decrease, but established cirrhosis is irreversible
  • Pigmentation of skin decreases
  • Cardiac failure may be reversed
  • Diabetes also improves in about 40% of patients
  • There is little or no effect of arthropathy and hypogonadism. In some cases, arthropathy may even progress, despite therapy.

The goal is to reduce the serum ferritin levels to 50–100 ng/mL. Once the goal is reached, the phlebotomies may be done at appropriate intervals (usually, 3-4 times a year), required to maintain the serum ferritin levels at that level. 

Hemochromatosis is an autosomal recessive disease caused due to mutation in the HFE gene on chromosome 6. It is tightly linked to the HLA-A locus on chromosome 6p.

Clinical manifestations are initially non-specific like lethargy, arthralgia, skin pigmentation, and features of diabetes mellitus. The liver is the first organ to be affected, resulting in hepatomegaly, ascites, and spider angiomas. Other systems are also affected, leading to cardiac arrhythmias, congestive cardiac failure, and testicular atrophy. 

Pathogenesis:

The mutated HFE gene on chromosome 6p causes abnormally low levels of hepcidin, which is a principal iron regulatory hormone. This, in turn, leads to increased iron absorption from the duodenum. The excessively absorbed iron is primarily deposited in the parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas; heart; joints; and endocrine organs.

Other features:

  • Hemochromatosis can also be acquired from iron overload due to hemolytic anemia and transfusions.
  • It is associated with an increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is the most common manifestation of hemochromatosis. Hemochromatosis can also produce restrictive cardiomyopathy but it is less common as compared to DCM.

Diagnosis: Clinical features, family history, and laboratory investigations directed at diagnosing an increase in total body iron stores using serum iron, transferrin saturation, and serum ferritin levels. Liver biopsy with measurement of the iron concentration and calculation of the hepatic iron index. MRI of the liver is also indicated.

Other options:

Option B- Deferoxamine is a chelating agent, which removes 10–20 mg of iron per day when given parenterally. It is used in cases of severe iron load or when phlebotomy is not well-tolerated.

Options A and D- Trientine and D-penicillamine are chelating agents that bind to copper and are used in the treatment of Wilson's disease.

Related Pearl: HLA association with diseases
