questions.text: Identify the virus in the transmission cycle shown in the given image:
questions.solution:
The transmission cycle of the Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus is shown in the image. 

Japanese encephalitis follows bird-arthropod-human transmission. Humans are the dead-end hosts, pigs are the amplifier hosts, and herons act as reservoir hosts. The disease is transmitted by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India)

Clinical features include high fever, headache, and vomiting. Signs of encephalitis such as convulsions, neck rigidity, and altered sensorium appear after 1-6 days. Measures like mosquito control, and locating piggeries away from houses can be done.

Inactivated vero cell culture-derived SA-14-14-2 vaccine is approved for use in India. JE vaccine is given in two doses- at 9-12 months of age and at 16-24 months of age in areas that are endemic to the disease, according to the National Immunization Schedule. 

Other options:

Option-A: Nipah virus is a zoonotic virus, which is transmitted from pigs to humans. Fruit bats are the natural hosts. It causes severe encephalitis with high mortality. 

The image given below depicts the life cycle of the Nipah virus:

 

Option B: Ebola virus belongs to the family Filoviridae and is transmitted by bats. Human-to-human transmission through blood or body fluids can occur. It causes fever, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and hemorrhage. 

The image below shows the lifecycle of the ebola virus:

 

Option D: Zika virus is transmitted to human beings by the bite of an infected Aedes mosquito. It can also be transmitted trans-placentally, causing microcephaly and other severe fetal brain defects.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman receiving cyclosporin A after renal transplantation develops multiple and bilateral breast lumps that regress after cessation of treatment. ​The biopsy image is given below. Which of the following is incorrect regarding her condition?

choices.text: It is the most common benign breast tumor in females.
Overexpression of the transcription factor HOXB13 is frequently seen.
The epithelial component is hormonally responsive.

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this scenario is a fibroadenoma. Two-thirds of fibroadenomas harbor driver mutations in MED12 while overexpression of the transcription factor HOXB13 is associated with a severalfold increase in risk of developing adenocarcinoma of the prostate.

Fibroadenomas are the most common benign tumor of the female breast. They are frequently multiple and bilateral and usually occur in women<30 years of age. The epithelial component is hormonally responsive and is responsible for the increase in size during lactational changes or during pregnancy.

Almost half the women receiving cyclosporin A after renal transplantation develop multiple and bilateral fibroadenomas that regress after cessation of treatment.

Complex fibroadenomas are grouped with “proliferative changes without atypia” and are associated with a 1.5-2-times increased risk of subsequent cancer. Complex fibroadenomas contain cysts larger than 0.3 cm, sclerosing adenosis, epithelial calcifications, or papillary apocrine change.

Interesting fact: Fibroadenomas are sometimes called "Breast mouse" due to their high mobility within the breast.

Histological image of Fibroadenoma showing proliferation of ducts arranged in intracanalicular (compressed) and pericanalicular pattern surrounded by fibromyxoid stroma

According to recent studies,two-thirds of fibroadenomas harbor driver mutations in MED12. The pathogenesis of the remainder is uncertain.

questions.text: While examining a patient diagnosed with Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia, it was found that the neoplasia has metastasized to the adnexa, vagina, and also to the broad ligament but not other structures.  According to FIGO staging, the above case can be staged as?
questions.solution:
This case will be classified as stage-II Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia(GTN).

Stage 2 includes GTN, which extends outside the uterus but is limited to the genital structures i.e adnexa, vagina, broad ligament.

International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) Staging for GTN is as follows:
Stage I - Disease confined to the uterus

Stage II - GTN extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structures    

(adnexa, vagina, broad ligament)
Stage III - GTN extends to the lungs, with or without known genital tract involvement
Stage IV - All other metastatic sites

Related Pearl: Risk factors and FIGO staging of Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia

Risk factors

  • Older age
  • β-hCG levels > 100,000 mIU/mL
  • Uterine size that is large-forgestational age
  • Theca-lutein cysts > 6 cm
  • Slow decline in β-hCG levels
  • Postevacuation uterine sonographic surveillance showing myometrial nodules or hypervascularity may be a predictor of subsequent neoplasia.

FIGO staging:

Stage I Disease confined to the uterus
Stage II GTD extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structure
Stage III Lung metastasis with or without genital tract involvement
Stage IV Other metastasis

questions.text: A patient is managed with an implant for a tibial fracture 2 years back. He is now diagnosed with chronic osteomyelitis.  Which is the commonest organism to cause chronic osteomyelitis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most common causative agent of chronic osteomyelitis in the presence of surgical implants is staphylococcus epidermidis.

The most common organism involved in acute hematogenous osteomyelitis is staphylococcus aureus.

Clinical features include:

  • Fever, Pain, and swelling are seen in acute exacerbation of chronic osteomyelitis.
  • In long-standing cases, the tissue gets thickened and folded inwards where a scar or a sinus get adheres to the underlying bone.
  • Presence of seropurulent discharge and skin excoriation surrounding it.

Radiological features include:

  • Sequestrum is a piece of devitalized bone that has been separated from its surrounding bone during the process of necrosis.
  • Involucrum is the thick sheath of periosteal new bone that surrounds the sequestrum. 
  • Cloacae are openings in the involucrum that allow drainage of purulent and necrotic material out of the dead bone.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents after a road traffic accident. He is confused, opens his eyes to painful stimuli, flexes one limb to painful stimuli, and localizes to the painful stimulus with the other limb. What is the grade of head injury based on his GCS score?
questions.solution:
The above patient can be graded to be suffering from moderate head injury, according to the Head injury classification using the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score. The GCS in this patient is 11.

If the GCS is in the range of 9-13 , it is classified as moderate head injury.

For calculating the GCS:

  • Score for verbal response: 4, because he is confused
  • Score for eye-opening: 2, because his eyes are opening to painful stimuli only.
  • Score for best motor response: 5, because he can localize to pain
  • Therefore, the GCS score is (4+2+5) = 11.

Head injury classification using the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score

Minor head injury GCS 15 with no loss of consciousness
(LOC)
Mild head injury GCS 14 or 15 with LOC
Moderate head injury GCS 9–13
Severe head injury GCS 3–8

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: An 81-year-old woman presented with gradually increasing shortness of breath over the past 6 months. Examination reveals finger clubbing and bibasilar fine inspiratory crackles. Pulmonary function test showed a restrictive defect with reduced lung volumes. HRCT is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Respiratory bronchiolitis associated interstitial lung disease

questions.solution:
In a patient with chronic shortness of breath, finger clubbing, and fine inspiratory crackles, spirometry showing a restrictive defect and reduced lung volumes points to a diagnosis of interstitial lung disease. In the given HRCT, there is prominent honeycombing in the lower and posterior lung zones. This is seen in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).

Interstitial lung diseases are characterized by inflammation and fibrosis involving the lung parenchyma. Although there are multiple diseases under this subset, the clinical presentation for all of them is the same. The patients are usually over 60 years of age and present with progressive exertional dyspnea and dry cough. On examination, fine inspiratory, velcro crackles may be heard. Digital clubbing and cyanosis are signs of advanced disease.

Pulmonary function tests (PFT) will show a restrictive deficit and reduction of TLC, FEV1, and FVC. There is also a reduction in DLCO and may be the first finding seen in PFT. Other laboratory tests should be undertaken if the patient has symptoms involving other systems, to rule out any connective tissue disorder which might have led to ILD.

IPF is the most common interstitial lung disease occurring due to an unknown cause. HRCT shows predominant subpleural and basal involvement, in the form of reticulation, honeycombing, and traction bronchiectasis. This is known as the usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern. Note that ground glass opacities are absent in this pattern. 

The treatment of IPF is with antifibrotic therapy such as pirfenidone and nintedanib.

Other options:

Option A: Acute interstitial pneumonia is characterized by a sudden onset of hypoxemia and respiratory distress, following symptoms of an upper respiratory tract infection. HRCT shows patchy bilateral ground-glass opacities and consolidation of the air spaces.

Options B and D: Respiratory bronchiolitis associated with ILD (RB-ILD) and desquamative interstitial pneumonia (DIP) are more commonly seen in smokers. HRCT shows prominent ground-glass opacities in both these disorders.

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text: A couple presents to you with complaints of inability to conceive despite staying together for 4 years and having unprotected intercourse. You advise them to come to the hospital within 2 hours after having sexual intercourse for post-coital test. Which of the following is false regarding this test?

choices.text: Ability of sperms to penetrate cervical mucous can be studied
Cervical mucus viscosity and quantity can be studied
Can detect presence of anti-sperm antibodies

questions.solution:
The test being advised for the above couple is the post-coital test and normally, the sperms should show progressive, but not rotatory movements.

Post-coital test (Sims’ or Huhner’s test):

The couple is advised intercourse close to the ovulation time, preferably in the early hours of the morning. The woman presents herself at the clinic within 2 hours after the intercourse.

The mucus is aspirated from the cervical canal and is spread over a glass slide. Another smear made from the posterior fornix serves as a control. Normally 10–50 motile sperms are seen per high-power field in cervical mucus.

The presence of antispermal antibodies in the cervical mucus imparts shaky or rotatory movements to the sperms or may totally immobilize them. The cervical mucus is simultaneously examined for its quantity, viscosity, and fern test.

The advantage of this test is that the cervical mucus can be simultaneously studied for oestrogenic effect and ovulation and its capability to allow sperm penetration and to look for the presence of any anti-sperm antibodies.

Note: The test is useless in the presence of cervical infection, which should be treated before performing the post-coital test.

questions.text: Which of the following salivary gland neoplasm is responsible for the given appearance in the Tc-99m radionuclide scan?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Warthin's tumor is the salivary gland tumor that appears as a hot spot on the technetium-99m scan as shown in the image.

Because of the high mitochondrial content within oncocytes, the oncocyte-rich Warthin's tumor and oncocytomas incorporate technetium-99m and appear as hot spots on radionuclide scans.

Warthins tumor or papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum is the second most common benign tumor of the parotid gland. It is seen in elderly male smokers. It is a slow-growing, benign, well-encapsulated cystic tumor and involves the lower pole of the parotid gland. It usually occurs unilaterally.

Treatment is superficial parotidectomy.

Grossly, they appear as round to oval encapsulated masses, 2-5 cm in diameter, easily palpable in the superficial parotid. Transection reveals a pale grey surface punctuated by cleft-like spaces filled with mucinous or serous secretions.

The image below shows the gross appearance of Warthin's tumor. Note the well-encapsulated mass.

Histologically, Warthin's tumor shows epithelial and lymphoid elements. The epithelium typically consists of a double layer of oncocytic epithelial cells, with a columnar luminal layer and a cuboidal layer. 


Other options:

Only a minority of salivary gland tumors show uptake on 99Tc scintigraphy. They include:

  • Warthins tumor
  • Oncocytoma of salivary glands

Tc-99m radionuclide scan is not done for pleomorphic adenoma, mucoepidermoid carcinoma, and adenoid cystic carcinoma as they show variable uptake. 

Option A: Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common salivary gland neoplasms and it most commonly involves the parotid gland (in about 60% of the cases). These are benign and mixed tumors that consist of a mixture of ductal (epithelial), myoepithelial, and mesenchymal cells. They present in the buccal cavity, parotid, or submandibular area as a painless, slow-growing, mobile mass.

Histopathology:

Grossly, the tumor is rounded and well-demarcated, measuring <6 cm in the greatest dimension. They are usually encapsulated, except in some areas such as the palate. The cut surface is gray-white with myxoid and blue translucent areas of the chondroid (cartilage-like) stroma (image given below).

Microscopic features include the epithelial elements which resemble ductal cells or myoepithelial cells and these are arranged as ducts, acini, irregular tubules, strands, or sheets of cells. They are dispersed within a background of loose myxoid and hyaline tissue containing islands of cartilage and, rarely, foci of bone.

The image below shows pleomorphic adenoma of the salivary gland consisting of mixed epithelial (left) and mesenchymal cell components (right).

Option C: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the salivary gland, commonly affecting the parotid gland. Mucinous, intermediate, and squamous elements, with small to large mucus-filled vacuoles are seen in histopathology. The image is shown below.

Option D: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is a malignant tumor that involves minor salivary glands, commonly the palatine glands. Histology shows tumor cells resemble swiss cheese due to an organized cribriform growth pattern. The image is shown below.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: A 53 year old man is found to have stage 2 hypertension without any co morbidities. Which drug will you start?
questions.solution:
Chlorthalidone is one of the first choice drugs in the treatment of hypertension without any comorbidities.
 
First-choice drugs used in the treatment of hypertension in patients without any comorbidities include:
  • Thiazide diuretics: Chlorthalidone is usually preferred to hydrochlorothiazide.
  • Calcium channel blockers: Extended-release, long-acting dihydropyridines are preferred.
  • ACE inhibitors: Captopril is preferred for the initiation of therapy. Enalapril and ramipril twice daily may also be used.
In the presence of any associated conditions or comorbidities, the first choice drugs for the treatment of hypertension would be as follows:
 
Conditions associated with hypertension
First choice drugs for hypertension
Diabetes
Chronic kidney disease with proteinuria
Inhibitors of renin-angiotensin system.
Angina
Beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers
Heart failure
ACE inhibitors and alpha+beta blockers such as carvedilol
Benign prostatic hyperplasia
α1 Blockers
Pregnancy
Labetalol
Atrial fibrillation
Diltiazem and verapamil

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman develops a fever, headache,  agitation, and focal seizures. Her T2-weighted MR shows a high signal intensity in the temporal lobe, as shown below, prompting suspicion of Herpes Simplex encephalitis. What is the most sensitive investigation to diagnose this condition?

choices.text: Brain biopsy to show ballooned cells
CSF examination to analyse cell counts

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of Herpes simplex encephalitis. The clinical hallmark of HSV encephalitis is the acute onset of fever and focal neurologic symptoms and signs, especially in the temporal lobe. The most sensitive investigation for this is HSV DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR.

HSV causes hemorrhagic necrosis of the inferomedial temporal and frontal lobe. 

Both HSV 1 and HSV 2 cause Herpes simplex encephalitis. Patients present with fever, headache, seizures, personality, and behavioral changes.

PCR amplification of viral DNA from the cerebrospinal fluid is the most sensitive means of detection and is recommended for the diagnosis of herpes meningitis or encephalitis.

CSF shows lymphocytic pleocytosis, moderately elevated protein levels, and normal glucose concentration.

EEG shows periodic lateralized spike-wave discharges.

 The drug of choice for HSV encephalitis is acyclovir.

 This coronal T2-weighted MR image shows high signal in the temporal lobes including hippocampal formations and parahippogampal gyrae, insulae, and right inferior frontal gyrus.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in a case of pyramidal tract lesion?
questions.solution:
Hyperreflexia, muscle atrophy, and spasticity are all features of the upper motor neuron(UMN) disease. Rigidity is a feature of extrapyramidal tract lesion such as rubrospinal or vestibulospinal tracts lesion.

Rigidity should not be confused with spasticity seen in UMN lesion. In rigidity, resistance is same in all directions, whereas in spasticity resistance is more in one direction than other. Further, rigidity is not velocity dependent (does not vary with the speed of movement of the muscle groups), while spasticity is velocity-dependent (i.e. more noticeable with fast movements).

 

Related Pearl: Features of Motor Neuron Lesions

Upper Motor Neuron Lesion

Lower Motor Neuron Lesion

Upper motor neuron typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons

Lower motor neurons are those whose axons terminate on skeletal muscles

Little or no muscle wasting → weakness of relatively large group of muscles

Muscle atrophy → muscle weakness of an individual and specific muscle

Hypertonia

Hypotonia

Increased or exaggerated deep tendon reflexes (hyperreflexia)

Hyporeflexia or areflexia

Spasticity

Flaccidity

Positive Babinski sign (abnormal plantar extensor reflex)

Fasciculations

questions.text: A 20-year-old female singer presents to you with weakness of voice after having multiple recordings in the studio. You diagnose phonasthenia in this patient as her indirect laryngoscopy shows the following characteristic finding. This appearance of the glottis is due to the weakness of which of the following muscles.
questions.solution:
The weakness of the thyroarytenoid gives the characteristic elliptical appearance of the glottis, which is seen in the image given.

Phonasthenia is the weakness of voice due to fatigue of laryngeal muscles. It is seen in abuse or misuse of voice or may follow laryngitis.

The weakness of muscles leads to a phonatory gap. The shape of the gap depends on the muscles involved:

  • Thyroarytenoid alone: elliptical space
  • Interarytenoid alone: triangular space
  • Both thyroarytenoid & inter arytenoid: Keyhole appearance.

Treatment is voice rest and vocal hygiene. Periods of voice rest after excessive use of voice is also imperative.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented with fever, cough, dyspnea, arthralgia, and a painful rash on the lower limbs suggestive of erythema nodosum. A chest X-ray was taken and the findings are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The chest X-ray showing bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, together with the presence of erythema nodosum, suggests the diagnosis of sarcoidosis.

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disorder of unknown etiology that is characterized by the presence of non-caseating granulomas.

In acute cases, patients may typically present with Lofgren’s syndrome, consisting of arthritis, erythema nodosum (as shown below), uveitis, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, lethargy, and occasional fever. Patients may also present with insidious onset of cough, exertional breathlessness, and radiographic infiltrates.

 

Investigation findings in sarcoidosis are as follows:

  • Lymphopenia and deranged liver function tests 
  • Hypercalcemia (due to increased synthesis of calcitriol [1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D] by alveolar macrophages) and hypercalciuria (can lead to nephrocalcinosis)
  • Pulmonary function test - the most common abnormality is an isolated decrease in diffusion of carbon monoxide (DLCO). A restrictive pattern is seen in patients with more advanced pulmonary disease. Approximately 15-20% of patients have an obstructive pattern
  • Bronchoscopy shows a typical 'cobblestone' appearance of the mucosa. Bronchial and transbronchial biopsies reveal non-caseating granulomas. An increased CD4:CD8 T-cell ratio may be seen in bronchoalveolar lavage
  • Chest X-ray is useful for staging sarcoidosis
  • HRCT shows reticulonodular opacities that follow a perilymphatic distribution centered on broncho-vascular bundles and the subpleural areas

The presence of erythema nodosum with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on chest X-ray is sufficient to make the diagnosis of sarcoidosis. A tissue biopsy is not required in this case. A typical presentation with classical HRCT features may also indicate the diagnosis. In all other cases, the diagnosis should be confirmed by histological examination of the involved organ.

A chest X-ray showing bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy in sarcoidosis is shown below,

Management of sarcoidosis is as follows:

  • Asymptomatic patients- monitored for disease progression
  • Localized/ limited cutaneous and ocular lesions- treated using topical steroids
  • Multisystem involvement:
    • Systemic steroids
    • Other drugs like hydroxychloroquine, methotrexate, and infliximab are considered when the steroids are ineffective or not tolerated

Other options:

Option A: The chest radiograph of a patient with lobar pneumonia right middle lobe is given below. Note the prominent wedge-shaped area of airspace consolidation in the right lung, which is characteristic of acute bacterial lobar pneumonia.

 

Option C: The chest radiograph given below shows extensive bilateral reticulonodular infiltrates seen in miliary tuberculosis.

 

Option D: The chest radiograph given below shows cannon-ball lesions of metastatic lung cancer.

questions.text: A male patient presents with erosions and blistering lesions over flexural areas. Histological examination of lesional skin demonstrates the "dilapidated brick wall" appearance of keratinocytes. Which of the following characteristic nail finding is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Hailey-Hailey disease, and Longitudinal leukonychia is usually seen in patients with this condition.

Hailey-Hailey disease:

  • It is an autosomal dominant disorder associated with blistering, majorly in intertriginous (flexural) areas.
  • It occurs due to mutation in the ATP2C1 gene encoding SERCA Ca2+ Channel ATPase.
  • On histology, there is a widespread partial loss of cohesion between suprabasal keratinocytes leading to acantholysis.
  • Typically, the acantholysis is incomplete, and separated keratinocytes are still partially connected to each other giving the appearance of “dilapidated brick wall”.
  • Linear white bands (longitudinal leukonychia) are present in the nails

Image: Hailey-Hailey disease Histopathology: Partial acantholytic dyskeratosis giving the whole epidermis a "dilapidated brick wall resemblance"

 

Other options:

Subungual Hyperkeratosis, Dorsal Nail Pterygium and Onycholysis are the nail changes seen in lichen planus.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachyonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .

Image : Dorsal Nail Pterygium

Image : Pup-tent sign 

Image: Trachyonychia

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy had an episode of upper respiratory tract infection and fever followed by eruption of this rash on the trunk, which started to crust after 2-3 days. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the diagnosis of this viral exanthem?

choices.text: Smears should be prepared by scraping the margins of the late vesicles
Multinucleated giant cells can be seen on microscopy
Cowdry type A intranuclear inclusion bodies may be seen in Tzanck smears

questions.solution:
The rash shown in the image above is characteristic of chickenpox with a dewdrop on rose-petal appearance which is present more on the trunk and less in the extremities and different stages of the rash can be seen at one time. Tzanck smears are prepared by scraping the base of the early vesicles.

The rash of chickenpox evolves rapidly progressing through macule, papule, vesicle, pustule, and finally scab. It is a pleomorphic rash, meaning that it appears in crops and hence varying stages of lesions can be noticed at a given time. 

Characteristics of the rash of chickenpox:

  • Superficial
  • Pleomorphic
  • Centripetal
  • Unilocular
  • Symmetrical
  • Spares palms and soles, affects flexor surfaces and axilla
  • Rapid evolution

The secondary attack rate of chickenpox is very high, at about 90%. (The secondary attack rate is defined as the probability that infection occurs among susceptible persons following known contact with an infectious person within the incubation period)

Diagnosis:

Diagnosis is usually clinical.

Microscopy:  Tzanck smears are prepared by scraping the base of the vesicles and stained with toluidine blue, or Giemsa stain. Multinucleated giant cells and Cowdry type A intranuclear inclusion bodies may be seen in smears.

Differences between smallpox and chickenpox:

  Smallpox Chickenpox
Rash

Centrifugal spread

Usually on palms and soles

Axilla is usually free

Rash on extensor surfaces

Centripetal distribution

Seldom on palms and soles; appears in crops

Axilla affected

Rash on flexor surfaces
Infectivity From onset of exanthem until all scabs separate From 1 day before rash until all vesicles become scab. Scabs are non-infectious.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman hailing from China has been diagnosed with Keshan's disease. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding her condition?

choices.text: Glutathione peroxidase has the involved element
Deficient element is a component of  the 22nd amino acid

questions.solution:
Keshan's disease occurs due to selenium deficiency which is a component of the 21st amino acid - Selenocysteine. 

Keshan disease is endemic cardiomyopathy found in children and young women residing in regions of China where the dietary intake of selenium is low. Mainly dilated cardiomyopathy (Option D) is the characteristic feature, but it may also result in congestive cardiac failure, cardiomegaly, and fulminant cardiogenic shock. It is associated with tumorigenesis and atherosclerosis (Option C).

Selenium is an important trace element that is a part of Selenocysteine. Selenocysteine is the 21st amino acid coded by the UGA codon, which is normally a stop codon. It is formed by co-translational modification. The protein synthetic apparatus can identify a selenocysteine-encoding UGA by the presence of the selenocysteine insertion sequence (SECIS) in the untranslated region of mRNA. There are many selenium-containing enzymes such as :

  • Glutathione peroxidase (Option A)
  • De-iodinase
  • Thioredoxin reductase

Selenium is also an intracellular antioxidant that complements the role of Vitamin E. Dietary sources of selenium include seafood, muscle meat, and some cereals.

Related Pearl: Metals as cofactors and prosthetic groups in enzymes

Metal  Enzymes
Zinc
  • Carbonic anhydrase II
  • Carboxypeptidase A
  • Alcohol dehydrogenase
  • Alkaline phosphatase
  • ALA dehydratase
  • Lactate dehydrogenase
  • Adenosine deaminase
  • Phospholipase C
Selenium

 

  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • Thioredoxin reductase
  • De-iodinase
Magnesium
  • Phosphofructokinase
  • Hexokinase
  • Glucose -6-phosphatase
  • Mutase
  • Enolase
Copper
  • Cytosolic superoxide dismutase
  • Tyrosinase
  • Cyt c oxidase
  • Lysyl oxidase
  • Amino acid oxidase
Molybdenum
  • Dinitrogenase
  • Xanthine oxidase
  • Sulfite oxidase
Manganese
  • Mitochondrial superoxide dismutase
  • Enolase
  • Arginase
  • Hexokinase
  • Phosphofructokinase
  • Ribonucleotide reductase
Iron
  • Succinate Dehydrogenase

  • Lecithinase

Related Pearl: Start and stop codons

Start codon: AUG - Methionine

Stop codons:

  • UGA- Selenocysteine (21st Amino acid )
  • UAG- Pyrrolysine (22nd Amino acid)
  • UAA

questions.text: A radiology consultant advises you to use a water-soluble contrast media having an iodine particle ratio of 6:1 in a patient referred for a radiological investigation. Which of the following contrast media will you prefer?
questions.solution:
Non-ionic Dimers have an Iodine: particle ratio of 6:1

Contrast agents can be divided into water-soluble (iodine-containing) and non-water-soluble (barium) compounds.

Classification of iodinated contrast:

  • Ionic – Monomer and dimer
  • Non-ionic– Monomer and dimer

Other options:

  • Ionic monomers have an Iodine: particle ratio of 3:2
  • Ionic Dimers have an Iodine: particle ratio of 6:2 or 3:1
  • Non-ionic monomers have an Iodine: particle ratio of 3:1

Related Pearl: Classification of iodinated contrast medias:

  Iodinated contrast materials  
Types Ionic  Non-ionic
Subtypes  Monomer Dimer Monomer Dimer

1400- 1600 mOsm (Not preferred due to high osmolarity)

Iodine: particle ratio 3:2 6:2 or 3:1 3:1 6:1
Examples 

Diatrizoate (Urograffin)

Iothalamate

Ioxaglate

Iohexol (most commonly used)

Ioversol

questions.text: A 38-year-old  male patient presented with severe dyspnoea. Examination revealed mitral stenosis and left atrial hypertrophy. The diagnosis was made based on the HPE image which showed myocardial inflammatory lesions consisting of T cells, plasma cells, and Anitschkow cells associated with zones of fibrinoid necrosis. Which of the following vegetation pattern is most likely to be associated with the underlying disease seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The vegetations depicted in "Image A", are consistent with rheumatic heart disease. These present as small, 1 to 2 mm warty vegetations called verrucae along the lines of the closure of the valve leaflets and are most likely to be seen in this case.

The h/o severe dyspnoea with mitral stenosis and left atrial hypertrophy and the HPE image which showed myocardial inflammatory lesions consisting of T cells, plasma cells, and Anitschkow cells associated with zones of fibrinoid necrosis are suggestive of rheumatic valvular disease.

The slide shows Anitschkow cells or caterpillar cells which are pathognomic for RF.

  • During acute rheumatic fever, focal inflammatory lesions are found in various tissues.
  • Distinctive lesions in the heart - Aschoff bodies, consisting of foci of T lymphocytes, occasional plasma cells, and plump activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells (pathognomonic for RF)
  • These Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei (occasionally binucleate) in which the chromatin condenses into a central, slender, wavy ribbon (hence the designation “caterpillar cells”)

 

Histology showing Aschoff bodies with Anitschkow cells in Rheumatic heart disease.

Related Pearl: Vegetations in Various Types of Endocarditis

 

RHD

heart disease

(M3-AML, pancreatic

vein thrombosis,

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented to the OPD with dysuria and frequent micturition. Urinalysis showed pus cells. The culture on MacConkey agar showed the appearance of non-lactose fermenting colonies. Phenyl pyruvic acid (PPA) Reaction is positive. What is the most likely organism implicated in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario indicating, non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar, and a positive Phenyl pyruvic acid (PPA) Reaction in a patient with lower urinary tract symptoms is suggestive of Proteus infection.

Proteus is a gram-negative bacillus. All members of the tribe Protea have the enzyme phenylalanine deaminase which converts phenylalanine to phenyl pyruvic acid. This is called the PPA reaction.

Proteus can cause urinary tract infections. Struvite stones (triple phosphate stones) are usually seen in a setting of infection with urease-producing bacteria like Proteus, Pseudomonas, and Staphylococcus. Production of urease enzyme by Proteus, which hydrolyses urea to ammonia causes alkalinization of urine. Alkalinization of urine leads to the precipitation of organic and inorganic compounds which contributes to the formation of Struvite stones.

Image showing a positive PPA reaction:

On solid culture media such as blood agar, Proteus shows swarming motility due to the presence of peritrichous flagella. It is characterized by expanding rings (waves) of organisms over the surface of the agar (shown in the image below). However, swarming is inhibited on MacConkey agar due to the presence of bile.


Enterobacteriaceae family is classified based on their action on lactose present in MacConkey's medium as,

Lactose fermenters Escherichia, Klebsiella, Enterobacter 
Late lactose fermenters Shigella sonnei, Serratia, Citrobacter, Erwinia
Non-lactose fermenters Salmonella, Shigella, Proteus


Mnemonic to remember Non-lactose fermenters: SPY PSM

  • Salmonella
  • Proteus
  • Yersinia
  • Providencia - late fermenter
  • Shigella (Except S. sonnei, which is a late lactose fermenter)
  • Morganella

questions.text: Which of the following patients receiving blood transfusions are more prone to develop bacterial sepsis?

choices.text: A young women with severe anaemia

questions.solution:
Patients with thrombocytopenia receiving blood transfusions (platelets) are more prone to develop bacterial sepsis. 

Sepsis is mostly due to significant bacterial contamination of the blood products. Platelets have the maximum risk of causing this condition when compared to red cell preparations. Since patients with thrombocytopenia receive platelet transfusion, they are at an increased risk of infections.

Platelets (unlike red cells) must be stored at room temperature. This is a condition that is favourable for bacterial proliferation. Broad-spectrum antibiotics must be started while waiting for the culture reports.

The blood components that are preferred for the other conditions are:

  • Anaemia - RBCs
  • Hemophilia - FFP
  • vonWillebrand disease - cryoprecipitate

questions.text: During the surgery residency,  your consultant asks you to do a case study of a child having Type 4  jejunoileal atresia. The children with this type of jejunoileal atresia show _____

choices.text: Christmas tree deformity with a large mesenteric gap
Complete separation of the blind ends of  bowel with mesenteric gap
Apple peel deformity with a large mesenteric gap
Multiple atresias with a string of sausage appearance

questions.solution:
Type 4 Jejunoileal atresia shows Multiple atresias with a string of sausage appearance.

Atresias are slightly more common in the jejunum than in the ileum. It is thought to result from an intrauterine mesenteric vascular accident. 

Classification of Jejunoileal atresia:

Type

Feature

Type 1

Mucosal web or diaphragm

Type 2

With an atretic cord between two blind ends of bowel with intact mesentery

Type 3 a

Complete separation of the blind ends of the bowel by a V-shaped mesenteric gap

Type 3 b

An apple peel or Christmas tree deformity with a large mesenteric gap

Type 4

Multiple atresias, with a string of sausage appearance

 

Clinical features:

Infants present with bilious emesis, abdominal distention, and failure to pass meconium. The clinical presentation varies by the location of the atretic obstruction.

  • In proximal atresia, abdominal distention is less, but significant bilious emesis is present. Abdominal radiographs can show air-fluid levels with absent distal gas.
  • In distal atresias, abdominal distention is more common.

Management:

Infants are managed for neonatal bowel obstruction. An orogastric tube is placed, and appropriate IV fluid resuscitation is implemented. At operation, the main objective is to establish intestinal continuity while preserving as much intestinal length as possible.

In multiple atresias, multiple anastomoses over an endoluminal stent may be necessary. If the proximal intestine is significantly dilated, prolonged dysmotility may persist, and therefore a tapering enteroplasty of the dilated segment should be considered.

questions.text: Which of the following measures is not advocated for controlling the transmission of Japanese Encephalitis?

choices.text: The use of indoor residual sprays
Keeping pigs away from human dwellings
The use of Malathion for outdoor fogging

questions.solution:
Indoor residual sprays are not used in the vector control measures for Japanese Encephalitis, as its vectors are outdoor resters.

Japanese encephalitis is caused by group B arbovirus (Flavivirus) and transmitted by culex mosquitoes.

Prevention and control of JE:

  • Vaccination: SA-14-14-2 strain is used in India. A single dose is given followed by a single booster given at an interval of about 1 year. The children between 1 - 15 years of age are immunized.
  • Keeping pigs away from human dwellings from dusk to dawn (biting time of the vectors). Pigs act as important amplifiers of the virus.
  • Use of bed nets for personal protection.
  • Use of larvivorous fishes.
  • Using Malathion for outdoor fogging to control an outbreak.

 

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: You were asked to perform fundoscopy in a patient diagnosed with hypertensive retinopathy. You notice arteriovenous nicking with tapering of veins on either side of the crossings on fundoscopic examination. This sign is known as _______
questions.solution:
Tapering of veins on either side of the crossings is known as the Gunn sign, which is seen on fundoscopy in a patient with hypertensive retinopathy.

Arteriovenous nicking is the hallmark of hypertensive retinopathy. It occurs where the arteriole crosses and compresses the vein, as the vessels share a common adventitious sheath.

These changes are also known as A-V crossing changes and they include:

  • Salu’s sign is the deflection of veins at the arteriovenous crossings.
  • Bonnet sign is the banking of veins distal to arteriovenous crossings, and
  • Gunn sign is the tapering of veins on either side of the crossings.

 

Grading of Hypertensive Retinopathy:

Grade 1: Mild generalized retinal arteriolar narrowing

Grade 2: Focal arteriolar narrowing and arteriovenous nipping. Opacified appearance of arteriolar walls as a copper wiring can be seen.

Grade 3: Grade 2 plus dot/blot/flame-shaped retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and cotton wool spots. Chronic retinal edema results in the deposition of hard exudates around the fovea as a macular star. 

Grade 4: Severe grade 3 plus optic disc swelling. It is a marker of malignant hypertension

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman came to the hospital with complaints of excruciating paroxysmal pain on the right side of her lips, gums, and cheek. The episodes last for 2-3 min and have been present for the past 2 months.  Which of the following is incorrect regarding the primary drug used in the treatment of this condition?

choices.text: It is a GABAc receptor modulator
It can lead to hyponatremia in the elderly

questions.solution:
The symptoms of excruciating and paroxysmal facial pain are suggestive of trigeminal neuralgia. Carbamazepine is used as the primary drug in this condition. The incorrect statement about carbamazepine is that it is a GABAc receptor modulator. 

Carbamazepine acts by slowing the recovery rate of voltage-activated sodium channels from their inactivated state and acts as a sodium channel blocker. 

It is used as the primary drug in both trigeminal and glossopharyngeal neuralgias. It is also the primary agent for treating generalized tonic-clonic and focal seizures. It can also be used in bipolar affective disorders.

Carbamazepine also has a potentiating effect on the action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). It can result in water retention with decreased osmolarity and hyponatremia, especially in elderly patients with cardiac disease. Other adverse effects include:

  • Hypersensitivity reactions such as:
    • Stevens-Johnson syndrome
    • Skin rashes
    • Transient leukopenia
    • Aplastic anemia 
    • Agranulocytosis
    • Hepatotoxicity (on concomitant use with valproate)
  • Dose-related neurotoxicity such as:
    • vertigo
    • ataxia
    • diplopia and blurred vision
    • worsening of seizures
    • vomiting

Related Pearl: First-line Agents in Different Types of Seizures

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents multiple smooth,  well‐demarcated papules on the vermilion of the upper lip as shown in the image below.   The glands affected in the given condition shows which of the following types of secretion?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Fordyce spots. Fordyce spots are sebaceous glands without hair follicles and these sebaceous glands are an example of holocrine gland.

Glands have been classified into 3 types based on the manner in which their secretions are poured out of the cells, which includes:

Apocrine Holocrine Eccrine(Merocrine)
The apical part of the cell sheds off during discharge Whole-cell disintegrates during discharge The cell is intact and secretions are thrown out by exocytosis
Eg: Apocrine sweat glands in the axilla and groin, mammary glands, the external auditory canal (ceruminous glands), and eyelids (glands of Moll)

Eg: Glands of Zeis and Meibomian gland 

Montgomery tubercle: Nipple and areola

Tyson's gland: External fold of the prepuce

Fordyce' spot: Vermillion border of lips and mucosa

Eg: Sweat glands on palms and soles

Found everywhere except clitoris, glans penis, labia minora, external auditory canal, and lips

 

Related Pearl: Fordyce Spots

Fordyce spots/Fordyce granules:

  • The Fordyce spots are heterotopic sebaceous glands wherein the duct is connected directly to the overlying skin or mucosal surface unlike other sebum glands which open into the follicle.
  • They are called ectopic/free-lying sebaceous glands.
  • They occur commonly on the vermilion border of upper lip(m/c), buccal mucosa, skin over penile shaft and areolar of the breast.
  • They are commonly multiple and appear as symmetrical discrete yellow papules.
  • Fordyce spots on penis are called Tyson glands.
  • They are asymptomatic.
  • Treatment ladder
    • First line: Reassurance
    • Second line
      • Local destruction with superficial cautery or electrodessication
      • Topical trichloracetic acid 

Image: Fordyce spots on the vermilion border of both lips in A, upper lip in B, and buccal mucosa in  C.

questions.text: You notice the presence of both acidophilic and basophilic cells in the report of Papanicolaou Test, done on a 21-year-old woman during her hormonal cytological evaluation. Which of the following vaginal epithelial cells appear as acidophilic in the given test?
questions.solution:
Superficial cells are acidophilic with characteristic pyknotic nuclei. All the other cells are basophilic.

Type of cell Identification feature
Basal & Para Basal Cells are small, rounded, basophilic with large nuclei 
Middle layer (Intermediate) Cells are squamous cells, transparent and basophilic (Blue/Green) with vesicular nuclei
Superficial layer Cells are acidophilic (Pink), with pyknotic nuclei
Malignant cells Hyperchromatic, nuclei vary in size, small cytoplasm in undifferentiated malignant cells

 

Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. The presence of malignant cells on Pap smear requires further evaluation with colposcopy, cervical biopsy, fractional curettage, etc.

The prerequisites are:

  • It should be done prior to vaginal examination.
  • Lubricants should not be used.
  • The patient should not be menstruating during the pap test.
  • The ideal time is around ovulation.
  • The patient should not have intercourse 24hrs prior to the test.

Procedure:

  • The patient is put in a dorsal position, and the labia are parted.
  • Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced.
  • The squamocolumnar junction is scraped with Ayer’s spatula.
  • The scrapings are evenly spread onto a glass slide and immediately fixed.
  • After fixing it for 30 min, the slide is air-dried and stained with Pap or short stain.
  • Endocervix is also scraped with a brush and added to the slide to improve the predictive valve.

                  

The above image shows superficial cells (arrow mark) along with other basophilic cells.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl came to the hospital with a history of upper respiratory illness since two weeks. Initially, she had a low-grade fever, sinus congestion with clear discharge which improved over a week but recurred with increased severity. Now she has a severe sore throat, enlarged and tender cervical lymph nodes, and fever (38.2degrees celsius). There is no cough or shortness of breath. Examination of the oral cavity is shown in the image below.  Based on centor criteria, what is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Triple throat swab culture and sensitivity test

questions.solution:
Empirical Penicillin V therapy is provided.

The above image shows tonsillar exudates. Based on the clinical features the patient has a centor score of 4, suggesting a high probability of group A β- hemolytic streptococcal (GABHS) pharyngitis. The treatment includes empirical antibiotic therapy with:

  • Empirical antibiotic therapy with penicillin V potassium for 5-10 days or
  • Erythromycin (in case of allergy to penicillin) or
  • Cefuroxime axetil for 5-10 days.

 

Centor criteria:

  • Absence of cough
  • Pharyngotonsillar exudate
  • Tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Fever over 38°C

One point is allotted for each criterion, and the maximum score is 4.

For the above patient, the score is: 1+1+1+1 = 4

 

Based on the centor score, the management is as follows:

Centor criteria score Management
0 or 1 No testing or treatment
2 or 3 A single Throat swab culture and Rapid streptococcal antigen testing, and if they are positive provide antibiotic treatment
4 Empirical antibiotic therapy with penicillin V potassium for 5-10 days or Erythromycin (in case of allergy to penicillin) or Cefuroxime axetil for 5-10 days

 

 

 Primary Prevention of Rheumatic Fever (Treatment of Streptococcal Tonsillopharyngitis)

Penicillins

Penicillin V 

Amoxicillin

Benzathine penicillin G

For individuals allergic to penicillin

Narrow-spectrum cephalosporin

(cephalexin, cefadroxil)

Clindamycin

Azithromycin

Clarithromycin

Related Pearl: Acid resistant penicillins: mnemonic "VODKA"

The mnemonic "VODKA" can be used to for acid-resistant penicillins that are active orally.

  • V - Penicillin V
  • O - Oxacillin
  • D - Dicloxacillin
  • K - Cloxacillin
  • A - Amoxycillin/ Ampicillin

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented with 12 weeks of amenorrhea. The ultrasonography of the abdomen and pelvis revealed twin gestation, as shown in the image below. This type of twin gestation results if the division of the inner cell mass occurs:
questions.solution:
The image shows the lambda sign or twin peak sign seen in dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy. If the division of the inner cell mass occurs within 3 days of fertilization, it results in this type of twin gestation. 

Placental chorionicity is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. A thick septum between the two gestational sacs is present in dichorionic twins.

A triangular projection is seen at the base of the membrane. This is known as lambda or twin peak sign. The presence of lambda or twin peak sign indicates a dichorionic placenta.

Twinning and Time of division:

Time of division Type of twin
<3 days  Dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) 
4-8 days Monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA)
>8 days Monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA)
>13 days  Conjoint twins

 

Lambda sign:

Note: "T sign" is the sonographic image seen in a monochorionic twin pregnancy. It refers to one gestation sac with a dividing membrane and two fetuses, as shown below.

Related Pearl: Twinning

Related Pearl: Important radiological signs in OBG

Sign
Significance
Bagel sign
Gestational sac in the adnexa with a hyperechoic ring.
USG sign in tubal ectopic.
Ball Sign
X-ray shows a crumpled up spine of the fetus.
Radiological sign of intrauterine fetal death.
Banana Sign
Abnormal anterior curvature of the cerebellum due to the associated Arnold-Chiari malformation.
USG sign in open spina bifida.
Double decidual sac Sign
Two concentric echogenic rings separated by a hyperechoic space.
Normal USG appearance of an intrauterine gestational sac.
Lambda Sign
The chorionic tissue in between the two layers of the membrane between the twins.
USG sign seen in di-chorionic pregnancies.
‘T’ Sign
USG sign seen in monochorionic twins. As the intertwin membrane does not have any chorionic tissue it gives rise to ‘T’ sign in ultrasound.
Bunch of grapes sign
USG appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.
Butterfly sign
Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.
Cloverleaf skull
Seen in craniosynostosis
Empty amnion sign
Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 24-year-old teacher presented with weight loss, diarrhea, and peripheral edema for the past 6 months and was diagnosed with a protein-losing enteropathy. The hispathological image of the gastric tissue is given below. Which of the following growth factors is primarily responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the histological image with the arrow mark showing hyperplasia of foveolar mucous cells, cystically dilated glands which are elongated (with a corkscrew-like appearance) are suggestive of Ménétrier disease, which occurs due to excessive secretion of transforming growth factor α (TGF-α).

Menetrier disease:

Menetrier disease is one of the causes of hypertrophic gastropathy. It is characterized by irregular enlargement of the gastric rugae in the body and fundus but the antrum is generally spared. It is associated with diffuse hyperplasia of the foveolar epithelium and hypoproteinemia due to protein-losing enteropathy.

Symptoms such as weight loss, diarrhea, and peripheral edema, are commonly present. The features of Ménétrier disease in children are similar to those in adults, but the pediatric disease is usually self-limited and often occurs after an episode of respiratory infection. There is an increased risk of gastric adenocarcinoma in adults.

Treatment of Ménétrier disease is mainly supportive, with intravenous albumin and parenteral nutritional supplementation. Gastrectomy may be required in severe cases. Drugs that block TGF-α-mediated activation of the epidermal growth factor receptor are also being tried.

Image below:

A CT abdomen, in coronal section, showing characteristic large rugal folds in the stomach. A cyst can also be seen in the liver.

questions.text: The presence of which of the following bonds in starch makes it digestible by salivary amylase?
questions.solution:
Salivary α-amylase present in humans acts on α (1→4) glycosidic linkage binding the glucose molecules in dietary starch and glycogen.

Starch is a polymer of glucose that is linked by α(1→4) glycoside bonds, which are catalyzed by salivary and pancreatic amylases. It consists of two types of molecules, amylose (linear and helical) and amylopectin (branched).

Other options: 

α (1→6) linkage is found in glycogen. The primary glycosidic bond is an α (1→4) linkage, whereas the branch point contains an α (1→6) linkage. Salivary amylase can digest α (1→4) linkage but not α (1→6) linkage in the branching point, resulting in the production of a mixture containing short, branched, and unbranched oligosaccharides termed as dextrins.

β (1→4) linkage is found in cellulose. This bond cannot be digested by α-amylase, hence, cellulose doesn't give us energy but serves as a source of fiber in our diet.

Related Pearl: Structural Bond of Various Polysaccharides

Polysaccharides

Structure

Amylose starch

Unbranched chain, α (1→4) glycosidic  linkages of glucose. Hollow helix

Amylopectin  starch

α (1→4) glycosidic linkages with α (1→6) glycosidic branches every 24-30 glucose molecule. Hollow helix

Glycogen

α (1→4) glycosidic linkages with α (1→6) glycosidic branches every 8-12 glucose molecule. Hollow helix

Cellulose

Unbranched beta (1→4) glycosidic linkages of glucose. Linear

Chitin

Unbranched beta (1→4) glycosidic linkages of N-acetylglucosamine. Linear

questions.text: A 32-year-old sewer worker was trapped in the sewer lines without any mask or protective equipment. He was brought dead to the casualty by his co-worker. The doctor observed an odor of rotten eggs emanating from the victim's body.  Which of the following complexes of the electron transport chain is inhibited by sewer gas?
questions.solution:
Sewer gas is a common name used for hydrogen sulfide which causes the characteristic smell of rotten eggs on poisoning, as seen in this patient. Hydrogen sulfide inhibits complex IV of the electron transport chain (ETC) and arrests the respiratory chain. 

The electron transport chain (ETC) is a specialized set of electron carriers that can accept electrons resulting from the oxidation of energy-rich molecules like glucose. The intermediate substrates in these reactions can pass on electrons to certain coenzymes such as nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FADH2).

The reduced forms can then donate electrons to the ETC by which they lose most of their free energy which is used to move H+ through the inner mitochondrial membrane. The H+ gradient thus produced results in the production of ATP. ATP synthesis together with electron transport is known as oxidative phosphorylation.

The reactions in oxidative phosphorylation and the arrangement of complexes that form the ETC are shown below.

questions.text: A 3-weeks-old infant diagnosed with primary adrenal insufficiency presented with failure to thrive, recurrent vomiting, and hepatosplenomegaly. Radiological imaging shows bilateral adrenal calcification. Enzyme studies revealed a deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase. What is the most likely disease in this case?
questions.solution:
An infant with primary adrenal insufficiency with hepatosplenomegaly, recurrent emesis, and bilateral adrenal calcification is suggestive of Wolman's disease. It is due to the deficiency of the enzyme acid lipase.

It is a lipid disorder caused by a deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase (chromosome 10) which leads to the accumulation of cholesterol esters and triglycerides in the most visceral organs. It is an Autosomal recessive disease.

The child presents in the first few weeks of life with failure to thrive, vomiting, abdominal distention, steatorrhea, hepatosplenomegaly, and hyperlipidemia with extensive bilateral calcifications of the adrenal glands.No specific therapy is available and death usually occurs within 6 months of life.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman with inflammatory bowel disease in remission comes to you for a follow-up. She is on azathioprine to prevent recurrence. Which of the following should be advised?

choices.text: Routine analysis of complete blood count

questions.solution:
Routine analysis of complete blood count for the duration of the azathioprine therapy should be advised.

Azathioprine is a purine analog commonly used in the treatment of moderate to severe inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). It is an immunosuppressant that can be used alone or in combination with other drugs. It is used alone in patients in remission to prevent a recurrence. Side effects include hepatotoxicity, arthralgia, and pancreatitis. Bone marrow suppression is a dose-related adverse effect and warrants regular monitoring of complete blood counts. Regular liver function tests are also recommended. 

Inflammatory bowel disease includes ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease. Ulcerative colitis is a recurrent condition marked by mucosal inflammation restricted to the colon. Crohn's disease is characterized by transmural inflammation of any section of the gastrointestinal tract.

Laboratory investigations usually show elevated C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Fecal calprotectin and lactoferrin can be used to differentiate it from irritable bowel syndrome. In ulcerative colitis, a sigmoidoscopy is usually done before treatment to assess disease activity while a colonoscopy is done when the disease is not active. A colonoscopy also allows visualization and biopsy of mass lesions and strictures in Crohn's disease. 

IBD can be medically managed by 5-aminosalicylic acid agents such as sulfasalazine and mesalamine. Other drugs used are azathioprine, mercaptopurine, methotrexate, glucocorticoids, and anti-tumor necrosis factors. Indications for surgery are extensive bleeding, intestinal obstruction, symptomatic perianal fistulas, and unresponsiveness to medical therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Annual screening for skin cancer is recommended in patients who are prescribed anti-tumor necrosis factor anti-TNF agents such as infliximab or adalimumab. These drugs increase the risk of developing melanoma.

Option B: Folate supplementation is recommended in patients on methotrexate in addition to liver function tests and CBC monitoring.

Option D: The patient should avoid pregnancy while on treatment with methotrexate. Methotrexate is a known teratogen and should be stopped at least 3-6 months before conception.

questions.text: A young patient who is a known case of glaucoma presented with sudden onset of decreased vision. Following an ophthalmic examination, a provisional diagnosis of glaukomflecken was made. This condition refers to:

choices.text: Posterior subcapsular opacities secondary to angle closure glaucoma
Anterior subcapsular opacities secondary to angle closure glaucoma
Corneal opacity secondary to open angle glaucoma
Corneal opacity secondary to angle closure glaucoma

questions.solution:
Glaukomflecken refers to anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity secondary to angle-closure glaucoma.

Marked elevation of intraocular pressure in acute congestive angle closure may cause small anterior grey-white subcapsular or capsular opacities to form within the pupillary area. This is called glaukomflecken and indicates focal infarcts of the lens epithelium. This finding is strongly suggestive of a previous episode of acute congestive angle closure.

The images below show glaukomflecken in a patient with angle closure glaucoma. 

Vogt's triad is seen after an acute attack of primary angle closure. It includes glaukomflecken, patches of iris atrophy, and a slightly dilated nonreactive pupil.

In angle-closure glaucoma, there is an apposition of the peripheral iris against the trabecular meshwork. Furthermore, there is obstruction of aqueous outflow by the closure of an already narrow angle of the anterior chamber resulting in an increase in intraocular pressure.

questions.text: You induce anesthesia in a patient undergoing surgery by using NaOH as a dry CO2 absorbent. 10 minutes after the induction of anesthesia, you noticed a fall in SpO2 and a rise in COHb levels. You suspect carbon monoxide poisoning. Which of the following agents produce maximum carbon monoxide with dry CO2 absorbents?
questions.solution:
Desflurane produces maximum carbon monoxide with dry CO2 absorbents.

Note: The volatile anesthetics can be broken down to carbon monoxide by dry absorbent (eg, sodium or potassium hydroxide) to such a degree that it is capable of causing clinically significant carbon monoxide poisoning.

Sevoflurane produce carbon monoxide at high temperature.

Related Pearl: Composition of CO2 Absorbers in rebreathing system

SODA LIME:

  • Ca(OH)2 - 80%
  • NaOH - 3%
  • KOH - 2%
  • Silica - 0.2%
  • Moisture-  14-19%

Granule size is 4-8 mesh

Absorbs up to 23L of CO2/100 g

With Trilene, soda-lime forms neurotoxin dichloroacetylene and pulmonary irritant phosgene gas; hence contraindicated.

Sevoflurane reacts with soda lime and produces Compound A

Method of hardness- Silica

AMSORB:

  • Ca(OH)2
  • Ca Cl2
  • CaSO4

Causes less degradation of volatile anesthetics eg. Sevoflurane to Compound A or Desflurane to Carbon Monoxide

BARALYME:

  • Ca(OH)2 80%
  • Ba(OH)2 20%
  • KOH <1%

Absorbs up to 9-18L of CO2/100 g

Desflurane can be broken down to CO by dry barium hydroxide lime.

Method of hardness: water of crystallization.

questions.text: A patient comes to the emergency with pain in the right big toe after a heavy object fell on it. The X-ray of the foot is done and is shown below. What Salter-Harris type of physeal injury does the radiograph show?
questions.solution:
The given radiograph of big toe proximal phalanx shows a Salter-Harris type IV physeal injury.

In a type IV fracture, the fracture line passes through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, the metaphysis, and the epiphysis.

Related Pearl: Types of Salter–Harris fractures- Mnemonic

There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures. Among these, types I to V are more common.

The mnemonic "SALTER" can be used to help remember the first five types.

TYPE  MNEMONIC DESCRIPTION
Type I S = Slip/straight across Transverse fracture through the growth plate
Type II A = Away The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
Type III L = Lower The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis.
Type IV TE = Through Everything  A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
Type V R = Rammed (crushed)  A compression fracture of the growth plate

Rarer types VI to IX have been added subsequently.

  • Type VI - Injury to the perichondral structures
  • Type VII - Isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate
  • Type VIII - Isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification
  • Type IX - Injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

questions.text: A senior resident asks you to evaluate a patient diagnosed with type 2 endometrial carcinoma. All the following features are associated with this type of endometrial carcinoma  except _______
questions.solution:
Type 2 endometrial carcinomas are estrogen-independent. They develop from atrophic endometrium in postmenopausal women and are poorly differentiated

Histological endometrial cancers are classified into 2 varieties,

Type1 (Endometrioid) Type 2 (Non-endometrioid)
Estrogen dependent Estrogen independent
Good prognosis Poor prognosis
Associated with PTEN/KRas mutation Associated with TP53 mutation

Note: Type1 (Estrogen dependent) is the most common type.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient with a history of chronic arthritis on treatment came with complaints of defective vision in both eyes. On examination, vision in RE = 6/12, LE = 6/18, IOP = 18 mmHg in both eyes, the anterior segment was normal, fundus examination and fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) findings given in the figure. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical viginette of female patient on treatment for chronic arthritis which is most likely the drug chloroquine given for rheumatoid arthritis, now presenting with decreased visual acuity, fundoscopy with a typical bull's eye sign and Fundus fluroscein angiography showing increased fluroscence in the macular area is suggestive of chloroquine toxicity.

Chloroquine and it's derivative hydroxychloroquine (HCQ) are antimalarial drugs which is also used to treat connective tissue disorders such as Rheumatoid arthritis, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) and Discoid Lupus.

The maximum dose allowed for chloroquine is 6 mg/kg in 24 hours while for hydroxychloroquine it is 4.5 mg/kg. Hydroxychloroquine has a lower risk of ocular toxicity and hence is percived to be a safer drug but with weaker anti-inflammatory effect.

Manifestations of Chloroquine toxicity:

  • Reversible on stopping the drug: difficulty in night vision, blurring of vision, diplopia, keratopathy
  • Central and paracentral scotomas
  • Earliest fundus findings: blunting of foveal reflex, irregularity in the macular pigmentation.
  • Advanced stages: 'Bull's eye maculopathy' where the central irregular pigmentation may become surrounded by a concentric zone of hypopigmentation
  • End-stage appearance includes bullseye maculopathy, pigmentary degeneration of retina and bone spicule formation, vascular attenuation, and optic atropy.

Screening should include a baseline examination for all patients before starting these drugs followed by annual screening starting after 5 years of use.

Pre-existing maculopathy is considered a contraindication to treatment with chloroquine and HCQ because underlying abnormalities may mask early toxicity.

Screening examinations include visual acuity testing, dilated fundus examination, spectral-domain optical coherence tomography (SD-OCT) testing, and functional assessment with Humphrey test.

Various causes of Bull's eye maculopathy are:

  1. Chloroquine and HCQ toxicity
  2. Cone-Rod dystrophy
  3. Advanced stargardt's disease
  4. Clofazimine retinopathy

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of strychnine poisoning?
questions.solution:
Carphologia is not a feature of strychnine poisoning.

Carphologia - picking at the bedding/clothing, trying to pull imaginary threads from tips of fingers, threading imaginary needle etc. It is a feature of datura poisoning.

Risus sardonicus - The contraction of muscles of the face causing the angles of the mouth to be drawn wide apart with creases appearing in and around the eyelids.

Opisthotonos - Arching of the body in hyperextension because of spasm of anti-gravity muscles.

questions.text: You were asked to assist with the tubal sterilization procedure during your residency. The senior resident performs the following type of sterilization procedure. This technique is known as ____
questions.solution:
The sterilization procedure which is shown in the above image is the Kroener technique.

It refers to fimbriectomy done by ligating the distal ampulla of the tube with two permanent sutures followed by division and removal of the infundibulum.

Other options:

Option A - Uchida's method

  • The tubal serosa is stripped off the muscular layer in the midsegment of the tube, which is then excised.
  • The proximal end is ligated and buried in the broad ligament.
  • The minimal excision of the tube preserves the potential for tuboplasty.


Option B - Irving's procedure

  • The mid-portion of the tube is ligated and the intervening portion excised.
  • The proximal end is buried in the myometrium and the distal end is buried in the broad ligament.
  • It is a reliable method but irreversible and may require a laparotomy incision.


Option D - Pomeroy method

  • The most popular technique of tubal ligation is the Pomeroy operation.
  • The fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision, and the middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut and excised.

questions.text: What is the clinical significance of pores of Kohn?

choices.text: Release of spermatozoa into the vas deferens
Release of sebum on stratum corneum
Allow the passage of bacteria and exudates  in pneumonia
Allow the passage of bile into bile canaliculi

questions.solution:
Pores of Kohn (alveolar pores) are seen in the alveolar wall. They are the interalveolar connections that permit the passage of bacteria and exudate between adjacent alveoli. 

In case if the lung is partially deflated, collateral ventilation can occur to some extent through these pores.

Clinical relevance: The passage of bacteria and exudates through these pores play an important mechanism of spread of infection in Lobar pneumonia and spread of fibrin in the grey hepatisation phase.

questions.text: An intern uses the following instrument to catheterize a patient during his surgery rotation. What is the size of the catheter used?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is the Foley catheter having an orange-colored ring in the ballon port, indicating its size to be 16 F.

Related Pearl: Foley's Catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the outer diameter in millimetres, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter.

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 18 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 18 mm and a diameter of 6 mm. 

Note:

Colour of the foleys is the colour at the baloon port as shown in the figure below

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with complaints of daydreaming in the class as reported by his teacher. Examination revealed that the child had episodes of sudden brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control, which were induced by hyperventilation.  Such episodes lasted for a few seconds, and there was no post-ictal confusion. The child is most likely suffering from
questions.solution:
Sudden, brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control and no post-ictal confusion is seen in Absence seizures. Usually, the seizure lasts only a few seconds.

The seizures may occur about 100 times a day, and the child is unaware. The seizures are so subtle, that may go unrecognized by parents. Most common complaints include "daydreaming" and a decline in school performance recognized by a teacher. The seizures can be provoked by hyperventilation.

EEG shows generalized symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern. Hyperventilation provokes these EEG discharges and seizures.

 

 

Other options:

  • Syncope is defined as transient, self-limited loss of consciousness due to a sudden decrease in cerebral blood flow. There is loss of postural control, and patients may faint.
  • Myoclonic seizures have preserved consciousness. They involve a sudden brief jerking movement involving the entire body or a part of it.
  • Atonic seizures are characterized by a sudden loss of postural control.

questions.text: A senior resident asks you to do a slit-lamp examination on a 40-year-old patient. On performing slit lamp examination, you notice the following finding over the cornea. It is due to ________

choices.text: Cellular deposits on the corneal stroma
Cellular deposits on the cornel Descemet’s membrane
Cellular deposits on the corneal endothelium
Cellular deposits on the corneal Bowman's membrane

questions.solution:
The given slit lamp image shows keratic precipitates due to cellular deposits on the corneal endothelium.

keratic precipitates are usually arranged in a triangular fashion, occupying the inferior parts of the cornea with apex pointing up (Arlt's triangle) under the influence of gravity and aqueous humor

An exception for this distribution is seen in patients with Fuchs uveitis syndrome. In this condition, keratic precipitates are diffusely distributed.
