questions.text: A researcher is studying DNA replication in prokaryotic cells. Which of the following enzymes is responsible for the unwinding of DNA?
questions.solution:
Helicase is responsible for the ATP-driven unwinding of DNA.

Other options

Option A: DNA Polymerase I (Pol I) helps in gap filling following DNA replication, repair, and recombination

Option C: Topoisomerase helps in relieving torsional strain that results from helicase-induced unwinding.

Option D: DNA polymerase III (Pol III) helps in leading strand synthesis and DNA proofreading.

Related Pearl: Enzymes Involved in DNA Replication

DNA polymerase II (Pol II) DNA proofreading and repair

Processive, leading strand synthesis, DNA proofreading
DnaG

Primase 
Helicase ATP-driven processive unwinding of DNA.
Primase Initiates synthesis of RNA primers.
Topoisomerase Relieve torsional strain that results from helicase-induced unwinding.
Single-strand binding proteins (SSBs) Prevents premature reannealing of dsDNA.
DNA ligase Seals the single strand nick between the nascent chain and Okazaki fragments on lagging strand.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male receives a cadaveric kidney transplant. The patient was negative for cytomegalovirus (CMV) immunoglobulin G (lgG) before transplantation. However, the donor was positive for CMV IgG. Which of the following drugs decreases the likelihood of CMV-associated complications post-transplantation?
questions.solution:
Valganciclovir is indicated due to the high risk for CMV owing to the lack of pre-existing immunity and receipt of an organ from a CMV-seropositive donor.

CMV prophylaxis is recommended in seronegative recipients receiving a transplant from seropositive donors (R-, D+), and also in seropositive recipients irrespective of donor serostatus (R+, D+/-).

In solid organ transplants, such as transplantation of liver, kidney, heart, lung, the seronegative recipients who receive organs from seropositive donors, have the greatest risk of developing the CMV infection. These patients receive oral valganciclovir, 900 mg daily for 3–6 months. The duration may be longer in lung transplant recepients.

Seropositive recipients are at lower risk, but still, usually receive valganciclovir for 3 months. The least risk of CMV infection is in seronegative patients who receive organs from seronegative donors. These patients do not need any CMV prophylaxis.

Other options:

  • Foscarnet and cidofovir are used to treat CMV infection in cases where the patients develop resistance to ganciclovir or valganciclovir.
  • Brincidofovir is a lipid conjugate form of cidofovir. It has more activity, and less toxicity compared to cidofovir.

questions.text: Which is the most common site for mucocele in the oral cavity?
questions.solution:
The most common site of mucocele in the oral cavity is the lower lip. It is a retention cyst of the minor salivary glands of the lip. The lesions appear as a soft and cystic mass of bluish color. Treatment is surgical excision.

 

The image below shows a mucocele of the lower lip

If the ducts of any salivary gland become obstructed they can develop a retention cyst. If such cysts occur due to the obstruction in the sublingual salivary gland, it is called a ranula. A ranula usually presents as a large, tense, bluish swelling on the floor of the mouth to one side on the midline.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presented to the OPD with complaints of change in color of the toenails for the past 3 months. Examination reveals onycholysis. He did not give any history of trauma. The Lactophenol Cotton Blue mount done from the nail sample reveals the finding shown in the image below. Which of the following can be the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Trichophyton rubrum is a dermatophytic fungus which is the most common pathogen in onychomycosis. 

The given history is suggestive of onychomycosis and lactophenol cotton blue (LCB) mount from the nail sample shows the presence of slender septate hyphae with a few pencil-shaped macroconidia is characteristic of T. rubrum.

Trichophyton species can infect skin, hair, and nails.

Other options:

Option A: Microsporum shows abundant, thick-walled, spindle-shaped macroconidia with septa. Microsporum species infect the hair and skin but usually not the nails.

Option B: Trichosporon beigelii causes white piedra.

Option D: Epidermophyton shows club-shaped macroconidia in clusters. Microconidia are absent. It infects the skin and nails, but not the hair.

Related Pearl: Characteristic features of macroconidia and microconidia of dermatophytes

Scanty

Absent

Trichophyton

questions.text: A patient with a history of migraine headache was advised 20 mg of sumatriptan nasal spray for acute attacks. The patient enquires regarding the possible side effects and you inform her regarding the possible ones. Which of the following would you mention as the most common side effect of sumatriptan nasal spray, that she should watch out for?
questions.solution:
The most common side effect of sumatriptan nasal spray is a bitter taste.

Triptans are selective 5HT 1B/1D agonists. They are indicated in the management of acute attacks of migraine.

The side effect of Triptans: Commonly, minor side effects are seen with triptans in the acute treatment of migraine. The most common side effect of sumatriptan nasal spray is a bitter taste.

After subcutaneous injection of sumatriptan - irritation can occur at the site of injection (transient mild pain, stinging, or burning sensations). Triptans can cause paresthesias, asthenia, and fatigue. Pressure, tightness, or pain in the chest, neck, and jaw have also been noted.

Coronary artery disease/ IHD/ Arrhythmia: Serious cardiac events are rare, but have been associated with the use of 5HT1 agonists, including coronary artery vasospasm, transient myocardial ischemia, atrial and ventricular arrhythmias, and myocardial infarction, mainly in patients with risk factors for coronary artery disease.

Hypertensive and Ischemic Diseases: The triptans are contraindicated in patients with a history of ischemic or vasospastic coronary artery disease (history of stroke or transient ischemic attacks), cerebrovascular or peripheral vascular disease, hemiplegic or basilar migraines, or ischemic bowel diseases. Triptans are also contraindicated in patients with uncontrolled hypertension.

Hepatic/Renal Conditions: Naratriptan is contraindicated in patients with severe renal or hepatic impairment (rizatriptan should also be used with caution). Eletriptan is contraindicated in hepatic disease.

Serotonin syndrome: Rarely, triptans can cause serotonin syndrome (due to excess of serotonin at 5HT receptors), particularly when used in combination with SSRIs, SNRIs, TCAs, and MAO inhibitors.

Drug Interactions: All triptans are contraindicated in patients with simultaneous or prior exposure to ergot alkaloids, other triptans or 5HT agonists, SSRIs, and SNRIs. Almotriptan, rizatriptan, sumatriptan, and zolmitriptan are contraindicated with MAO inhibitor (within the preceding 2 weeks).

Pregnancy and Breastfeeding: The triptans are classified as a pregnancy category C drug ( there are no adequate and well-controlled studies in pregnant women and are to be used during pregnancy only if the potential benefit justifies a potential risk to the fetus). They should be used with caution in nursing mothers (sumatriptan has the best safety profile in pregnancy).

questions.text: Which of the following is true about vitamin B6?

choices.text: It is primarily stored in the liver
Serves as a coenzyme in transamination reactions
It has no role in heme synthesis

questions.solution:
Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), an active form of pyridoxine(Vitamin B6) serves as a coenzyme in transamination reactions.

Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) is a coenzyme for enzymes involved in the following:

  • Transamination 
  • Decarboxylation
  • Glycogenolysis: Glycogen phosphorylase
  • Transsulfuration reaction: Cystathionine β-synthase and cystathionase
  • Heme synthesis: ALA synthase, (deficiency causes microcytic hypochromic anemia)
  • Tryptophan metabolism: Kynureninase, (deficiency causes pellagra like symptoms)

Other options:

Vitamin B6 is primarily stored in the muscle and is released during fasting.

It activates glycogen phosphorylase, an enzyme involved in glycogen breakdown.

It doesn't catalyze reactions of gluconeogenesis, but acts as a coenzyme for transamination reactions, giving rise to substrates of gluconeogenesis.

Note: Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) serves as a coenzyme in many amino acid metabolisms, so its RDA mainly depends on daily protein intake.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for alprostadil use?

choices.text: Maintaining the patency of ductus arteriosus

questions.solution:
Alprostadil is used for the temporary maintenance of the patency of the ductus arteriosus in neonates, keeping the ductus arteriosus open. 

Alprostadil is a natural PGE1 analog. PGE1 is a potent and specific relaxant of ductal smooth muscle.

The ductus arteriosus (the fetal connection between the pulmonary artery and the descending aorta) is functionally closed at 10-15 hrs after birth and anatomically closed at 10-21 days after birth.

Survival of newborns with certain heart lesions such as coarctation of the aorta, hypoplastic left heart syndrome,  and transposition of great vessels depends on the patency of ductus arteriosus. Closure of ductus arteriosus in such conditions can lead to hypoperfusion, severe hypoxia, and cyanosis. Maintaining the patency of ductus arteriosus in neonates is essential in some congenital heart diseases before corrective surgery is performed, and alprostadil is used for this purpose.

Alprostadil is also used in the treatment of critical limb ischemia, erectile dysfunction, and pulmonary hypertension. Treatment with alprostadil results in an improvement in ulcers, pain, and limb salvage rates in critical limb ischemia patients.

Side effects of alprostadil include pain, bruising, and priapism. If priapism occurs, the patient will need urgent medical attention, which might include aspiration of blood, surgical shunt, or intracavernosal injection of phenylephrine for cavernosal vasoconstriction.

PGE1 analogs like alprostadil, misoprostol, and rioprostil can also be used to keep the ductus open and support systemic blood supply.

Other options:

Option A: PGF2α analog carboprost is used as an abortifacient in the second trimester.

Option B: Indomethacin a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug is used for the closure of patent ductus arteriosus.

Option D: Dinoprostone (PGE2) can be used for the induction of labor.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl born out of a second degree consanguineous marriage is found to have a staggering gait, hand clumsiness, dysarthria, kyphoscoliosis, and pes cavus on examination. Disease involving GAA trinucleotide repeat is suspected. The following features are true for this disease except for _________

choices.text: Absent or Depressed deep tendon reflexes

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of Friedreich ataxia. It is related to chromosome 9q13.

It is an autosomal-recessive disease with progressive ataxia, spasticity, weakness, sensory neuropathy, and cardiomyopathy. Deep tendon reflexes are depressed or absent, but an extensor plantar reflex is typically present.

Friedreich ataxia is caused by the expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat in the first intron of a gene on chromosome 9q13 that encodes frataxin. Most affected individuals develop pes cavus and kyphoscoliosis.

The accompanying cardiomyopathy is associated with a high incidence of arrhythmias and congestive heart failure, which contribute to the deaths of most affected individuals.

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady came from the UK after a long flight. She suffered from breathing difficulty and her oxygen saturation was measured to be low. She has a past history of deep vein thrombosis. Her CT scan was done as shown below. Which of the following is true regarding her V/Q ratio?
questions.solution:
The given patient with a classical history of dyspnea and CT thorax showing a saddle embolus (red arrows) in the pulmonary artery. The V/Q ratio will be infinity.

V/Q ratio is the ratio of pulmonary ventilation (V) and Pulmonary blood flow or perfusion (Q). The normal V/Q ratio is 0.8 for the whole lungs at rest.

In this case, as the blood flow to the lung will be impeded due to embolus, the perfusion will become zero or very low. As a result of a decrease in the denominator of V/Q, the ratio will become infinity.

In contrast to this, Whenever the V/Q is below normal, there is inadequate ventilation to provide the O2 needed to fully oxygenate the blood flowing through the alveolar capillaries (i.e. alveolar Po2 is low). Therefore, a certain fraction of the venous blood flowing through the pulmonary capillaries does not become oxygenated.

In either case, the blood will not be saturated with oxygen as a result of either wasted ventilation or wasted perfusion.

questions.text: You were asked to manage the patients diagnosed with choledochal cyst. In which of the following patients,  would you advise endoscopic sphincterotomy as a treatment option?

choices.text: 25 year old male with cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree
33 year old male with cysts limited to the intrahepatic biliary tree
45 year old female with caroli disease
30 year old male with intraduodenal choledochocele

questions.solution:
Endoscopic sphincterotomy is considered in the management of choledochocele i.e ( Type III choledochal cyst).

Choledochal Cysts are Cystic dilations of the extrahepatic and/or intrahepatic biliary tree. They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable upper quadrant mass, and abdominal pain.

Todani classification system divides choledochal cysts into five groups.

Type III cysts represent Choledochoceles, consisting of cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum. As type III cysts are associated with the lowest malignancy risk of any choledochal cyst, endoscopic sphincterotomy followed by surveillance is generally recommended over cyst excision with pancreaticoduodenectomy.

Other options:

Excision of all cystic tissues and reconstruction of biliary tree is recommended for extrahepatic biliary involvement as in Type 4B and in case of intrahepatic involvement, an additional segmental resection of the liver may be required.

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with recurrent episodes of heartburn and regurgitation of food for the past few years. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy was done, and the biopsy showed the following histopathological finding.  Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: This condition occurs as a complication of GERD
Obese white men are at a higher risk
Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma
It affects the area above the gastroesophageal junction

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and biopsy findings showing intestinal metaplasia are suggestive of Barrett's esophagus which increases the risk of adenocarcinoma, not squamous cell carcinoma.

Barrett's esophagus is a complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease, and it is estimated to occur in about 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD. Symptoms include heartburn, regurgitation and sometimes dysphagia. Obese white men over the age of 60 years represent the highest-risk group.

It is characterized by intestinal metaplasia within the esophageal squamous mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction. Microscopically, it is seen as the replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells. The greatest concern in Barrett's esophagus is that it confers an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

A histological image showing goblets cells is given below:

On endoscopy, Barrett's is recognized as areas of red, velvety mucosa extending proximally from the gastroesophageal junction. Such areas alternate with normal pale squamous esophageal mucosa. Diagnostic confirmation is by endoscopic biopsy. Biopsy reveals intestinal metaplasia characterized by the presence of goblet cells. Goblet cells are seen as cells with pale mucous vacuoles that stain blue. 

 

The sequential changes seen due to intestinal metaplasia in Barrett's is depicted in the histological image given below:

questions.text: B-scan can be used for all of the following except:

choices.text: Assessment of posterior segment in the presence of opaque media

questions.solution:
A-scan is used for measuring Axial length.

Ocular Ultrasonography has become a very useful diagnostic tool in ophthalmology.

Modes:

A scan (Time amplitude): It produces a unidimensional image and echoes are plotted as spikes

Uses of "A" scan

  • Axial length
  • Intraocular lens (IOL) power calculation: Biometry
  • Anterior chamber depth
  • Thickness of intraocular mass

B-Scan(intensity modulation): It produces a two-dimensional dotted section of the eyeball.

Uses of B scan

  • Assessment of the posterior segment in opaque media
  • Study of intraocular tumors
  • Localization of intraocular and intra-orbital foreign bodies

 

Images: (Top): "A" scan ultrasound amplitude spikes

            (Bottom): Normal "B" scan of the eye

questions.text: A 53-year-old patient presents with fever and cough, with a history of a visit to China and the consumption of pickled crayfish. He now complains of rusty sputum and cough which is suggestive of Paragonimus westermani infection. What is the infective form of this fluke?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is of Paragonimus westermani (oriental lung fluke) infection. Metacercariae encysted in crab or crayfish is the infective form.

Paragonimus westermani is a trematode. The transmission to humans occurs by eating raw or undercooked crab or crayfish containing metacercariae. The parasite is endemic to Japan, Korea, Taiwan, China, and Southeast Asia. Endemic foci of P. westermani are present in Manipur.

Definitive host: Man, and many other crab-eating mammals and domestic animals

First intermediate host: Freshwater snail

Second intermediate host: Freshwater crab or crayfish.

The adult worms live in the respiratory tract of the definitive host in cystic spaces surrounded by a fibrous capsule formed by the host tissues. Unembryonated eggs escape into the bronchi and are coughed up and voided in sputum or swallowed and passed in feces. 

Clinical features include cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis. There is viscous sputum speckled with golden-brown eggs. Demonstration of the eggs in sputum or feces provides definitive evidence.

Praziquantel (25 mg/ kg TDS for 1-2 days) is the drug of choice.

The following image shows the life cycle of Paragonimus westermani

questions.text: You were asked to evaluate a cyanotic baby during your residency and your examination revealed abnormal S2 along with grade 2 systolic murmur. The investigations also reveal an abnormal ECG. According to NADA's criteria, which of these findings in isolation would be sufficient to consider the diagnosis of congenital heart disease in this infant?
questions.solution:
Cyanosis is considered a major NADA's criteria and the presence of 1 major criterion is sufficient by itself to indicate congenital heart disease in an infant. Rest of the mentioned features are minor criteria.

  • NADA’s criteria is used to diagnose congenital heart disease in children.
  • The presence of 1 major or 2 minor criteria indicates congenital heart disease.
Major criteria  Minor criteria
Systolic murmur  grade 3 or more Systolic murmur < grade 3
Any diastolic murmur Abnormal second sound (S2)
Cyanosis Abnormal ECG
Congestive cardiac failure

Abnormal chest X-ray findings
 

Abnormal BP

questions.text: You use the ASA physical status (ASA-PS) classification system to assess perioperative risk in the patients during your anesthesia residency. Which of the following patients, you would classify as ASA-PS 3?

choices.text: Patient having massive intracranial bleed with mass effect
Patient having poorly controlled diabetes with retinopathy

questions.solution:
The patient having poorly controlled diabetes with retinopathy will be classified as ASA PS 3.

American Society of Anesthesiologists’(ASA) classification is used to define relative risk prior to conscious sedation and surgical anesthesia.

Other options:

  • Patient with massive intracranial bleed with the mass effect would be classified as ASA PS 5
  • Patient having well-controlled Hypertension would be classified as ASA PS 2
  • Patient with ruptured aortic aneurysm would be classified as ASA PS 5

Related Pearl: American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status Classification of Patients

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification is used to define relative risk before conscious sedation and surgical anaesthesia and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

ASA-PS Classification:

Class Definition Examples, including, but not limited to:
I A normal healthy patient Healthy, non-smoking, no or minimal alcohol use
II A patient with mild systemic disease Current smoker, well-controlled DM and HTN
III A patient with severe systemic disease Poorly controlled DM or HTN, history (>3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD or stents.
IV A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life Recent (< 3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents
V A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation Ruptured abdominal, thoracic aneurysm, massive trauma, intracranial bleed with mass effect
VI A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman lost her 3-year boy about 25 years ago. The boy died in front of her eyes after being hit by a bus while crossing the road by himself. During a psychotherapy session today, when the repressed memory was brought back to consciousness,  she relived the moment and immediately ran as if she were trying to save the child, and started crying. This phenomenon is called _________.
questions.solution:
The phenomenon described in the question is called abreaction.

Abreaction refers to a process by which a repressed memory or experience, that is particularly painful is brought back to the consciousness. During this process, the patient not only recalls the painful moment but also relives it, which is associated by an appropriate affective response.

The abreactive procedure may be done as a therapeutic procedure to relieve emotions. This can be done with or without medications. Medications such as amphetamine, amytal, diazepam, or ketamine may be used in this procedure.

The use of abreactive procedure has declined in the past few decades and is no longer routinely recommended by any guidelines.  

Abreaction is one of the therapeutics factors used in group psychotherapy, in which therapeutic sessions are conducted by one or two therapists along with a group of patients, usually with in-patients in a ward, or in self-help groups.

Some other therapeutic factors used in group psychotherapy include:

  • Altruism: It refers to a phenomenon where a person puts another person's needs before his/her own needs and finds value in helping others.
  • Imitation: It refers to conscious emulation or modelling of one's behaviour after that of another.
  • Cohesion refers to a sense that the group is working together toward a common goal.
  • Catharsis: It is defined as an expression of ideas, thoughts, and suppressed material that is accompanied by an emotional response that produces a state of relief in the patient.
  • Contagion: Process in which the expression of emotion by one member stimulates the awareness of a similar emotion in another member.
  • Transference: Projection of feelings, thoughts, and wishes onto the therapist, who has come to represent an object from the patient's past.
  • Universalization: The awareness of the patient that he or she is not alone in having the problems.
  • Ventilation: It is also known as self-disclosure, where the patient expresses suppressed feelings, ideas, or events to other group members. They share personal secrets that ameliorate a sense of sin or guilt.

questions.text: A young woman presents with fever, severe myalgia and arthralgia, and pain behind the eyes for 3 days. Lab reports show thrombocytopenia and leucopenia. NS-1 antigen has been detected in her blood sample. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this disease?

choices.text: The causative agent belongs to orthomyxoviridae
It is transmitted by Aedes aegypti

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of dengue and dengue viruses are members of the flaviviridae family, not orthomyxoviridae.

Dengue viruses are enveloped viruses that are transmitted from person to person by Aedes aegypti (tiger mosquitoes). 

Dengue is an acute febrile illness. The patient presents with sudden-onset fever, retro-orbital pain, muscle and joint pains, and a rash. Dengue fever is sometimes referred to as ‘break bone fever’ due to associated severe muscle and joint pain. The initial rash in dengue may appear as flushing erythema of the face in the first 2 days of symptoms. A second rash occurs 3-6 days after the onset of fever and appears maculopapular or morbilliform. Sometimes, lesions may coalesce and appear as white islands in a red sea due to generalized erythema with petechiae and islands of sparing. As the disease progress, it can be associated with leukopenia and thrombocytopenia.

Suspected cases of dengue are confirmed by the presence of NS-1 antigen or IgM antibodies.

The condition is self-limiting and the treatment of dengue is supportive management, with hydration and paracetamol for fever. If there is severe thrombocytopenia (<10,000) then platelets should be transfused. 

The image below shows erythema with petechiae in a patient with dengue fever showing white islands in a red sea appearance.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presented to the OPD with an asymmetrical nevus with irregular margins and variegated colour on her arm. Recently, the nevus had become pruritic. The histopathological examination of the lesion is shown below. Which stain would have been used on the biopsy specimen in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical features suggest a diagnosis of melanocytic nevus. In the histopathological examination, the Masson Fontana stain is used which is used for detecting melanin (seen as a dark or black pigmented area) as shown in the above image.

Stains used for melanin:

Masson Fontana silver stain: The ammoniacal silver stains melanin black. It is also used to stain argentaffin granules, which are normally present in endocrine cells in duodenal mucosa and pathologically seen in carcinoid syndromes.

Melanin:

  • In general, melanin is considered as the only endogenous brown-black pigment present in the hair, skin, retina, iris, and certain parts of the central nervous system (as neuromelanin). Pathologically, it may be found in skin tumors like melanomas.
  • However, another black-colored endogenous pigment called homogentisic acid may be seen in alkaptonuria, where the pigment is deposited in the skin, connective tissue, and cartilage; this pigmentation is known as ochronosis.

DOPA-oxidase method: It is the most specific method for staining melanin. The stain works on the principle that the DOPA substrate is acted upon by DOPA-oxidase in the melanin-producing cells which produce a brownish-black deposit. 

Schmorl’s method: Stains melanin blue-green.

questions.text: A 58-year-old female with type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to the ER with lethargy and deep breathing. She had undergone a contrast-enhanced CT scan one day prior. Biochemical examination showed lactic acidosis. Which of the following drugs is responsible?
questions.solution:
The most likely drug responsible for causing lactic acidosis in a diabetic patient with impaired renal function (due to contrast medium used in CECT) is metformin.

Lactic acidosis is seen with metformin when there are concomitant conditions that can impair tissue perfusion. Such conditions include heart failure, myocardial infarction and sepsis. Furthermore, metformin should be discontinued in diabetic patients who are being planned radiographic procedures that require contrast enhancement. Reduced GFR — as a result of chronic kidney disease, or because of contrast dye — leads to a reduction in the clearance of metformin. The levels of metformin rise above the therapeutic range and cause lactic acidosis.

Canagliflozin (option A) is an SGLT2 inhibitor. They lead to an increase in the incidence of urinary tract infections and genital fungal infections. Because of the increased diuresis, there may be hypotension. There may be an increased risk of fractures with these drugs. The adverse effects of pioglitazone (option B) include weight gain and edema. It causes an increase in fat deposition in the body. Since it causes fluid retention, it is contraindicated in patients with heart failure. Glibenclamide (option C) is a sulfonylurea. It can frequently cause hypoglycemia and weight gain. Being a sulfa-derivative, it can cause hypersensitivity reactions and hemolytic anemias. It can also cause a disulfiram-like reaction on concomitant consumption of alcohol.

Related Pearl: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

questions.text: A 19-year-old male, a chronic smoker, presented with fever, a painful lump over his left cheek just below the ear, and difficulty in swallowing or talking. The patient also complained of mild testicular pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of painful swelling in the parotid region (parotitis) together with testicular pain (orchitis) are most likely suggestive of mumps.

Mumps is a paramyxoviral disease, which spreads by respiratory droplets.

Patients experience prodromal symptoms followed by parotitis. It develops in 24 hours and is often bilateral. Other salivary glands such as submaxillary and sublingual glands may also be involved, but are less likely than parotid. Patients complain of earaches and difficulty in eating, swallowing, or talking. Epididymo-orchitis is the 2nd common presentation. The testis is painful and tender and may enlarge up to several times its normal size. Other manifestations may include CSF pleocytosis, encephalitis, pancreatitis, and myocarditis.

Diagnosis is made by the detection of viral RNA by reverse-transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR) or serology.

Treatment: The disease is self-limiting. Analgesics and application of warm or cold compress over the parotid and testicular swellings may help relieve the symptoms.

Other options:

Option A: Cervical tuberculosis may present as unilateral single or multiple painless lumps, usually in the posterior cervical or supraclavicular area. Night sweats, weakness, cough, and fever may be also seen.

Option B: Diphtheria presents with a sore throat and adherent tonsillar, pharyngeal, or nasal pseudomembranous lesions with low-grade fever. A few patients develop a bull neck. This results from submandibular and paratracheal edema and is associated with foul breath, thick speech, and stridor. Cutaneous diphtheria is characterized by punched-out ulcerative lesions with necrotic slough or a pseudomembrane.

Option D: Lymphomas present with enlarging lymphadenopathy centrally or peripherally depending on the type. They may be associated with B symptoms -fevers, drenching night sweats, and unintentional weight loss.

questions.text: All of the following are the uses of the instrument  given in the image except______

choices.text: To differentiate between chronic inversion and fibroid polyp
To measure the uterine cavity and the cervical length

questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is Simpson’s uterine sound. It is not used in the fallopian tube recanalization procedure.

Simpson’s uterine sound is a 30 cm-long angulated instrument. It has a handle at one end and a rounded blunt tip at the other. The angulation of the instrument accommodates for flexion of the uterus

Uses:

  • To measure uterine cavity and cervical length
  • To diagnose cervical stenosis
  • To sound a polyp, IUCD, or uterine septum
  • To break uterine adhesions in Asherman syndrome
  • To differentiate between chronic inversion and fibroid polyp.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic woman presents to you with complaints of a decrease in vision in the left eye. There is also a history of cataract surgery 1 month back on the same eye. Investigation reveals flower petal pattern on fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA). Optical coherence tomography done in this patient is shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and OCT image showing cystic spaces are suggestive of cystoid macular edema (CME) in a patient with a history of cataract surgery points towards the diagnosis of Irvine-Gass syndrome.

Optical coherence tomography (OCT) in CME reveals loss of foveal depression, intraretinal area of decreased reflectivity with round optically clear regions (cystoid spaces)

Irvine-Gass syndrome is the late postoperative complications of cataract surgery. The characteristic flower-petal appearance is due to the accumulation of dye in the outer plexiform layer at the fovea. CME occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier.

Ophthalmoscopy reveals loss of foveal contour, retinal thickening, a yellow spot at the center of the fovea, and Honeycomb appearance of the macula is seen due to multiple cystoid oval spaces.

 

Few other late postoperative complications of cataract surgery include,

  • Delayed chronic postoperative endophthalmitis
  • Pseudophakic bullous keratopathy
  • Retinal detachment
  • After cataract or secondary cataract

Note: Central serous retinopathy (CSR) shows fluid accumulation in the subretinal space due to abnormal permeability of the choriocapillaris. Fundus fluorescein angiography may demonstrate an enlarging inkblot pattern or smoke stack pattern. The OCT image showing fluid in the subretinal space is given below.

questions.text: During a surgical procedure, the surgeon noticed small nodules occurring near the upper pole of the epididymis of the left testis. It was grossly well-circumscribed, and he immediately sent a specimen from the lesion for histopathological examination. What is the most common benign paratesticular tumor he would suspect?
questions.solution:
The adenomatoid tumor is the most common benign paratesticular tumor.

Adenomatoid tumors are mesothelial in origin. They are usually seen as small nodules, typically occurring near the upper pole of the epididymis.

Grossly, they are well-circumscribed, but microscopically they can be minimally invasive into the adjacent testis. Adenomatoid tumor is one of the few benign tumors that occur near the testis.

Other options:

Option A- Liposarcoma is the most common malignant paratesticular tumor in adults. 

Option C- Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common malignant paratesticular tumor in children.

Option D- Adenosarcoma is a rare benign endometrial stromal tumor.  

Note:

The paratesticular region includes the contents of the spermatic cord, testicular tunics, and epididymis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with diarrhoea, steatorrhea, low-grade fever, abdominal pain and joint pains. Colonoscopy is normal. Duodenal biopsy revealed the presence of PAS-positive foamy macrophages containing gram-positive bacilli. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: IV glucocorticoids for 3 days followed by oral glucocorticoids for 1 year
IV meropenem for 2 weeks followed by oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for 1 year

questions.solution:
The clinical features and the duodenal biopsy showing the presence of PAS-positive macrophages containing gram-positive bacilli are suggestive of Whipple's disease. The current regimen for treatment includes intravenous ceftriaxone or meropenem for 2 weeks followed by oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) for 1 year.

Whipple's disease is a chronic multisystem disorder caused by a gram-positive bacillus Tropheryma whipplei. It primarily causes malabsorption along with central nervous system & cardiac problems.

The disease has an insidious onset, characterized by diarrhoea, steatorrhea, abdominal pain, weight loss, and migratory large-joint arthropathy. Patients may also have ophthalmologic and CNS symptoms. Few patients who develop a relapse after remission may present with dementia.

The diagnosis of Whipple's disease is made through a biopsy which shows PAS-positive macrophages containing  the gram-positive bacilli in the small intestine.

The treatment regimen includes ceftriaxone 1 g intravenously twice daily or meropenem 1 g intravenously three times daily for 2 weeks. It is followed by trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole 160/800 mg twice daily for 12 months.

Other options:

Option A: The use of IV glucocorticoids for 3 days followed by oral glucocorticoids for 1 year is not included in the management of patients with Whipple's disease.

Option B & D: Numerous randomized controlled trials have proven the failure of remission of patients when treated with tetracyclines or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole when used as monotherapy.

questions.text: What is the name of this medium shown below, which is used in the identification of Salmonella?
questions.solution:
Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium has been shown in the given image.

It is a type of selective and indicator media. 

Salmonella typhi reduces sulphite to sulphide in the presence of glucose and produces jet black colonies with a metallic sheen due to the production of H2S on Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium. It is an example of indicator media. It is also a selective media because inhibiting substances are added to inhibit the growth of unwanted bacteria.

It is a differential media as well, as it brings out different characteristics of bacteria. 

On the Wilson-Blair medium, S. typhi forms large black colonies, with a metallic sheen. S. paratyphi A produces green colonies due to the absence of H2S production.

 

On Deoxycholate citrate media and XLD (xylose lysine deoxycholate) , colonies show black heads due to H2S production.

Other options:

Option 1) PLET medium is used to isolate B. anthracis. It is a selective medium consisting of polymyxin, lysozyme, ethylene diamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA) and thallous acetate added to heart infusion agar.

Option 2) XLD (xylose lysine deoxycholate) agar is a selective growth medium used in the isolation of Salmonella and Shigella species. It has a pH of 7.4, with a bright pink or red colour due to the indicator phenol red. Sugar fermentation lowers the pH and the phenol red indicator turns yellow. Most gut bacteria, like Salmonella, can ferment the sugar xylose to produce acid but Shigella colonies cannot and therefore remain red.

Salmonella also metabolise thiosulfate to produce H2S or hydrogen sulphide, which leads to the formation of colonies with black centers and allows them to be differentiated from the Shigella colonies.

Option 4) Stuart Transport Medium is recommended for the preservation and transportation of Neisseria species and other fastidious organisms from the clinic to laboratory.

Composition of Stuart Medium:

  • Sodium glycerophosphate
  • Sodium thioglycollate
  • Calcium chloride
  • Methylene blue
  • Agar

Characteristics of Stuart medium:

  • This medium is a chemically defined, semisolid, non-nutrient medium which prevent microbial proliferation.
  • Because of this composition the medium ensures that microorganisms present are able to survive for a sufficiently long period of time.
  • Sodium thioglycollate produces a reduced environment so as to improve the recovery of anaerobes.
  • Methylene blue acts as oxidation reduction indicator.
  • Calcium chloride maintains permeability of bacterial cells and sodium glycerophosphate maintains the pH of the medium.
  • The medium appears colourless in the reduced state and blue in the oxidized state.

Related Pearl: Organisms and selective Culture Media

Appropriate culture media for various bacteria:

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of numbness around the lips and a tingling sensation in her fingers. She underwent parathyroidectomy for hyperparathyroidism one year ago. An ECG was done and is given below. What will be your immediate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and ECG showing a prolonged QT interval (QT interval more than 0.43 seconds) is suggestive of hungry bone syndrome i.e. hypocalcemia post parathyroidectomy. Acute symptomatic presentation of hypocalcemia is treated with IV calcium gluconate.

Symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia:

  • Mild circumoral or digital numbness
  • Paresthesia
  • Laryngeal spasms 
  • Cardiac arrhythmias 
  • Chvostek sign: This is elicited by gently tapping over the facial nerve in front of the tragus of the ear. There is hyperexcitability of the facial muscles, manifesting as a contraction of the muscles.
  • Trousseau's sign: This is elicited by making the forearm ischemic by applying a sphygmomanometer cuff to the arm and keeping the pressure above systolic blood pressure (SBP) for 5 minutes. The hand goes into a painful carpopedal spasm and assumes the accoucheur’s hand position. (shown in the image below)

Acute symptomatic hypocalcemia is an emergency and must be treated with:

  • 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate is given slowly through intravenous route
  • Calcium and vitamin D replacement is given orally
  • Magnesium supplementation may also be required due to the synergistic actions of calcium and magnesium

The continuous need for calcium or vitamin D, 1-year postoperatively is called permanent hypoparathyroidism.

questions.text: A child was brought to you with complaints of distal muscle weakness. Further evaluation reveals the presence of the following type of cataract in this child. What is the trinucleotide repeat mutation associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing a Christmas tree cataract is suggestive of Myotonic dystrophy, which usually shows CTG (trinucleotide) repeat mutation.

Other common trinucleotide repeat mutations and their associated conditions:

  • GAA- Friedreich ataxia
  • CAG- Huntington disease, Spinocerebellar ataxia
  • CGG- Fragile X syndrome.

Related Pearl: Diseases and Associated Cataracts - Images

Wilson's Disease/Chalcosis: Sunflower Cataract

Diabetes mellitus:  Snowflake cataract

Blunt trauma: May present as rosette-shaped cataract

Myotonic dystrophy - Christmas tree cataract

questions.text: Which of the following patients is least likely to benefit from radiotherapy and would be better served with a surgical approach?

choices.text: A 29 year old teacher with a lesion on the cords with preserved mobility
A 28 year old pianist with a lesion extending into the subglottic region
A 25 year old swimmer with a superficial exophytic lesion on the tip of epiglottis
A 30 year old ventriloquist with a superficial exophytic lesion on the aryepiglottic folds

questions.solution:
The 28-year-old pianist with a lesion extending into the subglottic region is least likely to benefit from radiotherapy and would be better served with a surgical approach.

Cases that do well with radiotherapy:

  • Cancer of the vocal cord without impairment of its mobility: 90% cure rate
  • Superficial exophytic lesions especially of the tip of epiglottis, and aryepiglottic folds:70–90% cure rate 

Radiotherapy does not give good results in :

  • Lesions with fixed cords,
  • Sub- glottic extension,
  • Cartilage invasion and
  • Nodal metastases.

These lesions require surgery

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl was brought to the OPD with complaints that the child always wants to stay with her mother at home, and doesn't want her mother to leave her alone. In situations where she had to be away from her mother, she becomes anxious and is worried that her mother might be harmed. She otherwise socializes well with her neighbours and friends who come to their home and makes her own decisions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are characteristic of separation anxiety disorder.

Separation anxiety disorder is characterized by developmentally inappro­priate and excessive anxiety when the patient is separated from their attachment figure. Separation anxiety is a normal developmental phenomenon in infants. It peaks between 9 months and 18 months and usually diminishes by two-and-half years of age. However, in some children, the separation anxiety may be excessive and persist beyond the normal age group, which is considered as developmentally inappropriate.

The clinical features include:

  • Fear or anxiety regarding separa­tion from their parents or primary caregiver (attachment figure), which is beyond developmental expectations. The symptoms should persist for at least 4 weeks.
  • They are usually worried that harm may come upon their parents after separation.
  • These children do not like being alone even at home, without their attachment figure.
  • They refuse to go away from their attachment figure, to school, hostel, or a friend's home.
  • When separation is anticipated, they may complain of physical symptoms and avoid separation.

 

Other options:

Option a: Dependent personality disorder is characterized by a pervasive pattern of dependent and submissive behaviour, where the patient cannot make his/her own decisions and excessively depends on another person for advice or reassurances. These patients avoid positions of responsibility. They also have fear of separation from the person whom they are dependant upon. 

Option b: Social anxiety disorder is characterized by the fear of social situations, including situations involving meeting new people, social gatherings, or involving scrutiny by strangers. 

Option d: Oppositional defiant disorder is characterized by negativistic, disobedient, and hostile behaviour towards parents or authoritative figures. The children frequently argue with adults and cause themselves anger and resentment.

questions.text: On noticing taurodontism in the postmortem reports of a body, you would suspect that the individual belongs to which of the following races?
questions.solution:
Taurodontism or bull tooth is most commonly associated with Mongoloid race. It is characterized by a wide and deep pulp cavity in molar teeth and fused and bent roots. 

Other common associations in Mongoloid teeth include enamel pearls, which are small nodules appearing on the tooth surface. This race is also frequently associated with shovel-shaped upper central incisors and a congenital absence of the third upper molar. 

Other options:

Negroid races are found to have large teeth, multiple cusps (up to 8) on their molars, and 2 lingual cusps on the mandibular first premolars.

Caucasians have smaller lateral incisors than central incisors (seen especially in females), and long pointed canine roots. They also have small nodules on the lingual surface of their maxillary molars known as 'Carabelli's cusp', which are most commonly associated with Caucasian races.

questions.text: While assisting your senior resident, who is conducting a breech delivery, you notice that she performs Pinard's maneuver to deliver the baby. This maneuver is done for _____
questions.solution:
Pinard’s maneuver is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of frank breech delivery.

Frank breech delivery (Pinard’s maneuver)—is done by intrauterine manipulation to convert a frank breech to a footing breech. Pinard’s maneuver is usually performed when the membranes have ruptured recently.

Technique:

  • In Pinard’s maneuver, the middle and index fingers are to be carried up to the popliteal fossa.
  • Then press and abduct the popliteal fossa so as to flex the fetal leg
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction and breech extraction is accomplished.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: A 55-year old man presents with the condition shown in the image. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Drugs like alcohol and heroin can lead to this condition.
Associated with high androgen- low estrogen states.
Associated with a small increase in risk of breast cancer.
Anabolic steroids can lead to this condition

questions.solution:
The image above depicts gynecomastia in a male patient. Gynecomastia occurs as a result of an imbalance between estrogens, which stimulate breast tissue, and androgens, which counteract these effects. In older males, gynecomastia can occur due to a relative increase in estrogens and a decrease in testicular androgen production.

The most common causes are as follows:

  • Cirrhosis of the liver
  • Alcohol
  • Marijuana, heroin
  • Antiretroviral therapy
  • Anabolic steroids
  • Klinefelter syndrome (XXY karyotype)
  • Functioning testicular neoplasms, such as the Leydig cell or Sertoli cell tumors.

Microscopically, there is an increase in dense collagenous connective tissue associated with epithelial hyperplasia of the duct lining with characteristic tapering micro-papillae. Lobule formation is almost never observed.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male patient with cirrhosis presented with increasing abdominal distension for the past 3 weeks. Examination revealed mild jaundice and low-grade pyrexia. The patient is haemodynamically stable.  A diagnosis of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis was made based on ascitic fluid analysis. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ascitic fluid neutrophil count > 250/μL indicates the diagnosis of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.

Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is the spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intraabdominal source. The most common organisms are E.coli and other gut bacteria.

Abdominal paracentesis is the investigation of choice. The diagnosis of SBP is made when the ascitic fluid has an absolute neutrophil count >250/μL.

Management: The first line of empirical treatment is with a third-generation cephalosporin or a combination of beta-lactam/beta-lactamase agent. In patients who have had an episode of SBP and recovered, prophylactic antibiotics are given to prevent a recurrence.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient presents to the OPD with complains of pain in the right hip following a fall from her bed. On examination, the limb was shortened and in external rotation. X-ray was performed which showed an unstable inter-trochanteric fracture of the right femur. What is the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Unstable inter-trochanteric fractures are best treated with intramedullary implants like a proximal femoral nail.

The intertrochanteric fractures of the femur can be treated by intramedullary and extramedullary implants.

  • Intramedullary implants include proximal femoral nail and gamma nail which are used in displaced/unstable intertrochanteric fractures of the femur. Compared to dynamic hip screws, the intramedullary fixation with proximal femoral nails has smaller incisions, decreased blood loss, decreased femoral neck shortening, and decreased risk of infection.
  • Extramedullary implants include a dynamic hip screw which is used in undisplaced/stable inter-trochanteric fractures

The below image shows the proximal femoral nail with locking and stabilization screws.

Below image shows the dynamic hip screw. It has a long cancellous screw which glides freely inside the sleeve of the side plate.

Inter-trochanteric fracture

Fractures in the inter-trochanteric region of the proximal femur, involving either the greater or the lesser trochanter or both, are grouped in this category. In the elderly, the fracture is normally sustained by a sideway fall or a blow over the greater trochanter. In the young, it occurs following violent trauma, as in a road traffic accident.

Clinical features include a history of a fall or road accident, followed by pain in the region of the groin and an inability to move the leg. There will be swelling in the region of the hip, and the leg will be short and externally rotated. There is tenderness over the greater trochanter.

X-ray of an inter-trochanteric fracture

Complications include malunion and osteoarhtritis.

questions.text: A child is brought to the OPD with a history of impaired vision and severe photophobia. He has achieved all the developmental milestones at the appropriate age. Examination shows fair hair, light skin color, and pale blue eyes. Which enzyme is most likely deficient in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of albinism which occurs due to a deficiency of copper-containing enzyme tyrosinase causing a defect in melanin production. 

Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes. They have an increased risk for skin cancer.

Its symptoms are albinism with vision problems, which include:

  • Strabismus
  • Photophobia
  • Nystagmus
  • Impaired vision or blindness
  • Astigmatism

Neuropsychiatric manifestations are not seen.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was found to have the following  arterial blood gas (ABG ) test findings. The pH is 7.24, serum bicarbonate is 18mEq/L, pCO2 is 35mmHg. Which of the following is the most common cause of the given ABG presentation in children?
questions.solution:
The given ABG findings is suggestive of metabolic acidosis because the pH is low (acidosis) with low bicarbonate (metabolic) and normal pCO2 levels. Diarrhea is the most common cause of metabolic acidosis in children overall, because of the loss of bicarbonates from the body.

Acidosis can be due to either low serum bicarbonate/increased organic acids (metabolic) or high pCO2 (respiratory). The normal values in ABG are:

  • pH = 7.35-7.45
  • [HCO3] = 22-28 mEq/L
  • pCO2 = 35-45 mmHg
  • Anion gap = 4-11

The amount of bicarbonate lost in the stool depends on the volume of diarrhea and the bicarbonate concentration of the stool, which tends to increase with more severe diarrhea.

Causes of Metabolic acidosis include,

Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA)

  • Diarrhea (Loss of bicarbonate is compensated by chloride reabsorption)
  • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Urinary tract diversions (reabsorption of ammonium and hydrogen by the bowel)

High anion-gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA)

  • Lactic acidosis (hypoxia, malignancy)
  • Ketoacidosis (diabetic, starvation)
  • Poisoning (ethylene glycol, methanol, salicylate)

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

Related Pearl: Causes of Acid-Base Disorders

Metabolic acidosis

Metabolic alkalosis

Respiratory acidosis

Respiratory alkalosis

Ketoacidosis

Lactic acidosis

Chronic renal failure

Salicylate intoxication

Methanol/formaldehyde intoxication

Ethylene glycol intoxication

Diarrhoea

Renal tubular acidosis

Vomiting

Hyperaldosteronism

Loop or thiazide diuretics

Opiates, sedatives, anesthesia

High altitude

questions.text: A 30-year-old farmer presents with firm, painless nodules with purulent discharge on his left foot for 10 days. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows nodular lesions that have broken down to form draining sinuses with purulent discharge which is suggestive of mycetoma.

The nodules are painless and with time form papules and pustules which break down to form draining sinuses, with the discharge of granules. It is caused by various types of fungi (eumycetoma) or filamentous bacteria (actinomycetes).

questions.text: An annual symposium on diabetes mellitus is being conducted by a medical college. The event would most likely comprise of _______.

choices.text: A series of speeches on the topic with the chairman summarizing at the end
A series of meetings with emphasis on individual work within a group
6-12 people seated in a circle interacting with each other
4-8 qualified persons  discussing the topic in front of an audience

questions.solution:
A symposium comprises of a series of speeches on the topic with the chairman summarizing at the end.

A symposium is a series of speeches on a selected subject by experts. Each expert presents an aspect of the subject briefly, after which the audience is allowed to ask questions.There is no discussion among symposium members. The chairman makes a comprehensive summary at the end of the session.

Other options:

Option B - A workshop is a series of meetings with an emphasis on individual work within a group, with the use of external consultants or experts. It can be divided into small groups each with a chairman and recorder. Each individual solves a part of the problem and leaves the workshop with a plan of action.

Option C - A group discussion is described as 6-12 people seated in a circle interacting with each other in a face-to-face manner. Health interventions that involve long-term compliance such as cessation of smoking, obesity reduction; group discussions are considered valuable. There should be a leader to start the subject and to ensure equal participation, preventing side conversations and summarize the subject in the end. A recorder of the discussion is desirable.

Option D - Panel discussions take place with 4-8 qualified persons who sit together and discuss a topic in front of an audience. It has a chairman, moderator, and 4-8 speakers. There is no specific agenda or set speeches. The audience is also invited to take part after the main discussion.

Related Pearl: Principles of Health Education

(Mnemonic: PLS, Good Friend, CLICK MoRe!)

  • Participation
  • Learning by doing
  • Setting an example
  • Good human relations
  • Feedback
  • Credibility
  • Leaders
  • Interest
  • Comprehension
  • Known to unknown
  • Motivation
  • Reinforcement

Related Pearl: Health Education vs. Propaganda

  Health education  Health propaganda
Knowledge Actively acquired Instilled in the mind
Skills Actively acquired Instilled
Primitive desires Disciplined Aroused
Action Reflective behaviour; trained to use judgement before acting Reflexive behaviour;Aims at impulsive action 
Emotion  Does not appeal to emotion but appeals to reason Appeals to emotion
Behaviour Process is behaviour centered  Process is information centered

questions.text: During the evaluation of a 32-year-old HIV positive female with headache and nuchal stiffness, the CSF sample reveals the following on microscopic examination with India-ink staining. What is the most likely mode of acquiring this infection?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the presence of encapsulated yeast cells in CSF with India Ink staining are suggestive of Cryptococcosis which is caused by Cryptococcus neoformans. It is an opportunistic fungus that is acquired by inhalation of yeast cells or spores which are found as a saprophyte in soil enriched with pigeon droppings.

In immunocompromised patients, the infection is acquired by inhalation of yeast cells or spores.

Cryptococcal meningitis and meningoencephalitis are the most vulnerable forms of cryptococcal infection. It is insidious in onset and often seen in AIDS patients. The CSF profile may show modest elevations in mononuclear cells and protein levels.

The diagnosis is made by the identification of yeast cells in CSF with India ink stain or by the detection of Cryptococcal antigen using latex agglutination(CrAg).

Cryptococcosis in HIV patients needs aggressive therapy. It includes

  • Induction therapy: IV or Liposomal Amphotericin B with Flucytosine daily for 2 weeks followed by fluconazole for at least 10 weeks.
  • Maintenance therapy: Oral Fluconazole lifelong

The given life cycle is of Cryptococcus species – Cryptococcus neoformans (common) and Cryptococcus gattii.


Other options:

  • Infection by tick-borne encephalitis viruses belonging to the Russian Spring-Summer Encephalitis complex are transmitted by the bite of Ixodid ticks
  • Cat scratch disease is caused by Bartonella henselae. It presents as a febrile illness with lymphadenopathy following a cat scratch.
  • Primary amoebic meningoencephalitis caused by Naegleria fowleri is acquired by swimming in freshwater rivers or ponds. Naegleria invades the nasal mucosa and passes through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into the meninges.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is not essential for the transfer of fatty acids across the mitochondrial membrane?
questions.solution:
Acyl CoA transferase is not required for the transfer of FFA across the mitochondrial membrane. Acyl CoA synthetase is required to transfer FFA across the outer mitochondrial membrane.

Fatty acid oxidation happens in mitochondria. But long chain fatty acids are unable to penetrate the inner mitochondrial membrane. To facilitate its transfer, Acyl CoA synthetase is required to transfer FFA across the outer mitochondrial membrane. It converts fatty acids to an active intermediate by ATP hydrolysis and Coenzyme group tagging. 

Further transport of fatty acid inside inner mitochondrial membrane for oxidation, involves formation of Acyl-carnitine. The enzymes CPT-1 and CPT-2 are involved in carnitine adding and recyling from fatty acids. The enzyme carnitine-acyl carnitine translocase helps the fatty acid penetrate inner mitochondrial membrane.

Transport of acyl-CoA for oxidation using a shuttle involves formation of Acyl-carnitine. This is the only step degradation of a fatty acid that requires energy from ATP.

Related Pearl: Enzymes Involved in Fatty acid Transfer Across Mitochondrial membrane

Enzyme

Site of action

Action

Acyl-CoA synthetase (Thiokinase)

Outer mitochondrial membrane

Converts free fatty acid into Acyl CoA

Carnitine palmitoyl transferase-I

Outer mitochondrial membrane

Transfers long-chain acyl group from CoA to carnitine, forming acylcarnitine.

Carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase

Inner  mitochondrial membrane

Help Acylcarnitine to penetrate the inner membrane

Carnitine palmitoyl transferase-II

Inner  mitochondrial membrane

Along with carnitine palmitoyl transferase I oxidizes long-chain fatty acids in the mitochondria.

Scheuermann's osteochondritis affects the ring epiphysis of the vertebra.

questions.text: During an anesthesia posting, you are monitoring a patient in the OR, where you see your consultant administering him Remifentanil for a procedure. Which of the following options is incorrect regarding this drug?

choices.text: It is given by continuous intravenous infusion because of its short duration of action.
Remifentanil  is used for epidural analgesia as continuous infusion.
It is metabolized by plasma esterases
Age and weight can affect clearance of remifentanil

questions.solution:
Remifentanil is not used for epidural or intrathecal administration because of its formulation with glycine, an inhibitory neurotransmitter in the spinal cord.

  • The most rapid analgesic action is achieved by remifentanil. Analgesic action (peak) is achieved within 1 to 1.5 min following intravenous administration.
  • Remifentanil is metabolized by plasma esterases, with a t1/2 of 8–20 min. Therefore, elimination is independent of hepatic or renal functions.
  • Age and weight can affect the clearance of remifentanil.
  • It is routinely given by continuous intravenous infusion because of its short duration of action.

Clinical note: The rapid onset of action and the rapid recovery (within 15 min) owing to metabolism by plasma esterases of remifentanil makes it an ideal analgesic for short painful procedures. Remifentanil alone is insufficient for postprocedural analgesia.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. You notice that the senior resident uses the trauma scoring system which involves the energy of the injury as one of the components. Which of the following trauma scoring systems is being used here?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the mangled extremity severity score involves the energy of the injury as one of the components. 

Components of mangled extremity severity score :

  • The energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

 Note: A score of 7 or higher predicts the need for amputation.

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 1 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
3-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Injury Severity Score
  • Revised Trauma Score
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)
  • Age

questions.text: A 52-year-old diabetic male patient while undergoing hemodialysis, had a sudden drop in blood pressure and complained of leg cramps. Which of the following is the next best step in the management?

choices.text: Stop hemodialysis and check arterial blood gases
Discontinue ultrafiltration and start saline infusion
Continue hemodialysis and send blood for serum electrolytes
Check serum K+ and arterial blood gases

questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of hypotension which is the most common acute complication of hemodialysis. The treatment includes the infusion of saline.

Hypotension occurs due to hypovolemia, caused by excessive removal of fluids. Hypotension can be prevented by careful evaluation of the dry weight and by ultrafiltration modeling, such that more fluid is removed at the beginning rather than the end of the dialysis session. Removal of excess fluid may also cause muscle cramps due to a decrease in muscle perfusion.

Factors causing hypotension during hemodialysis are:

  • Excessive ultrafiltration with inadequate compensatory vascular filling
  • Impaired vasoactive or autonomic responses
  • Osmolar shifts
  • Excessive use of antihypertensive agents
  • Reduced cardiac reserve

The management includes discontinuing ultrafiltration, the administration of 100–250 mL of isotonic saline, or administration of salt-poor albumin.

Related Pearl: Hemodialysis vs Peritoneal dialysis

Difference between Hemodialysis and Peritoneal dialysis

Hemodialysis Peritoneal dialysis
Comparatively difficult access Easy access
Better clearance Good clearance
Short time for treatment Longer time may be required
Principle:

Solute removal through a semi-permeable membrane.

Principle:

Solute removal through a peritoneal membrane
Must be done in hospital Can be done at home
Complications:
  • Hypotension
  • Disequilibrium syndrome
  • Muscle cramps
  • Anaphylaxis reaction

Complications :

  • Peritonitis
  • Catheter-associated non-peritoneal infections
  • Weight gain
  • Metabolic disturbances
  • Residual uremia

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida is in the latent phase of labor for 8 hours. The latent phase would be said to be prolonged in her if it lasts for more than ______.
questions.solution:
The latent phase is said to be prolonged in nulliparous women if it lasts for more than 20 hours.

Friedman defined the prolonged latent phase by:

  • A nullipara who has not entered the active phase by 20 hours after the onset of the latent phase
  • A multipara who has not entered the active phase by 14 hours after the onset of the latent phase 

The first stage of labor consists of two phases :

1) Latent phase: It is considered to begin at the time the woman first perceives regular uterine contractions and is characterized by gradual cervical change (up to 5 cm of cervical dilatation).

2) Active phase: This follows the latent phase and is characterized by regular painful uterine contractions, cervical effacement, and rapid cervical dilatation from 5 cm to full dilatation.

Related Pearl: Abnormalities of first stage of labor

Labor pattern Criteria- Nullipara Criteria-Multipara Treatment
Prolonged latent phase >20 hrs >14hrs

Bed rest

Oxytocin or cesarean delivery 
Protraction of dilatation <1.2cm/hr 1.5cm/hr

Expectant management and support

Cesarean delivery for CPD
Protraction of descent <1cm/hr <2cm/hr
Secondary arrest of dilatation >2hr >2hr

Check for CPD:

If no CPD- administer oxytocin

If CPD present- cesarean delivery

 
Arrest of descent >1hr >1hr
 CPD- Cephalopelvic disproportion

questions.text: A transplant physician is studying the effect of increasing arterial perfusion pressure in an isolated denervated kidney. He starts at a pressure of  70mmHg and increases to 200mmHg. Which of the following is correct regarding measured renal blood flow?

choices.text: There will be minimal or no renal blood flow, as the kidney is denervated.
Increase in renal blood flow directly proportional to arterial perfusion pressure
Almost constant renal blood flow irrespective of arterial perfusion pressure
Irregular blood flow through kidney as regulation by nerves is absent

questions.solution:
Renal autoregulation maintains the renal blood flow to almost a constant level irrespective of arterial perfusion pressure within physiological limits.

Renal autoregulation is present in denervated and in iso­lated, perfused kidneys.

Feedback mechanisms intrinsic to the kidneys keep the renal blood flow and GFR relatively constant, despite marked changes in arterial blood pressure. This relative constancy of GFR and renal blood flow is referred to as autoregulation. It is due to the action of vascular smooth muscles in renal afferent arteriole, which respond to stretch caused by blood pressure.

Renal autoregulation is absent in case of paralysis of vascular smooth muscle. Paralysis of vascular smooth muscles abolishes its action i.e., autoregulation of renal blood flow and GFR. Vascular smooth muscles act through the myogenic mechanism of renal autoregulation. Paralysis of vascular smooth muscles can be brought about by the administration of drugs.

questions.text: You diagnose organic acidemia in a 3-day-old child, who presented with complaints of poor feeding and lethargy. Laboratory investigations in this child would most likely have revealed _________

choices.text: Hyperammonemia with normal anionic gap acidosis
Hyperammonemia with High anionic gap acidosis
High anionic gap acidosis with normal plasma ammonia levels
Normal anionic gap acidosis with normal plasma ammonia levels

questions.solution:
A child with Organic acidemia would show Hyperammonemia with High anionic gap acidosis.

Initial clinical approach to a full-term newborn infant with a suspected genetic metabolic disorder

 

Organic aciduria

  • In the degradation of essential branched-chain amino acids (valine, leucine, isoleucine), the intermediate metabolites are all organic acids.
  • Deficiency of any enzyme (except transaminase) in the metabolism of these amino acids causes the accumulation of organic acids.
  • Therefore, these disorders are called organic acidemia/organic aciduria.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with ascending muscle weakness for 2 days. On examination, the limb is flaccid.  Similar episodes were reported in the past, usually after prolonged exercise. What investigation should be done first?
questions.solution:
Flaccid ascending paralysis can be seen in case of hypokalemia. It causes periodic paralysis. Hence, serum potassium levels should be checked first.

Hypokalemic Periodic Paralysis:

  • This is an autosomal dominant disorder with onset in adolescence.
  • Males are more often affected because of decreased penetrance in females.
  • Two types:
    • Type 1 with mutation in voltage sensitive, skeletal muscle calcium channel gene CALCL1A3.
    • Type 2 with mutation in voltage sensitive sodium channel gene SCN4A.
  • Attacks are often provoked by meals high in carbohydrates or sodium and may accompany rest following prolonged exercise.
  • Weakness usually affects proximal limb muscles more than distal.
  • Ocular and bulbar muscles are less likely to be affected.
  • Respiratory muscles are usually spared, but when they are involved, the condition may prove fatal.
  • Weakness may take as long as 24 hours to resolve.
  • Life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias related to hypokalemia may occur during attacks.
  • As a late complication, patients commonly develop severe, disabling proximal lower extremity weakness.

Diagnosis:

  • A low serum potassium level during an attack, excluding secondary causes, establishes the diagnosis.
  • In the midst of an attack of weakness, motor conduction studies may demonstrate reduced amplitudes, whereas EMG may show electrical silence in severely weak muscles.
  • In between attacks, the EMG and routine NCS are normal. However, a long exercise NCS test may demonstrate decrementing amplitudes.

Treatment:

Mild attacks usually do not require medical treatment. However, severe attacks of weakness can be improved by the administration of potassium. Oral KCl (0.2–0.4 mmol/kg) can be given every 30 min. Only rarely is IV therapy necessary (e.g., when swallowing problems or vomiting is present).

The long-term goal of therapy is to avoid attacks. Patients should be made aware of the importance of a low-carbohydrate, low-sodium diet, and consequences of intense exercise.

Prophylactic administration of acetazolamide or dichlorphenamide can reduce attacks of periodic weakness. However, in patients with HypoKPP type 2, attacks of weakness can be exacerbated with these medications.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with pain in the right foot especially on walking. It exacerbates on wearing tight shoes and she feels as if walking on a pebble in the shoe. On examination, the pain increases on compressing, which also produced a click sound, which the resident mentions to you as Mulder's click. What is the cause of the presenting complaints?
questions.solution:
The given presenting complaints suggest it to be Morton's metatarsalgia.

Morton's metatarsalgia/ Morton's neuroma is a common problem, this is an entrapment or compression syndrome where it is affecting a single digital nerve (distal metatarsal interspace), usually the third. There is a secondary thickening of the nerve which forms a neuroma, this gives the feeling of a pebble in the shoe. Mulder's click is usually produced on examination when the neuroma displaces between the metatarsal heads.
