questions.text: A 72-year-old female was tested positive for COVID-19 two-weeks back. She developed pneumonia and was admitted in ICU for the past 7 days. After a few days in ICU, she developed ARDS and died a day later due to acute respiratory failure.  The patient is a known case of diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years. Which of the following conditions would you fill in the parts Ia, Ib, Ic, and II of the death certificate, respectively?

choices.text: Acute respiratory failure, ARDS, pneumonia, COVID-19
Acute respiratory failure, COVID-19, ARDS, pneumonia

questions.solution:
The conditions filled in Parts Ia, Ib, Ic, and II of a death certificate, in the given case, are ARDS, Pneumonia, COVID-19, and Diabetes mellitus respectively.

The immediate cause of death (Ia): In the given case, the patient died of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), which is entered in the part Ia of the death certificate. Acute respiratory failure is a mode of death, not a cause. So, it is not written in any part of the death certificate. 

Antecedent causes (Ib, Ic, Id): The antecedent causes of death, which led to the immediate cause, are filled from earliest to the oldest developing cause, in parts Ib to Id. In the given case, pneumonia is entered in Ib, while COVID-19 is entered in Ic.

Part II: It includes other significant conditions contributing to death but not related to the diseases or conditions causing it. In the given case, diabetes mellitus is entered in Part II of the death certificate.

 

 

Death certificate in COVID-19 related deaths:

 

Death resulting from COVID-19:

  • It is defined as a death resulting from a clinically compatible illness, in a probable or confirmed COVID-19 case, unless there is a clear alternative cause of death that cannot be related to COVID disease (Ex: Trauma).
  • A confirmed case is a patient with laboratory confirmation of infection with the COVID-19 virus, irrespective of clinical signs and symptoms.
  • A probable case of COVID-19 is a suspected case for whom the report from laboratory testing for the COVID-19 virus is inconclusive.

Conditions associated with COVID-19:

  • COVID-19 may cause the death of a patient mainly due to conditions such as pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), cardiac injury, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) etc. The most recent cause, which leads to death, is entered in Ia, while other causes that may have developed earlier, are entered in parts Ib to Id.
  • COVID-19 is entered in the lowest/last available field under antecedent causes.
  • Mode of death such as heart failure or acute respiratory failure is not entered in any part of the form.
  • Pre-existing comorbid conditions such as COPD, asthma, chronic bronchitis, ischemic heart disease, cancer, and diabetes mellitus etc. are entered in part II of the form.

Related Pearl: WHO Format for International Death Certificate

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with vague abdominal pain since the last 6 months. He also noticed spontaneously appearing and disappearing tender nodules (clots) under the skin, at different locations. His blood investigations reveal elevated serum levels of CEA and CA 19-9. Which of the following genetic mutations is the most frequently inactivated tumor suppressor gene associated with this pancreatic mass?
questions.solution:
The presence of abdominal pain, migratory thrombophlebitis, and elevated serum levels of tumour markers like CEA and CA 19-9 in an elderly man point to a diagnosis of pancreatic cancer with Trousseau syndrome. The CDKN2A gene present on chromosome 9p, is the most frequently inactivated tumour-suppressor gene in these tumours.

K-RAS is the most frequently altered oncogene associated mutation with pancreatic cancer.

Migratory thrombophlebitis, known as the Trousseau syndrome, occurs in about 10% of patients and is attributable to the elaboration of platelet-activating factors and procoagulants from the carcinoma or its necrotic products.

Molecular alterations in pancreatic carcinogenesis:

Pancreatic adenocarcinomas arise from well-defined non-invasive precursor lesions in small ducts referred to as pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN).

  • The K-RAS gene (chromosome 12p) is the most frequently altered oncogene in pancreatic cancer. This oncogene is activated by the point mutation in 90% to 95% of pancreatic cancers.
  • The CDKN2A gene (chromosome 9p) is inactivated in 30% of pancreatic cancers, making it the most frequently inactivated tumour-suppressor gene in these tumours. This complex locus encodes two tumour-suppressor proteins:p16 /INK4a and ARF.
  • Inactivation of the TP53 tumour-suppressor gene (chromosome 17p) occurs in 70% to 75% of pancreatic cancers.
  • SMAD4 tumour-suppressor gene (chromosome 18q) is inactivated in 55% of pancreatic cancers.

Following genes are associated with an inherited predisposition to pancreatic cancer:

  • BRCA2 mutation: some pancreatic cancer, breast cancer, prostate cancer, and ovarian cancers.
  • PRSS1 mutation: Pancreatic carcinoma starting early in life secondary to hereditary pancreatitis.
  • SPINK1 is only associated with hereditary pancreatitis, but not pancreatic cancer.

Interesting fact: Armand Trousseau, the physician after whom Trosseau syndrome is named, correctly suspected that he had carcinoma when he developed spontaneously appearing and disappearing (migratory) thromboses.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding necroptosis?

choices.text: Kinases like RIP1 and RIP3 are involved
It causes caspase-independent programmed cell death
Cytokine IL-1 plays an important role in the process
Necroptosis starts by ligation of TNFR1

questions.solution:
The fever-inducing cytokine IL-1 plays an important role in pyroptosis and not necroptosis. 

Necroptosis, also known as programmed necrosis, is programmed cell death without caspase activation. It shares features of both necrosis and apoptosis.

It resembles necrosis because of the following features:

  • loss of ATP
  • swelling of the cell and organelles
  • generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS)
  • release of lysosomal enzymes
  • rupture of the plasma membrane

It is triggered by genetically programmed signal transduction events that lead to cell death. This resembles programmed cell death, which is considered the hallmark of apoptosis. Hence, necroptosis is also called programmed necrosis.

Necroptosis does not result in caspase activation, and hence, it is also called “caspase-independent” programmed cell death (option B). The process starts with the ligation of TNFR1 (option D). Ligation of TNFR1 recruits two kinases called receptor-associated kinases 1 and 3 (RIP1 & RIP3) (option A).

Necroptosis begins similarly to the extrinsic pathway of apoptosis, i.e., by receptor-ligand interaction. The most well-studied is the TNF-TNFR mediated pathway. The pathway is demonstrated below:

Pyroptosis is a process of cell death that is different from apoptosis and necrosis. It is involved in the clearance of necrotic and infected cells. This type of programmed cell death is dependent on caspase 1. Caspases 4 and 5 are also involved and cause the death of infected cells. The pathway involves:

Cells infected by microbes → activation of inflammasome complex → activation of the caspase-1 → generation of biologically active IL-1 → fever, inflammation, leukocyte recruitment.

questions.text: A patient with a pituitary tumor has increased levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). This leads to the excess synthesis of thyroid hormones. Which of the following proteins is upregulated by the TSH to increase iodine uptake into thyroid follicular cells?
questions.solution:
The TSH upregulates the Na-I symporter (sodium-iodide symporter) to increase iodine uptake into thyroid follicular cells.

Na-I symporter (NIS) is the protein on the basolateral membrane of thyrocytes facing the capillaries. It mediates the entry of iodide into thyrocytes through secondary active transport. It transports two ions of sodium and one ion of iodine in the same direction (symporter) utilizing energy from the Na, K ATPase pump. TSH controls both the expression and retention of NIS in the basolateral membrane.

It is responsible for the uptake of iodide in the thyroid, salivary, mammary, gastric, and intestinal glands. It is regulated transcriptionally by the action of TSH.

The absence of NIS is implicated in causing congenital hypothyroidism. NIS is also upregulated in some thyroid cancers like papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. This is used in the targeted treatment of thyroid cancers using therapeutic doses of radioiodine, which will be accumulated into cancer cells because of NIS.

Iodide exit from thyrocytes into colloid occurs on the apical surface and is mediated via Cl-I exchanger. It is also known as pendrin. A defect in this protein is associated with Pendred syndrome (thyroid dysfunction and deafness).

The image given below shows the steps involved in the synthesis of thyroid hormone.

questions.text: Abdominal examination of a 28-year-old primigravida, who is in the second stage of labour, reveals Bandl’s ring between the active upper segment and the distended lower segment. Which would best describe this ring?
questions.solution:
Bandl's ring is a pathological retraction ring.

Bandl's ring/ pathological retraction ring is formed in cases of obstructed labor. The upper segment of the uterus contracts and retracts vigorously in an attempt to overcome the obstruction while the lower segment dilates.

With each contraction, there is myometrial shortening so that the actively contracting upper segment becomes progressively thicker and shorter. The passive lower segment is progressively stretched and becomes thinner. The junction between the two segments stands out prominently as a pathological retraction ring.

Clinically, the patient is usually in a lot of distress. She will complain of continuous pain in the abdomen and there may be features of maternal exhaustion. It is an indication of cesarean delivery.

Note:

Constriction ring/ Schroeder's ring is formed due to incoordinate uterine action when there is localized spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibers of the uterus. It is formed due to injudicious use of oxytocin and premature rupture of membranes (PROM).

Related Pearl: Constriction ring v/s retraction ring in uterus

  Constriction / Schroeder's ring  Retraction/ Bandl's ring
Nature Due to incoordinate uterine contraction Due to tonic uterine contractions and retractions
Cause Undue irritability of uterus due to injudicious use of oxytocin Obstructed labor
Location

Usually at the junction of the upper and lower segment.

Location does not alter once formed.

Always at the junction of the upper and lower segment.

Progressively moves upwards after formed.
Per abdomen Ring not felt Ring is felt
Per Vaginal Ring is felt Ring not felt

questions.text: Identify the culture medium shown in the given image_________
questions.solution:
Lowenstein-Jenson medium is shown in the given image. It is a selective medium used for Mycobacterium tuberculosis culture.The presence of malachite green imparts a green colour and makes Lowenstein Jenson medium a selective media by inhibiting other bacteria. 

Components of LJ medium:

  • Egg: Provide fatty acids and protein required for the metabolism.
  • Malachite green: Prevents growth of contaminants.
  • Mineral salt solution: Buffer.
  • Glycerol: Source of carbon, Favours growth of M. tuberculosis, but not M. bovis.
  • L-asparagine: Source of Nitrogen. 

Colony characteristics on LJ Medium:

Mycobacterium bovis forms moist, smooth, flat, white colonies on LJ media that break-up easily when touched. 

Mycobacterium tuberculosis colonies on LJ medium are dry, rough, raised, irregular colonies with a wrinkled surface, tenacious, difficult to emulsify, creamy white and buff-colored. (Rough, tough, buff). 

 

Culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis:

  • Solid Culture Media: Lowenstein–Jensen: A commonly used, egg-based, selective media. contains malachite green, which prevents growth of other organisms.  
  • Liquid Culture Media: Middle Brook’s media: Used for preparation of antigens and vaccines, and sensitivity testing. 
  • Automated Culture Media: BACTEC 460: Uses radioisotopes, BacT alert: A colorimetric method, BACTEC MGIT: A fluorometric detection method. 

Other options:

Option 1)

Thayer-Martin medium is shown in the image below. It is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae because the antimicrobials present in it, suppress the growth of other commensal organisms which may inhibit the growth of N.gonorrhoeae. Thayer Martin Medium selectively favors the growth of Neisseria by inhibiting the growth of gram-positive organisms with Vancomycin, gram-negative organisms (except Neisseria) with Trimethoprim and Colistin, and fungi with Nystatin

Thayer-Martin medium contains antimicrobials like vancomycin 3.0 mg, colistin 7.5 mg, and nystatin 12.5 units per ml of agar, in chocolate agar.

Loeffler's serum slope is an Enriched medium for the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheria

Advantage of Loeffler's serum slope

  • Rapid growth(6-8 hrs)
  • Best medium for metachromatic granules production

Disadvantage: As it is not a selective medium, if incubated beyond 6-8 hrs, it supports the growth of commensals also.

Liquid Culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis: Middle Brook’s media: Used for preparation of antigens and vaccines, and sensitivity testing. 

 

Related Pearl: Organisms and selective Culture Media

Appropriate culture media for various bacteria:

questions.text: A patient who presented with significant weight loss was started on parenteral nutrition, following which, he developed refeeding syndrome. What is the maximum nutritional support that should be started to prevent this condition?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario of refeeding syndrome, maximum nutritional support of 10 kcal/kg per day is recommended to prevent this condition from occurring.

Refeeding syndrome is a potentially lethal condition that can occur with rapid and excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition due to starvation, alcoholism, delayed nutritional support, anorexia nervosa, or massive weight loss in obese patients.

The patient is considered to be at risk of developing refeeding syndrome with either one or more of the following: 

  • BMI <16 kg/m2
  • Unintentional weight loss >15% within the last 3–6 months 
  • Little or no nutritional intake for more than 10 days 
  • Low potassium, phosphate or magnesium levels prior to feeding 

With excessive refeeding, there is an increased release of insulin due to the metabolic shift from fat to carbohydrate substrate. As a result, there is an increase in the cellular uptake of electrolytes including phosphate, magnesium, potassium, and calcium. Hence metabolic abnormalities are seen which include hypophosphatemia, hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia, and hypocalcemia.

These electrolyte disorders thereby result in myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, respiratory dysfunction, liver dysfunction, seizures, confusion, coma, tetany, and death.

Nutritional support should be started at a maximum of 10 kcal/kg per day, with the goal of gradually increasing levels to meet full needs within 4-7 days. Treatment includes the correction of underlying electrolyte abnormalities and nutritional support with supplementary thiamine, vitamin B, multivitamins and trace elements.

questions.text: A postpartum woman developed a severe headache and lactational failure. MRI revealed enlarged pituitary with a hemorrhagic infarct. She does not have any visual disturbance, ophthalmoplegia, or impaired consciousness. What is the most-likely management in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and MRI findings is suggestive of pituitary apoplexy in a post-partum woman. Since there is no evidence of visual loss or impaired consciousness, the most likely management in this case would be high-dose glucocorticoids.

Pituitary apoplexy is damage to the pituitary gland and the surrounding structures as a result of acute intrapituitary hemorrhagic vascular events. It occurs spontaneously, as in pre-existing adenoma or in postpartum cases (Sheehan's syndrome) or in association with other systemic diseases like diabetes mellitus, systemic hypertension, sickle cell anemia, and acute shock. 

Postpartum apoplexy is due to the hyperplastic enlargement of the pituitary gland (occuring normally in pregnant woman), which poses an increased risk for haemorrhage. Clinical features include:

  • Headache with signs of meningeal irritation
  • Lactational failure
  • Bilateral visual changes
  • Ophthalmoplegia
  • Cardiovascular collapse (shock) 
  • Hypoglycemia or diabetes mellitus
  • Loss of consciousness

Investigation of choice: MRI or CT shows signs of intratumoral or sellar hemorrhage, with pituitary stalk deviation and compression of pituitary tissue.

Treatment :

  • No signs of visual disturbances or loss of consciousness - high dose glucocorticoids
  • Signs of progressive visual loss, cranial nerve palsy, or loss of consciousness present - urgent surgical decompression

Note: Hypopituitarism follows pituitary apoplexy.

questions.text: During history-taking, a patient was responding to the questions with unnecessary and irrelevant responses. He gave excessive details before he finally answered the question.  Which of the following best describes the patient's thought disorder?
questions.solution:
The thought disorder known as circumstantiality best describes this patient's thought disorder.

Circumstantiality refers to a formal thought disorder in which a patient gives irrelevant and unnecessary details. This is before finally getting to the point or the correct answer. It may be seen in schizophrenia, obsessional distur­bances, and certain cases of dementia. An example is given below.

Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper, and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

A formal thought disorder is a disturbance in the formulation of thoughts and their expression. It is characterized by loosened associations, illogical constructs, and neologisms. Derailment, neologism, perseveration, and thought blocking are some examples.

Other options:

Option A: Clang association is a formal thought disorder where the thoughts are associated with the sound of words through rhyming, rather than the meaning of the words. It is usually seen in schizophrenia or mania. An example is "I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

Option B: Flight of ideas refers to a rapid succession of multiple associations, where the thoughts appear to abruptly shift from one idea to another. It is usually seen in mania. An example is "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

Option D: Tagentiality is a formal thought disorder where the patient says something that is related to the general topic. Although, the actual answer is not given. An example is as below.

Doctor: "How has your appetite been lately?"
Patient: "I usually have dinner with my wife, but now I eat alone"

questions.text: A 21-year-old male patient presents with low-grade fever, loss of weight,  dry nocturnal cough, dyspnea, and wheezing for the past 6 months  The eosinophil count is markedly increased along with a high level of serum IgE and filarial antibodies. Following treatment with diethylcarbamazine, he developed a severe allergic reaction. This is known as:
questions.solution:
Following treatment with diethylcarbamazine (DEC), the severe allergic reaction that may occur is known as the Mazzotti reaction. It occurs due to the death of microfilariae. The clinical scenario given above is suggestive of tropical pulmonary eosinophilia.

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia is a manifestation of occult filariasis. It presents with low-grade fever, weight loss, and pulmonary symptoms like a dry nocturnal cough, dyspnea, and wheezing. There is an increase in the eosinophil count, IgE, and filarial antibodies. The condition is treated with DEC.

Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice for filariasis. It is given orally (the dose is 6 mg/ kg body weight daily for 12 days). It has both macro and microfilaricidal properties. The Mazzotti reaction that may develop can be controlled with antihistamines and steroids.

Other options:

Option B- A Jarisch–Herxheimer reaction is a transient clinical phenomenon that occurs in patients infected with spirochetes like syphilis, leptospirosis, Lyme disease, and relapsing fever, who are treated with antibiotics. The reaction occurs within 24 hours of antibiotic therapy. It generally manifests as fever, chills, rigors, nausea and vomiting, headache, tachycardia, hypotension, hyperventilation, flushing, myalgia, and exacerbation of skin lesions. It is an acute, self-limiting condition.

Option C- Hoigne Syndrome is a pseudoanaphylactic or pseudoallergic reaction that occurs after intramuscular administration of penicillin G procaine or benzathine. It is not due to a penicillin allergy. 

Option D- Meyer's-Kouwenaar syndrome is a synonym for occult filariasis. It occurs as a result of a hypersensitivity reaction to microfilariae antigens. Microfilariae are not found in the blood. It presents with massive eosinophilia, hepatosplenomegaly, and pulmonary symptoms.

questions.text: A 40-year old female underwent total thyroidectomy and on the third postoperative day, the patient complains of numbness in her fingers and perioral area. Which of the following vessels would have been injured during the surgery?

choices.text: Anterior branch of superior thyroid artery
Posterior branch of superior thyroid artery
Superior branch of inferior thyroid artery
Inferior branch of inferior thyroid artery

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of postoperative hypoparathyroidism due to injury to the superior branch of the inferior thyroid artery.

The parathyroid glands are small yellowish-brown structures lying between the posterior border of the thyroid gland and its capsule.  There are

  • Two superior parathyroid glands 
  • Two inferior parathyroid glands

These are supplied by the superior branch of the inferior thyroid artery. They secrete parathormone which helps in the regulation of the serum calcium, by the release of calcium from bones.

questions.text: Which of the following effects indicate the stochastic effect of radiation seen in a person working in a diagnostic center and having an increased risk of radiation exposure?
questions.solution:
Heritable mutations are stochastic effects that occur as a result of radiation exposure.

The harmful effects of radiation may be classified into two general categories:

  • Stochastic effects
  • Nonstochastic or deterministic effects

Stochastic effects (chance or random effects): These effects of ionizing radiation are chance events. The probability of the effect increases with the dose. But the severity of the effect is independent of the dose received. There is no threshold. These effects are associated with damage to the DNA of cells.

Examples of stochastic effects include secondary malignancies and heritable mutations.

Non-stochastic/Deterministic effects (non-random effects): These effects are related directly to the absorbed radiation dose. The severity of the effect increases as the dose increases. A deterministic effect typically has a threshold below which the effect does not occur.

Examples of nonstochastic or deterministic effects include radiation-induced skin erythema, lens opacification, and transient decrease in sperm count.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the management of a dog-bite in a healthy individual?

choices.text: RIG should be administered IV within 7 days of the first vaccine dose.
Five-dose (Essen) regimen is administered IM on days 0, 3, 7, 14 and 28.
WHO prequalified vaccines are thimerosal-based vaccines for increased durability.
People with PrEP require RIG on exposure to the virus.

questions.solution:
The five-dose (Essen) regimen is administered IM on days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28 into the deltoid muscle of the individual.

Other options:

Option A: Rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) is never given IV. 

Option C: WHO prequalified rabies vaccines do not contain thimerosal. Thimerosal is a mercury-containing preservative used for its antiseptic and antifungal properties in many other vaccines but not in the rabies vaccine.

Option D: Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) of a previously immunized individual (PrEP or PEP) includes boosters on days 0 and 3, without RIG.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: A patient presented with the extension of MCP joint and flexion of IP joints. Which muscle is affected?
questions.solution:
The lumbricals and interossei muscles are affected.

The lumbricals and interossei muscles through their attachments to the dorsal digital expansions, cause:

  • Flexion of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints
  • Extension of the interphalangeal (IP) joints

In cases of ulnar nerve injury, these muscles may get atrophied leading to the extension of MCP joints and flexion of IP joints.

Note: The ulnar nerve innervates all the intrinsic muscles of the hand, except for 

  • First and second lumbrical
  • Abductor pollicis brevis
  • Opponens pollicis
  • Part of flexor pollicis brevis

questions.text:
A 56-year-old male patient successfully underwent elective CABG 3 days before. He is now acutely confused with a temperature of 102°F, SpO2 of 92%, and has also developed purulent sputum. CBC shows leukocytosis. Chest X-ray shows a new right-sided infiltrate. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

CABG - Coronary artery bypass-graft

SpO2- Oxygen saturation

CBC - Complete blood count

CTPA -  CT pulmonary angiogram

choices.text: Perform lung biopsy and start antibiotics after culture results
Start treatment as per hospital's local antibiogram for nosocomial pneumonia
Perform CTPA to rule out pulmonary embolism
Administer antipyretics and observe the patient

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of nosocomial pneumonia and the next best step in managing this patient is to start antibiotics as per the hospital's local antibiogram for nosocomial pneumonia.

Pneumonia is a lung parenchymal infection that can be community-acquired or nosocomial. Nosocomial pneumonia can be hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Treatment should be started as soon as possible due to the high mortality rate. Empirical antibiotics are first given and narrowed to specific antibiotics after the finalized culture reports. The initial empirical treatment is based on each hospital's local antibiogram (profile of antimicrobial susceptibility). This is done to guide the optimal choice of antibiotics and reduce the risk of creating antibiotic resistance and exposing the sick patient to unnecessary drugs. 

HAP occurs > 48 hours after admission to the hospital. The diagnosis should be made after excluding the possibility of any infections present at the time of admission. VAP is diagnosed when clinical features and positive respiratory samples consistent with pneumonia develop >48 hours after endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation.

Clinical diagnosis is made by clinical and radiological findings:

  • 2 or more clinical findings of:
    • fever
    • purulent sputum
    • worsening respiratory status
    • leukocytosis
  • 1 or more new/progressive lung opacities on chest imaging

The most common organisms responsible for HAP are Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Klebsiella pneumoniae. VAP is also associated with Acinetobacter species. VAP can be prevented by reducing the duration of intubation and preferring non-invasive ventilation methods. 

Related Pearl: Typical Pneumonia v/s Atypical Pneumonia

Typical pneumonia  Atypical pneumonia 
Extracellular organism  Intracellular organism
Alveolar exudates in air spaces Interstitial involvement
Neutrophilic in nature Lymphocytic in nature
High-grade fever Low-grade fever
Productive cough

Dry cough
hemoptysis   scanty sputum
Pleuritic chest pain Extrapulmonary manifestation
X-Ray shows large areas of consolidation X-Ray shows an interstitial pattern of involvement.

 

  • The most common cause of Community-acquired Pneumonia- Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • The most common cause of Atypical Pneumonia- Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
  • The most common cause of Nosocomial Pneumonia-
    • Overall- gram-negative bacilli (implicated as a group)
    • The single most common agent- Staphylococcus aureus (i.e., gram-positive cocci)

questions.text: A patient is admitted to the ICU with fever, cough with expectoration, and confusion for the past one week. During rounds, the senior resident advised you to add ceftazidime to the drug chart after sensitivity testing. Which of the following options is incorrect regarding this drug?

choices.text: It is a third-generation parenteral cephalosporin.
It has good activity against Pseudomonas
It has good activity against staphylococci
It requires dose adjustment in renal dysfunction.

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of pneumonia and Ceftazidime which has been added, is a third-generation cephalosporin that has clinically significant, excellent activity against Pseudomonas but poor activity against staphylococci.

It also has poor activity against B. fragilis. It requires parenteral administration and has a t1/2 in plasma of about 1.5 hours. This drug is renally eliminated and requires dose adjustment in renal dysfunction.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man has been on regular analgesics for knee pain for the past 3 years. There is a rapid decrease in urine output. On investigation, his urine/plasma creatinine levels were  42:1 and urinary sodium was 16 meq/l. What could be the possible cause?
questions.solution:
The given condition is Pre-renal AKI caused most probably by the regular intake of analgesics ( NSAIDs).

Urine/plasma creatinine ratio of >40:1 and Urine Na <20 meq/l is observed in Pre-renal AKI.

  Pre renal  Renal Post renal
Urine osmolality >500 mOsm/kg <350mOsm/kg < 400 mOsm/kg
Urine Na <20 meq/l >40meq/l Variable
Fractional excretion of Na <1% >2% Variable
Urine creatinine/plasma creatinine >40:1 <20:1 <20:1
BUN: Creatinine  >20:1 10 - 15:1 >20:1
Urine microscopy  Hyaline Muddy brown cast Normal or RBC/WBC

Causes of AKI are given below:

questions.text: After a recent event of severe floods in a metropolitan city, the local government has planned to implement certain measures which include floodwater diversion and storage, building new underground sewage lines with increased capacity, performing land surveys, and limit the construction of new buildings in flood-impacted areas.  The given measures are part of which of the following phases of disaster management?
questions.solution:
The measures given in the question, are part of disaster mitigation.

Disaster mitigation includes measures taken to prevent hazards from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies. Some of these measures include:

  • Flood mitigation
  • Land-use planning
  • Improved building codes
  • Reduction and protection of vulnerable populations or structures.

Mitigation measures aim to reduce the vulnerability of the system. It complements the disaster preparedness and response activities.

Other options:

  • Disaster response includes activities such as rescue and first aid, field care, triage, etc.
  • Disaster rehabilitation refers to measures that lead to the restoration of pre-disaster conditions. Some of these measures include water supply restoration, food safety, basic sanitation, and personal hygiene, and vector control.
  • Disaster preparedness is a long-term plan with ongoing multisectoral activities, which include the development of policies or programs for disaster management, prevention, mitigation, preparedness, response, rehabilitation, and reconstruction. The measures taken will ensure that the country is well prepared to face any future disasters, and effectively prevent or manage to reduce the impact.

Disaster management cycle:

questions.text: During your labor postings, you noted the Manning score of a G2P1 woman at 35 weeks of gestation to be 8 with normal amniotic fluid volume. What would be the recommended management?
questions.solution:
Manning score of 8 (normal is 8 to 10) is suggestive of normal or less risk of fetal asphyxia and a repeat testing at weekly interval is advised to a patient in 35 weeks of gestation.

Manning score, also known as BPP(Bio-Physical Profile) Scoring system refers to an antepartum fetal assessment.

Components of Biophysical profile (BPP)/Manning score:

(Mnemonic:BATMaN)

  • B - Breathing movements of the fetus
  • A - Amniotic fluid volume
  • T - Tone of the fetus
  • M - Movements of the fetus
  • N - Non-stress test (NST)

Each of these parameters is given a score of either 0 or 2 points, where an abnormal score gets 0 while a normal score gets 2.


Interpretation:

BPP Score Interpretation Management
8-10 Normal or Less risk of fetal asphyxia Repeat testing at weekly intervals
6 Suspect chronic asphyxia If ≥ 36 weeks; deliver, but if L/S < 2.0 repeat test in 4–6 hours
4 Suspect chronic asphyxia

If ≥ 36 weeks; deliver

If < 32 weeks; repeat the test in 4–6 hours
0-2 Strongly suspect asphyxia

Test for 120 minutes and if the score is persistently ≤ 4 then deliver regardless of gestational age

 

 

Note: The modified biophysical score has only 2 components i.e NST and amniotic fluid index only. It is considered abnormal (nonreassuring) when the NST is non-reactive and/or the AFI is <5.

questions.text: As a part of project work in radiology postings, you were asked to measure the biological risk of an individual i.e, the risk that a person will suffer health effects from exposure to radiation. Which of the following SI unit will be used for this purpose?
questions.solution:
The biological risk of an individual is measured by using the SI unit Sievert (Sv).

Different units of measure are used depending on what aspect of radiation is being measured

  • SI unit becquerel (Bq) or conventional unit curie is used for measuring the amount of radiation being emitted by a radioactive material.
  • SI unit gray (Gy) or conventional unit rad is used for measuring radiation dose absorbed by a person (that is, the amount of energy deposited in human tissue by radiation)
  • SI unit sievert (Sv) or conventional unit rem is used for measuring the biological risk of exposure to radiation (One Sv is equal to 100 rem).

Related Pearl: Important SI units for radiation

Quantity measured Old unit New Unit Conversion Description
Radioactivity Curie Becquerel 1 curie = 3.7 x 1010 becquerel  
Radiation exposure Roentgen Coulumb/kg 1 roentgen = 2.58 × 10-4 C/Kg Amount of radiation absorbed in air.  
Absorbed dose Rad Gray (Gy) 100 rad = 1 gray (or, 1 rad = 0.01 gray)  Amount of radioactive energy absorbed per unit gram of tissue or material.
Dose equivalent Rem Sievert (Sv) 100 rem = 1 sievert  Indicates potential danger to health.

questions.text: A 30-year-old hepatitis B positive patient presenting with severe abdominal pain is taken for an exploratory laparotomy, and an infarcted small bowel is resected. Tests are negative for p- ANCA. Arterial biopsy from the resected specimen reveals the following. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and the histopathological image showing fibrinoid necrosis of an artery with a mixed inflammatory infiltrate containing neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells along with negative p-ANCA are suggestive of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). 

PAN is a systemic vasculitis of small or medium-sized muscular arteries. It typically involves the renal (most commonly involved) and visceral vessels. It has no association with ANCA, but about 30% of patients have chronic hepatitis B. It is the most common vasculitis associated with mononeuritis multiplex. Impaired perfusion with ulcerations, infarcts, ischemic atrophy, or hemorrhages may be the first sign of disease. It characteristically spares the pulmonary circulation.

The patients may present with rapidly accelerating hypertension due to renal artery involvement or abdominal pain and bloody stools caused by gastrointestinal vessel involvement.

Other options:

Option A: Microscopic Polyangiitis is a necrotizing vasculitis that affects capillaries, small arterioles, and venules. It is associated with MPO-ANCA. It is also called leukocytoclastic vasculitis because of apoptotic neutrophils. All lesions of microscopic polyangiitis tend to be of the same age in any given patient, unlike polyarteritis nodosa where all stages of activity from early to late may coexist in different vessels or even within the same vessel.

The image below shows small vessel vasculitis with granulomatous inflammation with fibrinoid necrosis:


Option B: Behcet disease is a neutrophilic vasculitis affecting small- to medium-sized vessels that classically presents as a clinical triad of recurrent oral aphthous ulcers, genital ulcers, and uveitis. There can also be gastrointestinal and pulmonary manifestations, with disease mortality related to severe neurologic involvement or rupture of vascular aneurysms.

Option C: Giant cell arteritis is an inflammatory vasculitis of large vessels. It shows medial granulomatous inflammation which usually involves the temporal artery. It is commonly seen in females over 50 years of age who present with fever, anemia, and headache and may have tenderness over the affected artery, scalp pain, jaw, and tongue claudication. Untreated patients may develop ischemic optic neuropathy.

The image given below shows pan arteritis with infiltration of inflammatory mononuclear cells with giant cell formation:

questions.text: While examining  movements of the eyeball in the ophthalmology OPD, the final year PG resident asks you to name a pair of contralateral synergistic muscles. Which of the following options represent the correct pair?

choices.text: Right superior rectus and Right inferior oblique
Right superior rectus and Left inferior oblique
Right superior oblique and right inferior rectus
Right superior oblique and left inferior oblique

questions.solution:
Right superior rectus and Left inferior oblique represent a pair of contralateral synergistic muscles.

Yoke muscles are also known as contralateral synergists. They are pair of muscles, one from each eye, which contracts simultaneously during version movements

Examples:

  • Right MR and Left LR
  • Right LR and Left MR
  • Right SO and Left IR
  • Right IO and Left SR
  • Right SR and Left IO
  • Right IR and Left SO

(MR: Medial rectus; LR: Lateral rectus; SO: Superior oblique; IO: Inferior oblique; SR: Superior rectus; IR: Inferior rectus.)

Note: Version movements also known as conjugate movements are synchronous (simultaneous) symmetric movements of both the eyes in the same direction.

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby girl is being investigated for recurrent episodes of dermatitis. She develops blisters over the face, hands, and feet on exposure to sunlight. Parents report pinkish discoloration of the child's diapers. Characteristic "monkey-like" facies, delayed eruption and reddish discoloration of teeth are noted on examination.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of an 18-month-old baby with characteristic monkey-like facies, blisters over the face, hands, and feet on exposure to sunlight, reddish discolouration of teeth, erythrodontia, and pink stain in diapers are seen in congenital erythropoietic porphyria. 

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria also known as Gunther's disease is autosomal recessive porphyria due to the uroporphyrinogen III synthase defect. It presents with non-immune hydrops in utero or shortly after birth. Severe cutaneous photosensitivity is present. Uroporphyrin I and coproporphyrin I accumulate in teeth, bone marrow, erythrocytes, plasma urine, and faeces.

Portwine urine or pink stain in diapers is seen. When illuminated with UV light, the teeth show a reddish fluorescence phenomenon known as erythrodontia (as shown in the image below).


Other options:

Option B: Porphyria cutanea tarda also presents as blistering photosensitivity but typically manifests in adults. Moreover, erythrodontia is not seen. It is the most common type of porphyria, which is caused by a deficiency of Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase.

Option C: Erythropoietic protoporphyria presents as non-blistering photosensitivity, unlike in this case.

Option D: Acute intermittent porphyria presents with neurovisceral symptoms after puberty. It presents with abdominal pain and psychosis with no cutaneous features. It may be precipitated by drugs, decreased carbohydrate intake, and infections.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

(XLDPP)

(AIP)

(CPOX)
 Increased urinary ALA, PBG, and coproporphyrin III and fecal coproporphyrin III Both
Photosensitivity, neurologic symptoms, abdominal colic
Variegate porphyria
(VP)
Protoporphyrinogen oxidase
(PPOX)
 Increased urinary ALA, PBG, and coproporphyrin III and fecal protoporphyrin IX Both
Photosensitivity, neurologic symptoms, developmental delay
Erythropoietic protoporphyria
(EPP)
Ferrochelatase
(FECH)
 Increased fecal and red cell protoporphyrin IX  Cutaneous photosensitivity
Non-blistering Photosensitivity with skin lesions
 
Most porphyrias are autosomal dominant except:
  • ALAD enzyme deficiency porphyria
  • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria
  • Erythropoietic protoporphyria
  • X-linked protoporphyria

questions.text: The excitation of a particular cranial nerve leads to a decrease in the heart rate. Through which foramen does this nerve cross the base of the skull?
questions.solution:
Excitation of the vagus nerve leads to a decrease in the heart rate. The vagus nerve passes through the jugular foramen which is marked as 4 in the above image. 

Structures passing through the jugular foramen are the Inferior Petrosal sinus that continues as IJV, Cranial nerves IX, X & XI.

Other foramina marked in the above image:

  • 1 - Foramen rotundum
  • 2 - Foramen ovale
  • 3 - Foramen spinosum

questions.text: A severely injured person who is a victim of an assault is brought to the hospital. The medical officer on duty takes his dying declaration as he feels that the patient's death is imminent. In India, this dying declaration is accepted under?
questions.solution:
In India, the dying declaration is accepted under IEA section 32.

Procedure:

  • As soon the severely injured person is brought to the hospital, the medical officer should inform the magistrate to have a dying declaration recorded. Fitness of the declarant to make the statement should be examined first.
  • The doctor can record it himself or herself if he thinks that the person will not survive till the arrival of the magistrate. In such a case, the police or the doctor concerned must note down the reason as to why waiting for the magistrate for recording this statement was not feasible.
  • Treatment should not be delayed while recording dying declaration.
  • The doctor has to ascertain that the person is of sound mind (compos mentis).
  • If the person dies or becomes unconscious while recording the dying declaration, the doctor must record the information obtained upto that point.
  • Usually recorded in the form of a simple narrative in the patient's own language.
  • No suggestions, prompting, help, or leading questions from other people is allowed.
  • No outsider is allowed to be present
  • After completing writting, it has to be read back to the patient who has to approve it by signing/thumb impression. Signature of two witnesses is also mandatory.

Other options:

  • IEA section 139: Cross-examination of a witness
  • IEA section 114 A: Doctrine of Adverse Inference: When a rape victim states that she did not consent, the presumption is usually in her favor.
  • IEA section 45: Expert witness.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with gluten sensitivity presents with severely itchy papulovesicular lesions on extremities, knees, elbows, and buttocks for one year with histopathology showing subepidermal blister. Direct immunofluorescence staining of these lesions would reveal ________
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image is suggestive of Dermatitis herpetiformis and direct immunofluorescence staining of the lesion would show Granular IgA deposition in the papillary dermis.

Image showing multiple grouped papulovesicular lesions on extensor aspects associated with history of severe itching and sub-epidermal blisters on histopathology in a patient with gluten sensitivity are specific clues that point towards the diagnosis of Dermatitis herpetiformis. 

 

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens
Pemphigus vulgaris       Flaccid blisters, denuded skin,oro-mucosal lesions Acantholytic blister formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG on keratinocytes- fish net pattern Dsg3, Dsg1 in patients with skin involvement
Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase
Linear IgA disease     Pruritic small papules on extensor surfaces; occasionally larger, arciform blisters  Subepidermal blister with neutrophil-rich infiltrate  Linear band of IgA in epidermalBMZ BPAG2
Epidermo-lysis bullosa acquisita Tense bullae and erosions  Subepidermal blister  IgG and C3 DEJ – Continous and linear  Type VII collagen

 The images below shows clinical pictures of pemphigus patients.

  • Image A - oral erosions in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus
  • Image C - skin lesions found on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus

questions.text: A physiologist is studying the structure of a skeletal muscle sarcomere. He takes a cross-section of sarcomere at a level that appears dark as shown by the arrow in the image below. What will he find?
questions.solution:
The cross-section of sarcomere at a level that appears dark as shown by the arrow marks the A band. It consists of myosin surrounded by actin. 

Sarcomere is the area between two dark Z-lines. It is composed of thick filaments like myosin and thin filaments like actin, tropomyosin, troponin. 

The difference in the refractive index of various muscle fibers leads to cross-striations when viewed under a microscope. The various levels of section of the sarcomere and the myofilaments they are composed of are as follows: 

Sections Myofilaments
I band Only actin
A band (exculding H zone) Actin and myosin
AI junction Actin and myosin
H zone Only myosin
M line Thick filament linked with accessory proteins

Note: Pseudo-H zone is referred to the lighter areas around the M-line including the M-line.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions are Arbiskov cells seen?
questions.solution:
Arbiskov cells are monocytes seen in myeloblastoma or chloroma.

Chloroma, also known as granulocytic sarcoma, is a hematopoietic stem cell tumor, where myeloblasts are located at extramedullary sites. Orbit is one of the most common sites of occurrences in pediatric population. It is seen in AML - M2 most commonly. Other conditions associated are myelodysplastic and myeloproliferative syndromes. 

The image given below shows Arbiskov cells in chloroma.

questions.text: Which of the following instruments can be used for submucosal resection operation to remove bone or cartilage?
questions.solution:
Image B shows Luc’s forceps, which is used in submucosal resection to remove either bone or cartilage.

Other uses:

  • Caldwell–Luc operation (to remove mucosa)
  • Polypectomy (to grasp and avulse polyp)
  • Take biopsy from the nose or throat.

Other images:

  • Image A:  It shows Mollison’s mastoid retractor used in mastoidectomy to retract soft tissues after incision and elevation of flaps. It is self-retaining and hemostatic.
  • Image C: Image is of Tilley–Lichtwiz trocar and cannula, used for the puncture of the lateral wall of inferior meatus, at a point 1.5–2.0 cm from anterior end of inferior turbinate and near the attachment of concha with lateral wall.
  • Image D: The instrument is Rose’s sinus douching cannula used in irrigation of maxillary sinus, which should already have a nasoantral window due to intranasal antrostomy or Caldwell–Luc operation. Direction of the tip is indicated by the hook outside.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old African-American woman is at the risk of developing metabolic syndrome and has been suggested to switch to the Mediterranean diet which is rich in monounsaturated fatty acids. Which of the following describes the effect of monounsaturated fatty acids?

HDL - High-density lipoproteins
LDL - Low-density lipoproteins

choices.text: Increase HDL + decrease LDL + decrease plasma triacylglycerol
Decrease HDL+ decrease LDL + decrease total cholesterol
Decrease HDL + decrease LDL + decrease plasma triacylglycerol
Increase  HDL + decrease LDL + decrease total cholesterol

questions.solution:
MUFA (Monounsaturated fatty acids) causes an increase in HDL levels and decreases serum LDL and total cholesterol levels. Plasma triacylglycerols remain unchanged.

The Mediterranean diet is rich in monounsaturated fatty acids (from olive oil) and n-3 fatty acids (from fish oils and some nuts), but low in saturated fatty acids. It contains seasonally fresh food, abundant plant material, low amounts of red meat, and olive oil as the principal source of fat. When substituted for saturated fatty acids in the diet, MUFAs lower both total and LDL cholesterol and increase HDL. This may explain why the Mediterranean diet, is associated with decreased serum total and LDL cholesterol compared with a typical Western diet high in saturated fats.

Unsaturated fatty acids contain one or more double bonds. These are classified into monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFA) and polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA). Unsaturated fatty acids lower blood cholesterol levels by the upregulation of LDL receptors on the cell surface, causing an increase in the catabolism of LDL. Omega-3 (ω3) fatty acids also have an anti-inflammatory effect and decrease triacylglycerol levels.

Monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFA) contain a single double bond, Ex:

  • Palmitoleic acid (ω7)
  • Oleic acid (ω9)
  • Elaidic acid (ω9)

Polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) are divided into two types based on the position of double bonds (when counted from the methyl end of the fatty acid molecule)

  • ω-3 fatty acids: The first double bond is at the third carbon atom
  • ω-6 fatty acids: The first double bond is at the sixth carbon atom

PUFA lowers plasma cholesterol and LDLs, but HDLs, which protect against coronary heart disease, are also lowered. 

Related Pearl: Unsaturated Fatty acids

Unsaturated Fatty acids

Common name No. of Carbon atoms: Number of double bonds; Position of double bonds Family  Occurrence
Palmitoleic 16:1;9 ω7 In nearly all fats
Oleic 18:1;9 ω9 The most common fatty acid in
natural fats, olive oil
Elaidic 18:1;9 ω9 Hydrogenated and ruminant fats
Linoleic 18:2;9,12 ω6 Corn, peanut, cottonseed, soybean, and
many plant oils
γ-Linolenic 18:3;6,9,12 ω6 Some plants, eg, oil of evening primrose,
borage oil; minor fatty acid in animals
α-Linolenic 18:3;9,12,15 ω3 Linseed oil
Arachidonic 20:4;5,8,11,14 ω6 Animal fats,  Phospholipids in animals
Timnodonic acid 20:5;5,8,11,14,17 ω3 Fish oils, eg. cod
liver, mackerel, menhaden, salmon oils
Cervonic acid 22:6;4,7,10,13,16,19 ω3 Fish oils, algal oils, Phospholipids in brain

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the hospital by his wife. She complains that under stressful situations the patient's behaviour completely changes. He believes that he is a 7-year-old boy named "babu" and behaves like a child. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Dissociative identity disorder is characterised by the presence of two or more distinct identities or personality states that assume control of an individual's behavior. It was previously called multiple personality disorder.

The disorder usually begins in childhood, in those who experience overwhelming circumstances, such as physical or sexual abuse.

Patients with dissociative identity disorder initially present with symptoms of emotional and behavioural turmoil. Some patients may have memory gaps and incidents of out-of-character behaviour. The symptoms are characterised by different "alters" or alternate identities, controlling the patient's behaviour for varying lengths of time. The identities of the patient may switch under stressful situations, disputes among alters, and other psychological conflicts.

DSM-5 classification of dissociative disorders includes the following:

  • Dissociative identity disorder (multiple identity disorder)
  • Dissociative amnesia
  • Depersonalisation/derealisation disorder
  • Other specified dissociative disorders include dissociative trance, dissociative reactions to stressful events Etc.
  • Unspecified dissociative disorder

Other options:

Depersonalisation/derealisation disorder (Option A and C): It is characterised by

  • Depersonalization: Experiences of unreality, detachment, or being an outside observer of his/her own thoughts, feelings, sensations, body, or actions.
  • Derealization: Experiences of unreality or detachment with respect to surroundings, where the surrounding individuals or objects are experienced as unreal, dream-like, or foggy.

Dissociative amnesia (Option D): It is characterised by the inability to recall important autobiographical information, which is usually of a traumatic or stressful nature. The information that the patient forgets is too extensive and cannot be forgotten under ordinary circumstances. Some might forget significant personal information or even his/her own name. Although in dissociative identity disorder, there may be memory gaps, the key feature is that the patients switch between two or more identities, while in dissociative amnesia, the patient forgets his/her own identity.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the infarct shown in the image?

choices.text: This is an example of coagulative necrosis
Seen in organs which lack an end-arterial circulation
Sepsis is usually absent in this type

questions.solution:
The image shows a splenic infarct that appears white, wedge-shaped, and bland in nature. It is seen in organs with an end-arterial circulation (i.e. organs that lack collateral circulation)

An infarct is an area of localized coagulative necrosis. They may be red (hemorrhagic) or white (anemic) based on color. Based on the presence or absence of infection, they may be septic or bland, respectively. Splenic infarcts are usually white, bland, wedge-shaped, and subcapsular in location.

The spleen is an organ with end-arterial circulation. The occlusion of a major splenic artery or any of its branches causes the infarct. Vascular occlusion leads to an infarct due to the lack of collateral blood supply. Common sites where emboli lodges are the kidney, brain, and spleen.

Splenic infarcts are usually bland unless it occurs in a patient with infectious endocarditis. In such cases, septic infarcts are common. There is suppurative necrosis due to the presence of microbes in the necrotic tissue. The infarct gets converted to an abscess.

Red infarcts are seen

  • with venous occlusions (e.g., testicular torsion)
  • in loose, spongy tissues (e.g., lung), where blood can collect in the infarcted zone
  • in tissues with dual circulations (e.g., lung and small intestine), which allows blood to flow from an unobstructed parallel supply into a necrotic zone
  • in tissues previously congested by sluggish venous outflow
  • when the flow is re-established at a site of previous arterial occlusion and necrosis (e.g., following angioplasty of an arterial obstruction)

questions.text: A 40-year-old man undergoes ileal resection for refractive Crohn's disease not improving with medication. He suffers from steatorrhea later on, which occurs most likely because_____
questions.solution:
Fat absorption is facilitated by micelle formation by the action of bile. A lot of bile is re-used due to enterohepatic circulation. When ileum is resected, liver cannot cope up with so much bile production, as a result, micelle formation is hampered and fat absorption is decreased. This excess of fat is lost via feces giving rise to steatorrhea.

Enterohepatic circulation is necessary for the secretion of Bile salts. Bile acts as an emulsifying agent (separate the fat in small particles). Action of bile results in micelle formation. Micelles are cylindrical disks with core of digested lipid and outer surface lines by bile salts. These micelles solubilize and carries the lipid to intestinal lumen for absorption. However, in some individuals, steatorrhea may not result despite absence of micelles because the intestine has a large absorptive surface area, this is referred to as anatomic reserve

The enterohepatic circulation of bile salts is the recycling of bile salts between the small intestine (terminal ileum) and the liver by means of the portal vein. It occurs 6-8 times a day. The recirculation of bile salts to the liver reduces the demand to synthesize new bile salts.

Other options:

Chylomicron formation occurs throughout small intestinal mucosa, it will be decreased a bit but is less likely to cause steatorrhea.

Digestion of triglycerides occurs by the action of pancreatic lipase, which is unaffected in this case.

Intrinsic factor absorption occurs in the ileum. Its absorption will be decreased and Vitamin B12 deficiency might occur, but it does not cause steatorrhea.

questions.text: During a psychiatric assessment, a patient was shown a series of pictures to assess his personality. One of those pictures is given below. Identify the personality test.
questions.solution:
The image shows one of the cards from the thematic apperception test (TAT). It is a projective personality test intended to evaluate a person's personality through their responses to ambiguous pictures.

The TAT consists of a series of pictures that depict individuals of both sexes and of different age groups involved in different activities. The stories that the patient makes up concerning the pictures reflect the patient's own needs, thoughts, feelings, stresses, wishes, and views of the future. A sample picture from the TAT series of cards is shown below.

Other options:

Option A: The Rorschach test is a projective personality test that contains a series of symmetric inkblot cards. One of such cards is shown below. The examiner records the patient's description of these inkblots verbatim, which helps in the assessment of his/her personality.

Option C: Holtzman inkblot technique is a projective personality test that contains two parallel forms of inkblot cards. This test is not widely used.

Option D: Make a picture story (MAPS) is similar to the thematic apperception test. However, the stimuli can be manipulated by the patient, and is not widely used.

Related Pearl: Personality tests

Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI-2)

Uses Characteristics

The most commonly used objective personality test.

Useful for primary care physicians because no training is required for administration and scoring 

Evaluating the attitude of the patient toward taking the test

Objective test

Patients answer 567 true(T) or false(F) questions about themselves.

Clinical scales include depression, paranoia, schizophrenia, and hypochondriasis.

Validity scales identify trying to look ill (faking bad or malingering) or trying to look well (faking good) 

 

Rorschach Test

Uses Characteristics

The most commonly used projective personality test. 

Used to identify thought disorders and defense mechanisms

Projective test 

Patients are asked to interpret 10 bilaterally symmetrical inkblot designs (e.g., Describe what you see in this figure)

 

 

Thematic Apperception Test (TAT)

Uses Characteristics

Stories are used to evaluate unconscious emotions and conflicts

Projective test

Patients are asked to create a verbal scenario based on 20 drawings depicting ambiguous situations (e.g., Using the picture, make up a story that has a beginning, a middle, and an end)

The image given below is the first card, drawn by Christiana D. Morgan. It is a recreation of a photograph taken by Samuel Lumiere of violinist, Yehudi Menuhin, in 1928.

 

Sentence Completion Test

Uses Characteristics
Used to identify worries and problems using verbal associations

Projective test

Patients complete sentences started by the examiner

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman who was operated for femur fracture complaints of shortness of breath on the fourth postoperative day. She has chest pain and tachycardia as well.  Her chest X-ray shows dilated right descending pulmonary artery as shown in the below image. This is referred  as ______
questions.solution:
The given clinical features is suggestive of pulmonary embolism and the chest X-ray showing dilated right descending pulmonary artery in pulmonary embolism is known as Palla's sign.

Pulmonary embolism:

Pulmonary embolism refers to embolic occlusion of the pulmonary arterial system.

Most patients present with pleuritic chest pain, dyspnoea, and tachypnoea. The classical clinical triad of sudden onset of chest pain, dyspnoea, and hemoptysis is present in only few cases

Chest x-ray signs related to pulmonary embolism include:

  • Palla’s sign shows Dilated right descending pulmonary artery (Image below):
  • Hampton's hump is a pleural based, wedge shaped opacity with the apex of the triangle pointed towards the occluding vessel or hilum and implies lung infarction. 
  • Westermark sign (below image) is a chest X-ray finding in pulmonary embolism. It is defined by a hyper lucent area with decreased vascularity due to oligemia of the involved part of the lung.

 

  • Knuckle or sausage sign, describing a dilatation of a central pulmonary artery due to occlusion by the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with palpitations.  ECG shows a short PR interval and slurred QRS complexes as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome based on the clinical features and ECG showing the characteristic delta-wave. 

Short PR intervals and wide QRS complexes with delta waves (slurred and slow initial upstroke) are diagnostic ECG features of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome.

 

In this syndrome, there is an abnormal conduction pathway between the atria and ventricles called the bundle of Kent. Compared to the atrioventricular (AV) node, electrical conduction is faster through the accessory pathway. This setup facilitates the circus movement of electrical impulses. 

 

Treatment for WPW includes:

  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs from classes Ia (procainamide)and class III (ibutilide).
  • Electrical cardioversion if the patient is hemodynamically unstable
  • Radiofrequency ablation of the aberrant pathway (definitive treatment)

Other options:

Option A: AV nodal re-entry tachycardia (AVNRT) is due to a reentrant mechanism through multiple pathways connecting the atrium and AV node. The P wave is usually not seen, but sometimes appears as a pseudo-r' in lead V1 (black arrow) and pseudo-S waves in leads II, III, and aVF (blue arrows). Narrow QRS complexes (green arrows) are seen. It is the most common paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia for which vagal maneuvers such as the Valsalva maneuver and carotid sinus massage can be tried.

 

Option B: Junctional tachycardia, commonly seen in children with congenital heart diseases. It arises due to automaticity in the AV node. ECG shows narrow QRS complexes. 

Option D: In atrial flutter, sawtooth flutter waves are seen in leads II, III, and aVF with an atrial rate of 240-300 beats per minute. The condition is often associated with a 2:1 AV block and narrow QRS complexes.

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text: Which of the following cells originate from Monocytes?
questions.solution:
Microglial cells are possibly derived from the circulating monocytes which migrate into the CNS during the late fetal and early postnatal life.

The cells derived from the circulating monocytes are: alveolar macrophages in the lungs, phagocytic cells in the lymph nodes, spleen and bone marrow, Kupffer cells in liver sinusoids, and microglial cells in the CNS.

Neuroglial cells found in the parenchyma of the brain and spinal cord are broadly classified as follows:

  • Macroglia cells of ectodermal origin (neuroectoderm) and include the astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, and glioblasts.
  • Microglia cells of mesodermal origin.

questions.text: A man has been caught trespassing on burial places and graveyards, and was caught eating the flesh of a corpse. Under which section of the IPC is this crime defined?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Necrophagia. Necrophilia and Necrophagia are punishable under section 297 of IPC.

Necrophagia (necros =corpse and phagia = to eat) is a type of sexual perversion in which the person mutilates the body, sucks or licks the wounds, bites the skin, drinks the blood, and eats the flesh of his victim to derive sexual pleasure.

IPC section

Section it deals with

Punishment

290

Physical contact with another individual to obtain sexual satisfaction (Frotteurism)

Fine Up to Rs.200

294

Obscene acts including exposure of genitals to strangers so as to gain sexual satisfaction (Exhibitionism)

Up to 3 months of imprisonment or fine or both

297

Trespassing on burial places/ wounding the feeling of any person /indignity to any human corpse (Necrophilia, Necrophagia)

Up to 1 year of imprisonment or fine or both

 

Note: Section 298 IPC deals with the utterance of words with the intention of hurting religious sentiments.

questions.text: You are examining a 22-year-old college student whose oral cavity appears as below. You would suspect drug abuse and order a 'tox screen' for which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
The image shows a case of suspected meth mouth with a close-up shot of the lower right posterior teeth. Meth mouth is advanced tooth decay which is common in habitual methamphetamine users.

Methamphetamine is also colloquially referred to as 'ice', 'crystal', 'chalk', and 'meth'. It used to be known as 'speed' or 'go'. It can be taken by ingestion, intravenous injection, inhalation, or nasal insufflation. It enhances the release and inhibits the reuptake of catecholamines at the presynaptic terminals.

Advanced tooth decay or meth mouth is commonly seen in habitual meth abusers. It may be multifactorial and due to poor oral hygiene, dry mouth, consumption of high-carbohydrate carbonated beverages, jaw clenching, and tooth grinding.

Amphetamine intoxication is suspected in cases presenting with agitation, mydriasis, diaphoresis, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, and hyperthermia, similar to cocaine intoxication. Mental status may be normal or severely agitated and paranoid.

Other options:

Option A: Chronic use of LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) can cause a flashback phenomenon. When the person re-lives the experience under the influence of a substance periodically in the absence of drug intake for months or years it is known as the flashback phenomenon.

Option B: Phencyclidine is taken orally, smoked, injected, or inhaled. It may lead to acute psychosis and violence.

Option D: Chronic use of cannabis may lead to amotivational syndrome with lethargy, and lack of interest in day-to-day activities. Run amok is a psychic disturbance resulting from continued use or sudden consumption of cannabis and is characterized by a peculiar homicidal mania. The person is not held responsible for his acts since ‘run amok’ is considered a disorder of mind and not intoxication.

questions.text: In a patient with an acute exacerbation of asthma with severely compromised lung function who is not responsive to nebulized beta-2 agonists, which of the following is the steroid of choice for systemic use?
questions.solution:
The steroid of choice for systemic use in this above clinical scenario where there is an acute exacerbation of asthma (especially when the lung function is <30% predicted and there is no improvement with a nebulized β2 agonist) is hydrocortisone. 

Hydrocortisone has the most rapid onset (5–6 hours after administration), compared to 8 hours with prednisolone. It is given at a dose of 4 mg/kg initially, followed by a maintenance dose of 3 mg/kg every 6 hours. Intravenous therapy is usually given until a satisfactory response is obtained, and then it is replaced with oral prednisolone.

Mechanism of action of corticosteroids in an acute asthma attack:

  • Increases responsiveness to beta-2 agonists
  • Decreases mucous secretion
  • Decreases inflammatory cell response.

Steroids increase the transcription of beta-2 receptor genes and hence, increased responsiveness to beta-2 agonists. Beta-2 agonists, on the other hand, increase the effect of steroids by enhancing the action of glucocorticoid receptors. Theophylline increases the effects of steroids by activating the enzyme histone deacetylase, which is the target for steroids as well.

questions.text: Which among the following investigatory findings would you not expect to see in a patient with Paget's disease?

choices.text: Very low Serum calcium and phosphate

questions.solution:
Serum calcium and serum phosphate are usually normal in Paget's disease.

An increase in serum alkaline phosphatase indicates an increase in bone formation while increased excretion of hydroxyproline in urine indicates increased bone resorption.

Blade of grass/flame-shaped lesion on X-rays is typical of Paget's disease seen in the resorptive phase.

Pharmacological therapy includes the use of bisphosphonates (Zolendronic acid preferred) and calcitonin (Salmon calcitonin is preferred) which primarily reduces the rapid bone resorption and also increases the bone formation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with a history of post-coital bleeding had undergone a pap smear test whose reports were marked as class 4 according to Papanicolaou classification. This grade includes all of the following cervical lesions except _______
questions.solution:
Class 4 lesion of Papanicolaou classification system includes CIN 2, CIN 3, and Carcinoma In Situ.

Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia 1(CIN 1) falls under grade 3 of the Papanicolaou classification system. 

Papanicolaou Classifiactions are as follows: 

  • Grade I: Normal cells 
  • Grade II: Slightly abnormal, suggestive of inflammatory change: repeat smear after treating the infection
  • Grade III: A more serious type of abnormality, usually indicative of the need for biopsy
  • Grade IV: Distinctly abnormal, possibly malignant, and definitely requiring biopsy
  • Grade V: Malignant cells seen

Comparison of the different systems of classification

PAP classification CIN (WHO) Bethesda grading
Class I Normal Normal
Class II Inflammatory

Inflammatory

HPV

ASCUS
Class III CIN I

Low SIL
Class IV CIN II, CIN III, CIS

High SIL
Class V SCC

SCC

CIS: Carcinoma in situ, CIN: Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, SCC: Squamous cell carcinoma, SIL: Squamous intraepithelial lesion, ASCUS: Atypical squamous cell of undetermined significance, HPV: Human Papilloma Virus 

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)
