Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium

80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma

questions.text: Anti-larval measures are being taken to control the mosquitoes, which were breeding in a pond. All of the following are fishes, which may be used in biological control, except:
questions.solution:
Cyclops is a crustacean (omnivorous copepod), which belongs to the phylum Arthropoda. It is not a fish. However, the cyclops can also feed on larval stages of some mosquito species, and can be used in biological control.

The larvivorous fishes that can be used for biological control include:

  • Gambusia affinis
  • Lebister reticulatus (Barbados Millions)
  • Poecilia

Related Pearl: Mosquito Control Measures

  • Anti-larval measures
    • Environmental control
      • This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.
      • Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control
    • Chemical control
      • Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.
      • Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.
      • Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.
    • Biological control
      • The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.
      • These are used in conjunction with other methods.
  • Anti-adult measures
    • Residual sprays
      • Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)
      • Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes
    • Space sprays
      • Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.
      • Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.
      • Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.
    • Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.
  • Protection against bites
    • Usage of mosquito nets, building screens and repellants like diethyltoluamide (deet), indalone, dimethylphthalate, dimethyl carbate, etc.

questions.text: An investigator was studying the effects of various poisons on the enzymes of the glycolytic pathway. He plotted the graph for the enzyme catalyzing the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate after adding alanine, which is a non-competitive inhibitor. Which of the following graphs shows the effect caused by alanine?

choices.text: The type of plot will depend on the relative concentration of alanine and enzyme.

questions.solution:
Graph C represents non-competitive inhibition. The inhibition of pyruvate kinase by alanine is an example of non-competitive inhibition.

Non-competitive inhibition: When the substrate and the inhibitor are chemically not similar and have different shapes, the inhibitor binds away from the active site, i.e., at the allosteric site. This type of inhibition is known as non-competitive inhibition.

In non-competitive inhibition,

  • Vmax decreases.
  • Km remains constant.

In a Lineweaver-Burk Plot, the addition of a non-competitive inhibitor causes plots with the same x-intercept (Km is unaffected) but different slopes and y-intercepts.

Lineweaver-Burk plot is also known as the double reciprocal plot.

Competitive inhibition (graph A) - Here, the inhibitor is a structural analog of the substrate. Inhibitor molecules are competing with the normal substrate molecules for binding to the active site of the enzyme.

Uncompetitive inhibition (graph B) - Here, the inhibitor does not have any affinity for the free enzyme. The inhibitor binds to the enzyme-substrate complex, but not to the free enzyme. Here, both Vmax and Km are decreased. Inhibition of placental alkaline phosphatase (Regan isoenzyme) by phenylalanine is an example of uncompetitive inhibition.

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: A first-year medical student was recently given an intramuscular vaccine shot in the arm.  What is the origin of the muscle in which the shot is generally given?
questions.solution:
Intramuscular injection for the purpose of vaccination is generally given in the deltoid muscle in the arm. A part of the deltoid originates from the acromion part of the scapula which is marked as "B" in this image.

Deltoid arises from:

  • the anterior border and superior surface of the lateral third of the clavicle
  • the lateral margin and superior surface of the acromion
  • the lower edge of the crest of the scapular spine

and inserts in the deltoid tubercle on the lateral aspect of the midshaft of the humerus.

Parts of scapula marked:

A - Coracoid process

B - Acromion

C - Glenoid cavity

D - Inferior angle

questions.text: A 25-year old woman at 34 weeks of gestation with an Rh-negative pregnancy undergoes the following analysis. The amniotic fluid bilirubin levels plotted, fall in zone 1 of the graph given below. Which of the following indicates the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The graph shown in the above image is modified Liley's chart and the fetus is unlikely to be affected, and the pregnancy can be continued to term if the amniotic fluid bilirubin levels falls in zone 1 of modified Liley's chart.

Liley's chart: This helps in the estimation of hemolysis severity and indirect assessment of anemia. Amnionic fluid bilirubin is measured by a spectrophotometer and is demonstrable as a change in optical density absorbance at 450 nm—ΔOD450.

The chart is divided into 3 zones: 

Liley’s zone I (low zone): Rh-negative fetus or fetus is unlikely to be affected and the pregnancy can be continued till term.

Liley’s zone II (mid zone): Indicates fetal anemia

  • Repeat amniocentesis by 2 weeks → value upward→ cordocentesis→ hematocrit < 30%→ intrauterine transfusion to raise hematocrit 40–45%.
  • Preterm delivery may be needed after 34 weeks.
 

Liley’s zone III (high zone):

  • The fetus is severely affected and death is imminent.
  • Pregnancy >34 weeks → delivery.
  • Pregnancy <34 weeks → cordocentesis → hematocrit < 30% → intrauterine transfusion to raise hematocrit 40–45%.
  • Preterm delivery may be needed after 34 weeks

questions.text: A 55-year-old multiparous woman presents to you with complaints of genuine stress urinary incontinence(GSI). Investigation revealed loss of posterior urethrovesical angle and urethral hypermobility with normal intrinsic sphincter activity. Identify the type of GSI seen in this patient from the surgical procedure point of view?
questions.solution:
Type 2 GSI has been described in the above patient.

Genuine stress incontinence (GSI) occurs when the bladder pressure exceeds urethral pressure during physical stress in the absence of detrusor contraction

Considering the surgical procedure that should be done, GSI is classified into three types:

  • Type I: GSI occurs due to loss of posterior urethrovesical angle alone.
  • Type II: Loss of posterior urethrovesical angle as well as urethral hypermobility.
  • Type III: It is due to intrinsic sphincter deficiency.

Grading of GSI:

  • Grade I: Incontinence with only severe stress, such as coughing, sneezing, and jogging.
  • Grade II: Incontinence with moderate stress, such as fast walk, going up and down the stairs.
  • Grade III: Incontinence with mild stress such as standing.

Tests done for GSI(Genuine stress incontinence) are:

  1. Stress test
  2. Cotton swab stick test
  3. Marshall and Bonney test
  4. Urethroscopy
  5. Urodynamic evaluation- cystometry, urethrocystometry, uroflowmetry, etc

questions.text: You suspect non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy and advise Fundus fluorescein angiography(FFA) in a 50-year-old hypertensive male patient, who presented with the following visual field defect. Presence of which of the following finding in FFA would help you to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fundus fluorescein angiography in a patient with non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy would reveal delayed disc filling.

Altitudinal hemianopia is defined as hemianopia affecting the upper or lower half of the visual field. The above image depicts altitudinal hemianopia ( involving lower half of the visual field), which is present in both arteritic and non-arteritic ischemic optic neuropathy.

Associated with hypertension, diabetes, nocturnal hypotension.

  • Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Reduced color vision,
  • Altitudinal hemianopia

Note:

Altitudinal hemianopia is defined as hemianopia affecting the upper or lower half of the visual field.

questions.text: The suprascapular nerve is the content of which of the following triangles marked in the neck region?
questions.solution:
The suprascapular nerve (C5, C6) arises from the upper trunk of the brachial plexus. The nerve is a component of the subclavian triangle.

In the given image:

  • A – Carotid triangle
  • B – Occipital triangle 
  • C – Subclavian triangle
  • D – Muscular triangle

Contents of the subclavian triangle are:

  • 3rd part of Subclavian Artery and vein
  • Suprascapular artery and vein, transverse cervical artery
  • Supraclavicular lymph node
  • Trunks of Brachial plexus
  • Nerve to Serratus anterior
  • Branches from upper trunk – N to Subclavius, Suprascapular nerve

Related Pearl: Triangles of the Neck

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with complete obstruction of his left nostril and a nodule on the dorsum of the nose obscuring his vision as shown in the image. He gives a typical history of foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge with crust formation even before this nodule developed. The histology of the biopsied specimen is as shown in the image below. Which of the following is not true regarding the management of this condition?

choices.text: Both streptomycin (1 g/day) and tetracycline (2 g/day) are given together for a minimum period of 4–6 weeks
Steroids can be combined with antibiotics so as to reduce fibrosis.
Surgical intervention may be required to establish the airway and correct nasal deformity.
Treatment can be stopped after a culture from biopsy material turns negative

questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is suggestive of rhinoscleroma. Treatment is stopped only when two consecutive cultures from the biopsy material are negative.

It can be diagnosed as rhinoscleroma, as the patient had a history of purulent foul-smelling nasal discharge with crusting before the development of nodule, which corresponds to the atrophic stage of rhinoscleroma 

Adding to this, the given histology shows large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing the causative bacilli, which are Mikulicz cells

Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus).

It has 3 stages

Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul-smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis.

Granulomatous stage– Painless, non-ulcerative Granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of a woody nose.

Cicatricial stage – Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx, larynx. 

Treatment: Streptomycin (1g/day) and tetracycline (2g/day) are given together for a period of 4 to 6 weeks. Steroids can be combined with antibiotics so as to reduce fibrosis.. Surgical intervention may be necessary to restore the airway and correction of the nasal deformity.

Treatment is stopped only when two consecutive cultures from the biopsy material are negative.

questions.text: You were asked to calculate the modified Bishop's score before inducing labour in a pregnant female. For which of the following parameters, would you assign a score of 1?
questions.solution:
While calculating the Bishop's score, Fetal head at -2 station is given a score of 1.

The Bishop score is a scoring system used to assess the inducibility. It is based on the station, dilation, effacement (or length), position, and consistency of the cervix noted by doing a vaginal examination.

Note: In the modified Bishop score (1991) the effacement is replaced by a cervical length in cm.

 

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

questions.text: Calculate hepatic clearance of a drug given that the hepatic blood flow is 2500 mL/min and hepatic extraction ratio is 0.4.
questions.solution:
The hepatic clearance of the drug is 1000 mL/min.

Clearance of a drug by an organ is the difference between the rate of presentation of the drug to the organ and the rate of exit of the drug from the organ. It is calculated by the equation:

CLorgan = Q x (CA-CV/CA)

where,

CLorgan =Clearance of the drug by the organ

Q = Blood flow to the organ

CA = Arterial drug concentration

CV = Venous drug concentration.

The extraction ratio (E) is the fraction of the drug that is removed from the blood by the eliminating organ. CA is the concentration of the drug presented to the organ and CA-CV is the drug removed by the organ, hence,

Extraction ratio (E) = CA-CV/CA

Therefore, the clearance of the drug by the organ can be simply written as,

CLorgan = Q x E

In the question, it is given that the hepatic blood flow is 2500 mL/min and the hepatic extraction ratio is 0.4.

Substituting the values in the above equation, 

CLorgan = 2500 X 0.4

= 1000 mL/min

questions.text: You manage a patient diagnosed with an early stage of squamous cell carcinoma of  anus with Nigro regimen. This regimen includes the combination of all the following except
questions.solution:
Nigro regimen used in the treatment of squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal includes all the above except epirubicin.

Nigro regimen: It is used as a primary therapy. It includes a combination of chemotherapy and radiation (combined modality therapy).

Treatment of squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal:

  • The primary treatment for squamous cell carcinoma is by chemoradiotherapy (Nigro regimen)
  • A combination of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) with mitomycin C/ cisplatin is followed by external beam radiation to the pelvis with a minimum dose of 45 Gy.
  • Patients with a persistent disease which is diagnosed on pathological examination are managed with abdominoperineal resection.

The most common type of anal canal carcinoma is SCC. The patient presents with perianal mass, pain, anal discharge, and bleeding. The most common site of metastasis is the liver. The nodal metastasis is seen in peri-rectal and inguinal lymph nodes. Risk factors for carcinoma anal canal include HPV infection (16, 18, 31, 33), HIV or immunosuppression, and anal receptive intercourse.

Related Pearl: Chemotherapy for GI Tumours

GI malignancy

Chemotherapy

Esophageal carcinoma

ECF (Epirubicin + Cisplatin + 5-FU)

Gastric carcinoma

ECF (Epirubicin + Cisplatin + 5-FU)

Small intestine adenocarcinoma

5-FU

Colorectal carcinoma

FOLFOX-IV (5-FU + Leucovorin + Oxaliplatin)

Carcinoma of the anal canal

Nigro Regimen: Chemoradiation (5-FU + Mitomycin C) + Radiation

questions.text: A 56-year-old  male was admitted with complaints of breathing difficulty and confusion. Blood investigations show positive reports for ß-d glucan assay and raised galactomannan antigen levels. CT scan shows a pulmonary consolidation. Which of the following drugs will be the most effective and increase the likelihood of survival in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of pulmonary consolidation and positive ß-d glucan and raised galactomannan antigen point towards a diagnosis of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis. Voriconazole is the most effective drug in the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, and it also improves survival rates.

It can also be used against Candida species (including glabrata and krusei) in esophageal candidiasis, and Scedosporium and Fusarium species.

Treatment is initiated with an intravenous infusion of 6 mg/kg every 12 h for two doses, followed by 3–4 mg/kg every 12 h. Once the patient improves, 200 mg oral tablets given every 12 h.

  • Voriconazole is contraindicated in pregnancy.  
  • Liver function should be monitored during therapy.
  • It can prolong the QTc interval, a risk factors for torsades de pointes.
  • Transient visual or auditory hallucinations are common after the first dose, usually at night and particularly with intravenous administration.
  • Anaphylactoid reactions and rash can also occur
  • Intravenous voriconazole should be used with caution in patients with renal failure

Aspergillosis is a spectrum of diseases caused by aspergillus species. Manifestation may range from an allergic reaction in atopic individuals to an aspergilloma in a pre-existing cavity. In case of immunocompromised patients, it might lead to invasive bronchopulmonary aspergillosis. 

 The following signs are seen on CT in Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis:

  • Monod sign refers to the gas that surrounds a mycetoma (most commonly an aspergilloma) in a pre-existing pulmonary cavity.
  • Air crescent sign describes the crescent of air that can be seen in invasive aspergillosis.

questions.text: A patient complains of dysphagia and cough for the past 6 months and also has a history of atopy. You notice the following finding during endoscopy and advice biopsy. To make a definitive diagnosis of the likely condition, considering the clinical picture, the biopsy specimen should reveal a minimum of ___________
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the endoscopic findings is suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis and to make a definitive diagnosis the biopsy specimen should reveal a minimum of 15 eosinophils per high-power field

Eosinophilic esophagitis shows the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus. This appearance is called as the feline esophagus or ringed esophagus.

It is characterized by eosinophilic infiltration of the oesophageal wall, presumably of allergic or idiopathic origin. The most common presenting symptom is dysphagia, and more than half have some history of atopy. 

Dysphagia may occur with liquids or solids, but solid food dysphagia is most common.

The treatment of eosinophilic esophagitis is largely symptomatic and includes testing for food allergies and the elimination of identified food items from the diet. Second-line therapy includes inhaled or ingested corticosteroids. If dysphagia is not relieved with steroids, it may be necessary to dilate the  esophagus.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the demographic process and cycle of various countries. Which of the following statements would likely be true for India?

choices.text: Birth rate lower than death rate

questions.solution:
India is currently in the third (late-expanding) stage of the demographic cycle, which is characterized by a decreasing demographic gap.

A demographic gap is a difference between the birth rate and the death rate. The demographic gap is maximum in the early-expanding phase, characterized by a high birth rate and low death rate. As the demography of the country transitions to the late-expanding phase, both the birth rate and death rate fall, causing a decreasing demographic gap. Although the birth rate is falling in the late-expanding phase, it is still higher than the death rate, which causes the population to increase.

Other options:

Option A: A birth rate lower than the death rate is seen in the fifth (declining) stage of the demographic cycle.

Option B: The maximum demographic gap is seen in the second (early-expanding) stage, characterized by a high birth rate and low death rate.

Option D: The stationary population is seen in the first (high stationary) stage and fourth (low stationary) stage of the demographic cycle.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient was brought to the ER after RTA, his RR is 25/min, BP is 80/45mmHg. On examination, hyper-resonance is heard over the left side of the chest. The chest X-ray performed is given below. What would be the appropriate management in this case?

choices.text: Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)
Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hemodynamic instability, hyper-resonance on the left side of the chest, and the X-ray findings are suggestive of tension pneumothorax. It is managed by inserting a wide-bore needle in the 5th intercostal space (ICS) followed by placing an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS.

Traumatic pneumothorax can be:

  • Simple pneumothorax: Without hemodynamic instability
  • Tension pneumothorax: With hemodynamic instability

The X-ray given below is showing a left-sided tension pneumothorax. A large, well-demarcated area is devoid of lung markings on the left side. The yellow arrows are pointing to the tracheal deviation and the mediastinal shift to the right side. 

Management:

  • Simple pneumothorax: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety
  • Tension pneumothorax: 
    • Immediate management: Urgent needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS, anterior to the midaxillary line
    • Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety

Note: According to ATLS 10th edition

  • In adults, needle thoracostomy or needle decompression location is changed to 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line from 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location remains at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.

questions.text: Which of the following findings would you not expect in a female approaching menopause?

choices.text: Fall in the level of Inhibin A
Rise in the level of FSH

questions.solution:
A fall in the level of Inhibin B (not Inhibin A) is seen in women who are approaching menopause.

Menopause is defined as the time of cessation of ovarian function resulting in permanent amenorrhoea.

Prediction of approaching menopause

  • A fall in the level of inhibin B causes a rise in FSH level
  • A fall in the level of anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) suggests low ovarian reserve and low antral follicular count
  • A rise of FSH, which is more than normal LH level 

The study of FSH levels on days 2–5 after the last menstrual period is used to detect the premenopausal stage. Perimenopause is defined as a time period 3–4 years before menopause and followed by 1 year of amenorrhoea.

questions.text: A villager had to undergo lower limb amputation following a road traffic accident. He was later advised to use the prosthesis given below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the given prosthesis?

choices.text: Able to walk on uneven ground
Its mainly made of wood and rubber

questions.solution:
Jaipur foot, shown in the image, is mainly made of rubber and aluminum, whereas the SACH foot is made of wood and rubber.

Following are foot prosthesis:

  • Jaipur foot
  • Solid ankle cushion heel (SACH)
  • Stationary attachment flexible endoskeleton (SAFE), similar to Jaipur foot.
Prosthesis  SACH Jaipur foot 
Appearance Does not look normal Looks normal
Walking barefoot Not possible Possible
Mobility Restricted Allowed
Dorsiflexion Absent Present

Inversion/Eversion

Absent

 Present
Squatting Not possible Possible
Cost High Low

The above features make Jaipur foot more suitable for the Indian scenario.

questions.text: You notice a meteorologist using the instrument given below. What is he trying to measure?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is sling psychrometer (also called whirling psychrometer). It is used to measure the relative humidity.

Sling psychrometer:

  • It consists of two mercury thermometers (dry and wet), mounted side by side on a wooden frame.
  • A handle is present on one end of the frame, which allows for the rotation of the instrument.
  • By rotating the instrument, the bulbs are exposed to air at a definite velocity.
  • The wet bulb is first moistened by distilled water and the instrument rotated at the rate of four revolutions per second for about 15 seconds.
  • The instrument is rotated twice at an interval of 10 seconds. Two successive readings from the wet-bulb are obtained.
  • These readings are compared with the reading of the dry bulb, and with the help of suitable charts, the relative humidity of the air is determined.

Other instruments used to measure humidity include:

  • Dry and wet bulb hygrometer
  • Assman psychrometer

Other options:

Option A: The air temperature can be measured by several instruments such as globe thermometers, kata thermometer, dry and wet bulb thermometers.

Option C: Atmospheric pressure is measured by instruments called barometers. The commonly used instruments include Fortin's Barometer, Kew Pattern Station Barometer and Barograph.

Option D: Precipitation is a collective term used for rain, snow, hail, dew and frost. It is measured by Symon's Rain-gauge.

Related Pearl: Humidity

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.
  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers - most widely used instrument
  • Sling or whirling psychrometers

The following image depicts a whirling psychrometer:

The following image depicts an Assmann psychrometer:

The following image depicts a dry and wet hygrometer:

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to you with complaints of vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odor with a pH of  4.7. Microscopy reveals the cell shown in the below image. According to CDC guidelines, all the following could be used to treat this condition except?

choices.text: Metronidazole oral tablets 500 mg twice daily

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the image showing a clue cell is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis and 5% clotrimazole vaginal cream is not used in the treatment of bacterial vaginosis. 

Bacterial vaginosis is associated with alteration in the normal vaginal flora. There is a decrease in lactobacilli with a 100-fold increase in the growth of other anaerobic bacteria namely Haemophilus vaginalis, Gardnerella, Mobiluncus, and Myco­plasma hominis.

The patient complains of vaginal discharge with a fishy odor. Microscopy shows characteristic clue cells, which are vaginal epithelial cells with margins obscured by microbes. These suggest a diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis.

Amsel’s criteria are used in the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis which includes:

  • Homogenous vaginal discharge
  • Vaginal pH > 4.5
  • Amine-like odor(fishy odor) on adding KOH (Whiff test positive)
  • Clue cells (>20% of cells)

At least three of the four criteria should be present to confirm the diagnosis.

The CDC recommends one of the following treatment regimens.

  • Tablet metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days
  • Clindamycin 2% cream 5 g intravaginally for 7 days
  • Metronidazole 0.75% gel 5 g intravaginally for 5 days

Other drugs that can be used include tinidazole and secnidazole. 

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginitis

Candidal vaginitis
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomonas vaginalis Candida albicans
Aetiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual transmission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test The whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: A 22-year-old presents to the OPD following the consumption of a chemical. He complained of a hot burning sensation extending from mouth to stomach and had difficulty in breathing. After 48 hours, the patient passed dark, smoky urine which turned olive green in the urobag. Which of the following is most likely to be consumed by this patient?
questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario history of burning sensation, difficulty in breathing, and passage of olive green color urine (carboluria) is suggestive of Carbolic acid/ phenol poisoning.

Poisoning by carbolic acid is called carbolism.

Signs and symptoms:

  • Local skin effects: Burning, tingling followed by anesthesia and greyish-white sloughing 
  • Headache, giddiness, tinnitus
  • Vomiting, diarrhea, pain abdomen
  • Pulmonary and laryngeal edema, respiratory failure
  • Muscular spasms, convulsions
  • Collapse
  • A clammy, cold sweating body
  • Pupils dilated
  • Methemoglobinemia 

In carbolic acid poisoning if the patient survives for 48 hrs there will be carboluria followed by anuria. The victim will pass dark, smoky urine which soon turns olive green on standing due to the oxidation of hydroquinone and pyrocatechol. 

Management depends on the route of administration.

In case of poisoning through skin absorption

  • Remove the contaminated garments
  • Cleanse the site by mopping with a wet cloth and washing with soap and water
  • Apply olive oil/ methylated spirit/ 10 percent ethyl alcohol, which can prevent further absorption
  • Give normal saline + sodium bicarbonate (I/V- drip)

In case of poisoning through the oral route

  • Perform gastric lavage: Though phenol corrodes the stomach wall, it also hardens it, unlike other corrosive poisons. Hence gastric lavage is performed whenever possible with plenty of lukewarm water containing animal charcoal, olive oil, magnesium or sodium sulfate or saccharated lime, soap solution, 10 percent glycerine, etc. When the lavage is completed, 30 gm of magnesium sulfate or medicinal liquid paraffin should be left in the stomach.
  • Give egg white: Epsom salt/demulcents orally.

Related Pearl: Urine Color caused by certain Toxins

Urine colours

Causes

Olive green colour urine on standing

Carbolic acid

Grey-black

Phenols, cresols

Opaque appearance which settles on standing

Primidone crystals

Orange or orange-red

Rifampicin, iron (especially after giving desferrioxamine)

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese smoker presents with hypertension, moon facies, and easy bruisability. On examination, multiple purple striae are noticed over the abdomen. Which of the following statements is true about this condition?

choices.text: Basal plasma ACTH level is used as a screening test.
Raised late night salivary cortisol level is used for diagnosis.
Overnight 100-mg dexamethasone-suppression test is used for diagnosis.
24-h urine free cortisol level is raised

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an obese patient with hypertension, moon facies, and easy bruisability with multiple purple striae over the abdomen is suggestive of Cushing's syndrome. 24-h urine-free cortisol level is raised and is a cost-effective screening test.

Cushing syndrome is characterized by prolonged exposure to high circulating levels of cortisol, i.e., hypercortisolism, which can be due to endogenous or exogenous causes. 

Endogenous hypercortisolism can be ACTH dependent or ACTH independent. ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism caused by an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma is termed Cushing's disease. ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism can also be caused by ectopic ACTH-secreting tumors. ACTH-independent hypercortisolism is mainly caused by adrenal hyperplasia, adenoma, and carcinoma.

Exogenous hypercortisolism due to the prolonged use of glucocorticoids is the most common cause of Cushing's syndrome.

Excess cortisol increases the rate of gluconeogenesis, glycogenolysis, and insulin resistance. Cortisol directly affects the transcription and translation of enzyme proteins involved in the metabolism of fats, glycogen, protein synthesis, and Krebs' cycle. The excess catabolism of proteins causes purplish striae of the torso, osteoporosis, and poor wound healing. 

24-h urine-free cortisol (UFC) can detect endogenous overproduction of cortisol and is used as a screening test. An overnight 1-mg dexamethasone suppression test (Option C) can be used to identify patients with hypercortisolism.

Elevated midnight serum or salivary samples of cortisol are suggestive of Cushing’s disease. But, in smokers, late-night salivary cortisol can be falsely high (Option B) due to the inhibition of 11-beta-hydroxy dehydrogenase on the salivary gland, and hence it is not confirmatory. 

Basal plasma ACTH levels distinguish patients with ACTH-independent (adrenal glucocorticoid) from those with ACTH-dependent (pituitary ACTH) Cushing’s syndrome. Mean basal ACTH levels are higher in patients with ectopic ACTH secretion.  

  • Following dynamic tests are used to distinguish between ectopic and pituitary sources of excess ACTH:
    • ACTH stimulation in response to CRH 
    • Differential sensitivity to glucocorticoid feedback

Most ACTH-secreting pituitary tumors are <5 mm in diameter, and about 50% are undetectable by sensitive MRI.

Tapering exogenous steroids is the best therapy for iatrogenic Cushing's syndrome. The treatment of choice for Cushing's disease is selective transsphenoidal resection, and radiotherapy can be used in failed transsphenoidal surgery.

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text: In a child with difficult intravenous cannulation, an emergency intraosseous infusion is made through the tibia. What is the ideal site for inserting the needle in this tibial intraosseous infusion?

choices.text: Below the tibial tuberosity at a 45° angle towards the epiphyseal plate
Below the tibial tuberosity at a 45° angle away from epiphyseal plate
Above the tibial tuberosity at a 45° angle towards the epiphyseal plate
Above the tibial tuberosity at a 45° angle away from epiphyseal plate

questions.solution:
In tibial intraosseous infusion, a needle is inserted 2–3 cm below the tibial tuberosity at a 45° angle away from the epiphyseal plate.

Intraosseous access involves placing a catheter into the marrow venous plexus and administering crystalloids, colloids, drugs and blood which leads to rapid and reliable absorption into the systemic circulation. It provides emergency access to the venous circulation in pediatric patients by way of the large medullary venous channels. The needle is directed away from the epiphyseal plate to minimize the risk of injury.

The disadvantage of this route is the risk of osteomyelitis, compartment syndrome, and bone marrow or fat embolism.

questions.text: A 58-year-old chronic alcoholic woman presented to the dermatology outpatient department with the following lesion over the extensor aspect of the arm. All the following are the histopathological features seen in this condition, except _______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical image is indicative of psoriasis. All the following histopathological features are seen in this condition except suprapapillary thickening, instead suprapapillary thinning is seen.

Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin with systemic manifestations. The sustained inflammation leads to uncontrolled proliferation of the epidermal keratinocytes.

In a normal individual, it takes approximately 30 days for basal epidermal keratinocytes to proliferate, differentiate, and ascend through the layers of the epidermis. However, this process takes only 4-5 days in a patient with psoriasis. 

It can be caused due to drugs (lithium, antimalarials, interferon-α), seasons (winter), infections (streptococcal), alcohol abuse, and smoking. 

Histopathological features of psoriasis include:

  • Acanthosis- Irregular epidermal thickening 
  • Hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis
  • Suprapapillary thinning
  • Clubbing or elongation of rete ridges at the base
  • Kogoj spongiform pustules- collection of neutrophils in the malpighian layer (stratum basale and stratum spinosum referred together)
  • Munro microabscesses- collection of neutrophils in stratum corneum
  • Dilated, tortuous blood vessels in the dermis

Psoriasis patient presents with skin involved in the form of red/ salmon pink, scaly, and well-demarcated lesions. A peripheral clearing (ring of Woronoff) may be present. It is usually seen on the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

The appearance of a smooth, glossy red membrane with small bleeding points on the removal of the scales by gentle scraping is known as Auspitz sign, which is characteristic. It is associated with Koebner or isomorphic phenomenon.

Topical application of steroids, retinoids, vitamin D, and emollients is the mainstay of management

The following is an image of psoriasis. Its epidermis shows markedly elongated rete ridges, with bulbous thickening. Also, it shows thin suprapapillary epidermal plates, edema, and dilated vessels in the dermal papillae.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for different types of psoriasis

Type Drug of choice
Chronic Plaque Psoriasis Methotrexate
Erythrodermic Psoriasis Methotrexate 
Psoriatic Arthritis Methotrexate / Apremilast
Pustular Psoriasis Acitretin
Psoriasis in HIV patients Acitretin
Impetigo Herpetiformis

1. Systemic Corticosteroids

2. Cyclosporine
Erythrodermic Psoriasis in Pregnancy Systemic Corticosteroids 

 

Related Pearl: Drugs Inducing or Exacerbating Psoriasis

Drugs Inducing or Exacerbating Psoriasis

The following drugs are implicated in the exacerbation of psoriasis:

  • Beta blockers
  • Synthetic antimalarials
  • NSAIDS
  • Lithium
  • ACE inhibitors & angiotensin receptor blockers
  • Interferon alpha
  • Tetracycline
  • Terbinafine
  • Gemfibrozil

questions.text:
A 33-year-old female patient presented with a 2-cm thyroid nodule. The results of thyroid function tests are within normal limits. FNAC of the nodule was done, and the findings are shown in the given image. Identify the incorrect statement regarding this condition.

FNAC - Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology

choices.text: Exposure to ionizing radiation is causative.

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and histopathological slide showing epithelial cells with clear ground-glass or Orphan Annie–eye nuclei are suggestive of the diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Papillary thyroid cancers usually have an excellent prognosis.

Papillary carcinoma thyroid has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate of around 95%. The prognosis of papillary thyroid cancer is poor when age is more than 40 years, in the presence of extrathyroidal extension, and in the presence of distant metastases.

Papillary carcinoma thyroid (PTC) is the most common thyroid cancer. It is frequently associated with exposure to ionizing radiation. A gain-of-function mutation in BRAF is commonly seen in papillary thyroid cancer. Translocations that result in gene fusions of RET or NTRK are also seen in the PTC. 

Metastasis usually occurs via the lymphatic route, but hematogenous metastasis is less common. PTCs appear as cold masses on thyroid scintigraphy.

Microscopic features of papillary thyroid carcinoma:

  • The carcinoma shows branching papillae with fibrovascular stalk covered with simple or stratified cuboidal epithelium.
  • At high power, the nuclei appear optically clear or empty as the chromatin is dispersed. These empty-appearing nuclei are called Orphan Annie–eye nuclei.
  • Concentric calcified structures called psammoma bodies are usually seen.
  • Foci of lymphatic invasion by the tumor are usually present.

The presence of Orphan Annie-eye nuclei is diagnostic of papillary thyroid cancer, regardless of the presence of papillary architecture.

Variants of papillary carcinoma thyroid:

  1. Tall cell variant - Occurs in older people. Tall columnar cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm. The presence of BRAF mutations is diagnostic of this variant. They present with a higher rate of vascular invasion, extrathyroidal extension, and cervical and distant metastases than conventional PTC.
  2. Diffuse sclerosing variant - Occurs in younger individuals. This variant lack BRAF mutations, but RET/PTC translocations are present. There is a prominent papillary growth pattern with nests of squamous metaplasia. There is extensive, diffuse fibrosis throughout the thyroid gland, associated with lymphocytic infiltrate, simulating Hashimoto thyroiditis.
  3. Follicular variant - It has the characteristic nuclear features of papillary carcinoma and an almost totally follicular architecture. Contrasting to conventional PTC, this variant has a gain-of-function mutation of RAS.

The image below shows psammoma bodies in the papillary carcinoma thyroid. Inset shows a single concentrically calcified psammoma body.

Related Pearl: Gene alterations in thyroid cancer

Type of Thyroid Carcinoma  Mutations
Papillary Carcinoma

BRAF mutation

RET/PTC rearrangement

MET

NTRK1 fusion gene

GDNF - glial derived neurotropic factor
Follicular carcinoma  

RAS mutation

PIK3CA mutation

PTEN mutation

PAX8/PPAR1 fusion gene
Medullary carcinoma  RET mutation
Follicular adenoma  

TSH-R mutation

Gsα (GNAS) mutation

Ras mutation (<20% cases)

PAX8/PPARγ1 fusion (<10% cases)

PTEN
 Anaplastic carcinoma  

CTNNB1 (β-catenin)

TP53 inactivation

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the graph shown below?

choices.text: This is an example of a negative skew.

questions.solution:
The graph does not show a normal distribution. The image shows a negatively skewed distribution.

A normal distribution has the data distributed symmetrically. This data distribution is asymmetric. 

A distribution is negatively skewed, or skewed to the left, if the scores fall toward the higher side of the scale and there are very few low scores.

Here Mode>Median>Mean whereas in Right skewed distribution Mean>Median>Mode

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.
